questions.text: A woman whose blood type is A, Rh positive, and a man whose blood type is B, Rh positive, come to the clinic with a 3-year-old girl whose blood type is O, Rh negative. What can be said about the relationship of these two adults to this child?

choices.text: The woman can be the child’s natural mother, but the man cannot be the natural father
The man can be the child’s natural father, but the woman cannot be the natural mother
Neither adult can be the natural parent of this child
This couple can be the natural parents of this child

questions.solution: Each parent needs only a single allele for either the A or B antigen or the Rh(D) antigen to express these antigens on their blood cells and other cell types. Thus, if each parent also carries an allele for blood type O, as well as a null allele for the Rh(D) antigen, then the child can be homozygous for the recessive O allele and the Rh(D)-negative allele

questions.text: A breast-fed infant began to vomit frequently and lose weight. Several days later she developed jaundice, hepatomegaly and bilateral cataract. What is the possible cause for these symptoms:
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestations are typical of classical Galactosemia.

Bilateral cataract rules out the possibility of Von Gierke's disease and hereditary fructose intolerance although other symptoms are there in both these diseases.

In juvenile diabetes mellitus, jaundice and hepatomegaly are not observed.

ADDITIONAL EDGE:

Fig.: Galactosemia

GALACTOSEMIA:

  • Deficiency of Galactokinase: known as Minor Type Galactosemia.

Excess Galactose gets converted to Galactitol/Dulcitol with the help of enzyme Aldose Reductase (same enzyme which converts glucose to sorbitol). Galactitol is hygroscopic in nature. In excess it will cause oil drop cataract.

  • Deficiency of GALT: this is known as Classical Type Galactosemia.

Excess Galactose-1-P accumulates in liver and brain leading to jaundice and mental retardation. Excess Galactose-1-P also inhibits enzyme Galactokinase by product inhibition. If this patient still continue to take galactose in diet then excess galactose is converted to galactitol leading to oil drop cataract.

  • Deficiency of Epimerase is rare

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has a 2-year history of progressive muscle weakness in all limbs, with severe muscle atrophy and reduced MSRs in both lower limbs. In his upper limbs, the muscle atrophy is less pronounced and the MSRs are exaggerated. Which of the following types of neuronal degeneration would postmortem examination most likely show?

choices.text: Demyelination of axons in the posterior and lateral columns
Demyelination of axons in the posterior limb of the internal capsule
Loss of neurons from the globus pallidus
Loss of neurons from the paracentral lobule and from the anterior horns of the spinal cord

questions.solution: ALS affects both the upper and LMNs. It is also referred to as motor systems disease. A loss of Purkinje cells as seen in cerebellar cortical atrophy (cerebello-olivary atrophy) results in cerebellar signs. Cell loss in the globus pallidus and putamen is seen in Wilson disease (hepatolenticular degeneration). Demyelination of axons in the posterior and lateral columns is seen in subacute combined degeneration. Demyelination of axons in the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in contralateral spastic hemiparesis.

questions.text: What is the type of epiphysis involved the coracoid process?
questions.solution:
Option D: Atavistic

  • This is a case of coracoid process fracture.
  • The structure involved in this pathology is a coracoid process.
  • Atavistic means that a phylogenetically independent bone, which in humans is fused to another bone.
  • Example: The coracoid process of the scapula.

Pressure epiphysis

Traction epiphysis

Atavistic epiphysis

Aberrant epiphysis

Articular ends (takes part in the transmission of weight)

Example: Head of the femur

Nonarticular (does not take part in the transmission of weight)

Provides attachment to one or more tend that exert traction on the epiphysis.

Example: Tubercles of humerus, mastoid process.

Phylogenetically an independent bone, which in humans is fused to another bone.

Example: The coracoid process of the scapula

It is not always present

Example: Epiphysis of the head of the first metacarpal

 

Option A: Pressure

  • Articular ends (takes part in the transmission of weight)
  • Example: Head of the femur

Option B: Traction

  • Non-articular (does not take part in the transmission of weight)
  • Provides attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis.
  • Example: Tubercles of humerus, mastoid process.

Option C: Aberrant

  • It is not always present.
  • Example: Epiphysis of the head of the first metacarpal

questions.text: An experiment is performed in the laboratory to study the movement of ions across the membranes. Scientists have prepared two solutions of potassium chloride with different osmolarities. The lab's temperature has been optimized to normal physiological conditions of the living cells. Solution A and solution B are separated by a membrane, which is permeable to K+ and impermeable to Cl- Solution B is at 1 mM KCl and solution A is at 100 mM KCl. Which of the following statements best relates to Solution A and Solution B?

choices.text: K+ ions will diffuse from solution A to solution B until the [K+] of both solutions is 50.5 mM
K+ ions will diffuse from solution B to solution A until the [K+] of both solutions is 50.5 mM
KCl will diffuse from solution A to solution B until the [KCl] of both solutions is 50.5 mM
K+ will diffuse from solution A to solution B until a membrane potential develops with solution A negative with respect to solution B

questions.solution:
Option D: K+ will diffuse from solution A to solution B until a membrane potential develops with solution A negative with respect to solution B

  • In a solution, KCl dissociates into K+ and Cl−. Different concentrations of these and other ions across the membranes determine membrane diffusion potentials.
  • Every cell type functions at a different physiological membrane potential.
  • Charged ions move across the permeable membranes along or against the concentration gradient according to the membrane diffusion potential.
  • So membrane diffusion potential difference determines the movement of charged ions across the membranes.
  • The membrane is permeable only to K+ ions. K+ will diffuse down its concentration gradient from solution A to solution B, leaving some Cl− ions behind in solution A.
  • A diffusion potential will be created, with solution A negative concerning solution B.

Option A: K+ ions will diffuse from solution A to solution B until the [K+] of both solutions is 50.5 mM

  • This option is incorrect because K+ has a positive charge, and its movement across the membranes depends mainly upon the membrane diffusion potentials and not on the osmolarity gradient.

Option B: K+ ions will diffuse from solution B to solution A until the [K+] of both solutions is 50.5 mM

  • This option is incorrect because solution B has a lower osmolarity than solution A and solution A is more positively charged than solution B.
  • So positively charged potassium ions will not move from solution B to solution A.

Option C: KCl will diffuse from solution A to solution B until the [KCl] of both solutions is 50.5 mM

  • KCl solution dissociates into K+ and Cl- ions.
  • The membrane used in this experiment is permeable only to K+ and is impermeable to Cl-.
  • That is why KCl can't move across the membrane as a molecule.

questions.text: During a domestic dispute, a 16-year-old boy receives a deep stab wound around the superior angle of the scapula near the medial border, which injures both the dorsal scapular and spinal accessory nerves. Such an injury could result in paralysis or weakness of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution: The dorsal scapular nerve innervates the levator scapulae and rhomboid muscles, whereas the accessory nerve innervates the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. The serratus posterior superior is innervated by ventral primary rami of the spinal nerves, whereas the splenius cervicis and erector spinae are innervated by dorsal primary rami of the spinal nerves.

questions.text: CO2 is transported from the tissues to the lungs predominantly in the form of bicarbonate ion. Compared with arterial red blood cells, which of the following options best describes venous red blood cells?

choices.text:
Concentration
Cell Volume


Decreased
No Change

questions.solution: Dissolved CO2 combines with water in red blood cells to form carbonic acid, which dissociates to form bicarbonate and H+ ions. Many of the bicarbonate ions diffuse out of the red blood cells, whereas chloride ions diffuse into the red blood cells to maintain electrical neutrality. The phenomenon, called the chloride shift, is made possible by a special bicarbonate-chloride carrier protein in the red blood cell membrane that shuttles the ions in opposite directions. Water moves into the red blood cells to maintain osmotic equilibrium, which results in a slight swelling of the red blood cells in the venous blood.

questions.text: Which one of the following substances is unable to travel across the plasma membrane by simple diffusion?
questions.solution:
• Na+ -charged- need carrier
  • others move by simple diffusion

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred fuel for the body in a fasting state?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fats

  • The preferred fuel for the body in a fasting state is mainly fats.
  • Fats stored in adipose tissues are broken down to fatty acids, which undergo oxidation to give energy during fasting and starvation.
  • In a fasting state, glucose must be provided for the brain and red blood cells, supplied by the glycogen reserves. To spare glucose for brain and red blood cells, muscles and other tissues do not take up glucose in the fasting state and instead utilize fatty acids and later ketone bodies.

Option A: Carbohydrates

  • Carbohydrates are the primary source of fuel in the fed-state.
  • Dietary carbohydrates provide energy for 2 hours after diet. After that, glycogen provides energy and can last up to 12-18 hours.
  • RBCs only use glucose under all conditions due to the lack of mitochondria required for beta-oxidation of the fatty acids.

Option C: Proteins

  • During starvation, the body starts using the proteins for energy when all of the carbohydrates and some fats are used up. However, the body tries to minimize protein use by adapting to use the ketone bodies produced from the fatty acid as fuel.

Option D: Amino acids

  • During fasting/starvation, amino acids are released from muscle protein degradation and travel to the liver for energy production and to provide substrates for gluconeogenesis.
  • Alanine is the most glucogenic amino acid, and it is released from the fasting muscle and undergoes the Cahill cycle.
  • Excess dietary amino acids from protein-rich diets can also contribute to a significant amount of energy in the fed state.

questions.text: Which among the following does not take part in forming the stomach bed?
questions.solution:
Option C: Tail of the Pancreas

  • The stomach lies on multiple structures termed the stomach bed. The tail of the pancreas does not comprise the stomach bed.
  • The stomach is a muscular organ that is located in the upper abdomen towards the left side.

  • The stomach has a right lesser curvature, which is connected to the porta hepatis of the liver by the lesser omentum (hepatogastric ligament), and a left greater curvature, which is connected to the greater omentum.
  • The cardiac region of the stomach receives the esophagus, and the pyloric portion of the stomach is connected to the duodenum approximately at the transpyloric plane (L1 vertebra)
  • The structure on which the posterior-inferior bed of the stomach lies is known as the stomach bed.
  • The stomach bed comprises the following structures:
    • Diaphragm
    • Left Kidney
    • Left suprarenal
    • Pancreas except for the tail
    • Splenic flexure of the colon
    • Splenic artery
    • Transverse mesocolon
  • The tail of the pancreas is not part of the stomach bed. However, the body of the pancreas supports the stomach.
  • The posterior surface of the stomach is separated from the stomach bed by the Lesser sac.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option A: Splenic artery

  • The splenic artery is a part of the stomach bed.

Option B: Splenic flexure.

  • Splenic flexure is also a part of the stomach bed.

Option D: Transverse mesocolon

  • Transverse mesocolon is part of the stomach bed.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin can perform its coenzyme function without phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Option Analysis:

  • Coenzyme form of thiamine is thiamine pyrophosphate → option a is excluded
  • Coenzyme form of pantothenate is phospho pantothenate → option c is excluded
  • Coenzyme form of pyridoxine is pyridoxal phosphate → option d is excluded

Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) whose coenzyme form is FAD (flavin adenine dinucleotide) which is not phosphorylated. So answer is B.

questions.text: 34 year female underwent surgery and specimen excised and sent for HPE. Lab results shown that the organ lined by columnar cells with microvilli.  Identify the organ
questions.solution: Gall bladder lined by tall columnar cell with microvilli

questions.text: During surgery for the removal of a thyroid tumor, a number of small masses of glandular tissue are noted just lateral to the thyroid gland. Metastasis from the thyroid tumor is suspected, but histological analysis of a biopsy reveals parathyroid tissue and remnants of thymus. How can this finding be explained?

choices.text: Tumor tissue has differentiated into normal tissue
A parathyroid gland tumor is also present
Ectopic glandular tissue is commonly found in this region

questions.solution: The parathyroid and thymus migrate in a caudal and medial direction during development; therefore, ectopic glandular tissue may be found anywhere along the migratory path.

questions.text: Damage to the medial collateral ligament by a valgus force often causes concomitant damage to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Medial meniscus

  • The medial meniscus is firmly attached to the medial (tibial) collateral ligament. Damage to the medial collateral ligament by a valgus force often causes concomitant damage to the medial meniscus because of this relationship.
  • The anterior cruciate ligament may be torn when the knee is hyperextended.
  • The lateral meniscus is not attached to the medial collateral ligament but receives muscular attachment to the popliteus muscle.
  • The posterior cruciate ligament also lies outside the synovial cavity and limits hyperflexion of the knee.

Option B: Anterior cruciate ligament

  • The anterior cruciate ligament is torn when an athlete is cutting, decelerating, jumping, or landing, pushing the knee into a position with enough force that causes the ACL to rupture.

Option C: Lateral meniscus

  • The lateral meniscus is injured by force medial to the knee joint.

Option D: Posterior cruciate ligament

  • The posterior cruciate ligament is torn by a direct blow to the anterior aspect of the proximal tibia on a flexed knee when the ankle is in plantar flexion.

questions.text: A young woman receives daily injections of a substance from the sixteenth day of her regular menstrual cycle, and menstruation does not occur as long as the injections persist. The injected substance could be which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option D: hCG

  • hCG stimulates the corpus luteum in the same way as LH.
  • With hCG administration, the corpus luteum continues to secrete estrogen and progesterone, preventing the breakdown of the endometrium and the onset of menstruation.

Option A: FSH

  • The administration of FSH promotes follicular development.
  • This would promote menstruation.

Option B: Progesterone’s action inhibitor

  • Inhibition of progesterone action leads to failure to maintain pregnancy,
  • More, progesterone is required for the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle

Option C: PGE2 inhibitor

  • It has no role in menstruation.
  • Instead, the analog of PGE1 leads to abortion.

questions.text: Physical examination of a tall and thin 10-year-old showed a small curvature to his spine (scoliosis), pectus carinatum, and a dislocation of the lens in one eye. He had a recent history of blood clots that required treatment. Suspecting of homocytinuria, the physician put the boy on pharmacological doses of vitamin B6, which alleviated some of the symptoms. The enzyme that is most likely to be defective in this child is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
In homocystinuria, homocystine accumulates (due to homocysteine accumulation). Classical homocystinuria is due to a defect in cystathionine β-synthase, which requires pyridoxal phosphate as a cofactor

Most often, the mutation in the enzyme leads to a reduction in affinity of the cofactor for the enzyme. Increasing cellular levels of pyridoxal phosphate, by taking pharmacological doses of vitamin B6, can overcome the reduction in enzyme activity and reduce homocysteine, and homocystine, levels.

None of the other enzymes listed as potential answers would regain activity in the presence of large amounts of vitamin B6. An inactivating mutation in S- adenoyslhomocysteine hydrolase would reduce homocysteine levels.

A defect in methionine synthase (which requires vitamin B12) would raise homocysteine levels, but could not be reversed by B6 treatment.

A defect in N5, N10-methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase would also raise homocysteine levels, but that enzyme requires NADH, and would not be rescued by elevated B6 levels.

questions.text: Under low or reduced light conditions, which chemical compound is responsible for the inward-directed sodium current in the outer segments of the photoreceptors?
questions.solution: In low light conditions, the level of cGMP is high. cGMP-dependent sodium channels in the outer portions of the rods and cones allow sodium ions to pass from the extracellular space to the intracellular space of the photoreceptor. This passage results in a membrane potential that is somewhat lower than the resting membrane potential of a typical neuron. The movement of the sodium ions and resulting electrical potential change as a result of this enhanced permeability is known as the dark current

questions.text:
If the structure indicated by the letter A is calcified, which of the following muscles is most likely paralyzed?
A 11-year-old boy falls down the stairs. A physician examines the radiograph of the boy’s shoulder region (see Figure below).
questions.solution: The scapular notch transmits the suprascapular nerve below the superior transverse ligament, whereas the suprascapular artery and vein run over the ligament. The suprascapular nerve supplies the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles. The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles. The subscapular nerves innervate the teres major and subscapularis muscles.

questions.text: Sugars are reducing in nature and get readily oxidized to form acids. The oxidation of the sugar galactose with a strong oxidizing agent produces which of the following?
questions.solution:
Options A and D: Mucic Acid and Saccharic Acid

Oxidation of sugars with acid forms sugar acids

  • In mild oxidation, either C1 is oxidized, or C6 is oxidized
    • Aldonic acid is produced if the Aldehyde group (C1) is oxidized.
    • If the last Carbon (C6) is oxidized, then Uronic Acid is produced
    • Under strong acid, both the first and last carbon of sugar is oxidized to form Saccharic Acid
  • Oxidation of Galactose with a strong oxidizing agent produces music Acid (forms insoluble crystals), which also forms the basis of the Mucic Acid Test when a strong oxidizing agent such as nitric oxide is added to a sample solution. A positive test resulting in saccharic/ mucic acid formation confirms the presence of Galactose or Lactose (Galactose containing sugar).
  • Similarly, glucose is converted to Glucosaccharic Acid in the presence of a strong oxidizing agent.
  • Mannose to Mannaric acid

Option B: Gluconic Acid

  • Oxidation of Glucose with a mild oxidizing agent produces gluconic acid (-CHO group at C1 is oxidized)
  • Mannose to Mannonic Acid
  • Galactose to Galactonic Acid

Option C: Galacturonic Acid

  • Oxidation of Galactose with a mild oxidizing agent produces galacturonic acid (-OH group at C6 is oxidized)
  • Mannose to Mannuronic Acid
  • Glucose to Glucuronic Acid

questions.text:
Sequence of movement of electrophoretic pattern of serum lipoproteins from cathode to anode:
1. Broad beta lipoprotein
2. Beta lipoprotein
3. Pre beta lipoprotein
4. Alpha lipoprotein
questions.solution:
Based on electrophoretic separation:

From cathode to anode, the order of lipoproteins in an electrophoretogram is:

  1. Chylomicron
  2. β-lipoprotein (LDL)
  3. Broad β-lipoprotein (IDL)
  4. Pre β-lipoprotein (VLDL)
  5. α-lipoprotein (HDL)

questions.text: Which compensatory changes occur when a person moves from a supine position to a standing position?
questions.solution:
Option B: Increased contractility

  • There is a decreased venous return to the heart, decreased cardiac output and decreased arterial pressure when a person stands up or in a standing position because in this posture, the blood pools in the leg veins.
  • The baroreceptors detect a decrease in arterial pressure, and the vasomotor centre is activated to increase sympathetic outflow and decrease parasympathetic outflow.
  • There is an increase in heart rate (resulting in a decreased PR interval), contractility and total peripheral resistance (TPR).
  • Because both heart rate and contractility increase, cardiac output will increase towards normal.

Option A: Decreased heart rate

  • When the patient stands from a sitting position, the baroreceptors detect the decrease in arterial pressure.
  • This causes a compensatory increase in the heart rate of the patient.

Option C: Decreased total peripheral resistance (TPR)

  • When the patient stands from a sitting or lying position, the baroreceptors detect a decrease in arterial pressure, and the vasomotor centre is activated to increase sympathetic outflow and decrease parasympathetic outflow.
  • There is an increase in heart rate (resulting in a decreased PR interval), contractility and total peripheral resistance (TPR).

Option D: Decreased cardiac output

  • When the patient stands from a sitting position, both heart rate and contractility are increased.
  • So, cardiac output will increase towards normal.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with advanced breast cancer presents with severe nausea, vomiting, and dehydration. She is not undergoing chemo-therapy currently.
Laboratory findings reveal elevated serum-ionized calcium. Parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are undetectable, but there is an increase in PTH-related peptide (PTHrP). The increased flow of calcium into the cell is an important component of the upstroke phase of the action potential in which of the following?
questions.solution: In intestinal smooth muscle, the upstroke of the action potential is caused by the flow of calcium into the cell. In cells of the cardiac ventricular muscle, the plateau phase of the action potential, but not the upstroke, is accompanied by the flow of calcium into the cells. Skeletal muscle fibers resemble nerve fibers. In both of these cells, the upstroke of the action potential is caused by the flow of sodium into the cell. Hypercalcemia occurs in approximately 10% of all malignancies and is most commonly seen in solid tumors, particularly breast carcinoma, renal carcinoma, and squamous cell carcinomas (eg, esophagus and lung). Solid tumors usually produce hypercalcemia by secreting PTHrP. The resulting humoral hyper-calcemia mimics primary hyperthyroidism, but with no elevation in PTH.

questions.text: A tRNA molecule that is supposed to carry cysteine (tRNAcys) is mischarged. So that it actually carries alanine (ala-tRNAcys). Assuming no correction occurs, what will be the fate of this alanine residue during protein synthesis:

choices.text: It will be incorporated into a protein in response to an alanine codon.
It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon.
It will remain attached to the tRNA as it cannot be used for protein synthesis.
It will be chemically converted to cysteine by cellular-enzymes.

questions.solution:
Aminoacyl tRNA synthetase enzyme

  • Attaches amino acid & tRNA and this step is the only proof reading step in translation.
  • If wrong amino acid gets attached during this step, then it can be corrected but if correction will not occur in this step, then this wrong amino acid will be added in the protein.
  • 20 cytoplasmic aminoacyl tRNA synthetases which can attach specific amino acid to the 3’ adenosine residue of the tRNA. This specific selection of tRNAs by aminoacyl tRNA synthetase is known as the second genetic code.
  • tRNAcys is usually recognized by the cysteinyl-tRNA synthetase and charged with Cysteine to produce cys-tRNAcys.
  • As per the question, Alanine is incorporated to the tRNAcys to produce ala-tRNAcys. Ribosomal machinery can’t detect the amino acid attached to the tRNA.
  • Interaction between the codon of mRNA and anticodon of tRNA determines the amino acid incorporated in the polypeptide chain.
  • Anticodon of alatRNAcys interacts with codon of Cysteine only.
  • So Alanine will be incorporated in the polypeptide in place of Cysteine.

questions.text: Which of the following structures harbors the cell bodies of abdominal pain fibers?

choices.text: Lateral horn of the spinal cord
Anterior horn of the spinal cord

questions.solution:
Option C: Dorsal root ganglion

  • The dorsal root ganglia are the cell bodies of afferent axons and thus provide the main support for the afferent nerve fibres.

  • The DRG is comprised of most of the body's sensory neurons.

  • The DRG is responsible for carrying the sensory messages from thermoreceptors, nociceptors, proprioceptors, and chemoreceptors to the central nervous system.

  • The DRG mainly controls pain (nociception) and temperature sensations.

  • The cell bodies of the abdominal pain fibres, as afferent fibres carry them, are located in the DRG.

Option A: Lateral horn of the spinal cord

  • The lateral horns are primarily found in the thoracic and upper parts of the lumbar and sacral regions.

  • They contain the preganglionic visceral motor neurons.

  • These neurons project to the sympathetic ganglia.

  • These neurons form the autonomic nervous system and conduct the impulses from the brain and spinal cord.

Option B: Anterior horn of the spinal cord

  • The anterior horns contain the cell bodies of general somatic efferent (GSE) fibres.

  • They have motor neurons that send axons through the anterior roots of the spinal nerves and innervate the skeletal muscles.

Option D: Sympathetic chain ganglion

  • The sympathetic chain ganglia mediate the somatic nervous system.

  • It has general visceral afferent and efferent axons to control involuntary bodily functions through the hypothalamus.

  • It contains cell bodies of sympathetic postganglionic fibres that supply the blood vessels, sweat glands, and hair follicles.

questions.text: Which antigens must be matched optimally between donors and recipients of solid organ transplants?

choices.text: Class I human leukocyte antigen (HLA) antigens only
Class I and Class II HLA antigens only
Class I and Class II HLA antigens and ABO antigens

questions.solution: Unmatched donor HLA antigens of both classes are recognized as foreign by recipient T cells. In addition, blood group (ABO) antigens are expressed on the cells of solid organs and can lead to strong organ rejection.

questions.text: Which of the following is the (water) soluble mobile carrier of electrons in the electron transport chain?
questions.solution:
There are two mobile electron carriers in the electron transport chain. Let’s compare them.

  Ubiquinone (Coenzyme Q) Cytochrome c
Chemical nature Lipid – made up of 10 isoprene units, hence the name Q10 Soluble protein
Accepts electrons from Complex I & II Complex III
Delivers electrons to Complex III Complex IV
Number of electrons that can be accepted at a time Two One
Other points: Statins inhibit the synthe­sis of coenzyme Q10 and result in muscle cramps Cytochrome c in cytosol medi­ates apoptosis.

questions.text: Xeroderma pigmentosa is caused by a group of closely related abnormalities in:
questions.solution:
Defect  in   nucleotide  excision  repair   leads to  Xeroderma   pigmentosa, which increases the chances of  skin   malignancy.

OTHER QUESTIONS FREQUENTLY ASKED ON THIS TOPIC

DNA  Repair  (Single  Strand  Break  Repair)

Most  DNA  repairs  occur in  G1  phase of cell cycle  but  only  mismatch  repair  occurs in  G2  phase  of  cell cycle.

Types of repair Phase of cell cycle Damage Cause Disease
Nucleotide excision repair G1 Thymine-Thymine dimers (T-T dimers) UV radiation Xeroderma pigmentosa
Base excision repair G1 mainly but can occur in any phase Cytosine deaminated to uracil Spontaneous, heat, infra red rays, viral infection, nitrous oxide MUTYH associated polyposis
Mismatch repair G2 Mismatched base Proofreading error HNPCC (Hereditary Non Polyposis Colorectal Cancer)
  • HNPCC  also known as Lynch syndrome → leads to increase risk for developing colon cancer.
  • Xeroderma   Pigmentosa  increase  the  chances of skin malignancy.

Double  Strand  Break  Repair

  • Non  homologous  end  joining (NHEJ)  repair: Defect   in  this  repair  system  can  lead  to  SCID (Severe Combined Immuno Deficiency)
  • Homologous  repair / recombination (HR):  Defective   HR  can  lead  to  Bloom  syndrome,   Werner syndrome,  Rothmund- thomson  syndrome,  Breast cancer  susceptibility 1 and 2,   Ataxia tenlangiectasia-  like   disorders,   Nijmegen   breakage   syndrome

questions.text: A medical student was recording potential in a vascular smooth muscle from stimulation of postganglionic sympathetic nerve. What is the name of the structure on the nerve where the neurotransmitter is stored and what is the response in the smooth muscle:

choices.text: Synaptic vesicle and end plate potential
Small dense core vesicle and excitatory postsynaptic potential
Large dense core vesicle and inhibitory junctional potential

questions.solution:
• The post ganglionic autonomic fibres supplying the smooth muscle is an example of neuroeffector junction. The nerve fibres are beaded with enlargement (varicosity) that contains synaptic vesicle. Neurotransmitter released at these varicosities produces change in membrane potential of smooth muscle, known as junctional potential. This potential may be excitatory or, inhibitory depending on neurotransmitter.
  • Synaptic vesicles are of 3 types:
    • Small clear type: contains Ach, Glycine, GABA or, glutamate.
    • Small dense core type: contains catecholamines
    • Large dense core type: contains neuropeptides

questions.text: Your Professor begins with a lecture on the axial skeleton (especially the vertebrae). He catches you murmuring something and calls you up to ask if you have already mastered this topic. You give the ‘NO’ nod, following which he asks, which joint do you think permits this movement. Your answer would be:-
questions.solution:
• Looking towards the right or left (‘NO’ movement of head) occurs at the atlantoaxial joint.
  • ‘YES’ movement occurs at the atlantooccipital joint and involves flexion & extension of head over the vertebra.
  • C2-C3 and C3-C4 joints allow mainly flexion & extension of the neck and a small degree of rotation is also possible.

questions.text: Best method to detect the given structure of protein is:
questions.solution:
• This is alpha helix shown i.e. secondary structure of protein.
  • Best method to detect secondary, tertiary and quaternary structure of protein is X-ray crystallography.
  • In this technique, protein is first crystallized and then X-ray beam is thrown over it and then 3D structure can be determined.

questions.text: A community medicine intern posted in rural PHC was researching various larvae of different species of mosquito. Identify the mosquito larva shown below in the photograph.
questions.solution:
Option A: Anopheles larva

  • The given image is showing a larva resting parallel to the surface of the water, with palmate hairs present on the abdominal segment & no siphon tube.
  • All these features are characteristic of the larva of the Anopheles mosquito.

Option B: Culex larvae

  • Culex larvae rest at an angle to the water surface & siphon tube is present.

Option C: Aedes larvae

  • Aedes larvae rest at an angle to the water surface & siphon tube is present.

Option D: Mansonia Larvae

  • Mansonia larvae are attached to the roots of Aquatic plants.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presented to the clinic with a history of blood in the cough for the past week. He reports that he had tuberculosis three years back, for which he took a six-month course of medications. On a chest x-ray, a granuloma is seen. The biopsy specimen of the tissue shows the following image on microscopy. What could the causative organism presumably be?
questions.solution:
Option D: Aspergillus

  • In the clinical scenario above, the patient presented with aspergillosis. It has resulted in the formation of an aspergilloma (fungus ball). The image in question reveals the microscopic appearance of aspergillus fumigatus with acute angle branching.

  • Aspergillus fumigatus causes skin, eyes, ears, and other organs infections, "fungus ball" in the lungs, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

  • It exists only as moulds. They have monomorphic septate hyphae that form V-shaped (dichotomous) branches. These hyphae branch at a 45-degree acute angle. The conidia of aspergillus form radiating chains.

  • They grow on decaying vegetation.

  • Transmission is by airborne conidia.

  • It is the most common cause of fungal sinusitis.

  • Aspergilloma: Fungal ball grows within and is usually restricted to an existing lung cavity, for example, due to old tuberculosis. It causes hemoptysis. A fungal ball can be seen on a chest x-ray.

  • In immunocompromised persons, especially those with neutropenia, Aspergillus can invade the lungs and other organs, producing hemoptysis and granulomas. Here the fungus first causes pneumonia and later disseminates to involve other organs, for example, the brain, kidneys, or heart.

  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a hypersensitivity reaction to the presence of Aspergillus in the bronchi.

  • Microscopic appearance: A wet preparation demonstrates septate hyphae and conidiophores. The conidiophores have swollen, rounded ends with chains of conidia borne on elongated cells called sterigmata.

  • Biopsy specimens show septate, branching hyphae invading tissue. Cultures show colonies with characteristic radiating chains of conidia.

  • The treatment depends on the severity of the disease and underlying conditions. It mainly includes itraconazole or amphotericin b.

Option A: Coccidioides

  • It is a dimorphic fungus that exists in two forms:

    • The environmental form: Hyphae form arthroconidia found in the desert sand. Arthroconidia are inhaled and enlarged, becoming spherules inside which the cytoplasm walls off, forming endospores.

    • Tissue form: Spherules with endospores.

  • It causes coccidioidomycosis, which results in Valley fever (asymptomatic to self-resolving pneumonia). Pulmonary lesions tend to calcify as they heal.

  • Systemic infections occur in immunocompromised individuals.

  • Treatment:  Amphotericin b

 

Option B: Blastomyces

  • It is a dimorphic fungus that exists in the following forms:

    •  Environmental form: Hyphae with nondescript conidia.

    • Tissue form: Broad-based budding yeasts with a double refractile cell wall.

  • It causes blastomycosis, which results in acute and chronic pulmonary disease.

  • Immunocompromised patients present with dissemination.

  • Treatment: Amphotericin b

 

Option C: Histoplasma

  • It is a dimorphic fungus which exists in the following forms:

    •  Environmental form: Hyphae with microconidia and tuberculate macroconidia.

    • Tissue forms: Small intracellular yeasts with a narrow neck on the bud. It has no capsule.

  • It is found in soil enriched

questions.text: "A conscious attempt by one individual to change or influence the general beliefs,understanding, values and behaviour of another individual or group of individuals in some desired way" denotes?
questions.solution: Persuasion Persuasion is the art of winning friends and influencing people. It is an art that does not employ force or deliberate manipulation. The sole purpose of communication is to influence. Persuasion is "a conscious attempt by one individual to change or influence the general beliefs, understanding, values and behaviour of another individual or group of individuals in some desired way": Persuasive communication is more effective than coercion or authoritative communication. Persuasion can change life style and modify the risk factors of disease.                                                                                                                                                                                   When persuasive communication is deliberately employed to manipulate feelings, attitudes and beliefs, it becomes "propaganda" or "brain washing"

questions.text: A 60 yrs elderly male  presented with complaints of mild chest pain, and cough with expectoration since 15 days.  The sputum culture on blood agar yielded gram-positive cocci. Which of the following would be the most useful test to identify the organism?
questions.solution:
• This 60 year old man with complaints of mild chest pain, and cough with expectoration since 15 days, has pneumonia wherein the sputum culture on blood agar has yielded gram-positive cocci. 
  • So the pathogenic organism is likely to be Streptococcus pneumoniae(Pneumococcus), for which bile solubility is best diagnostic test.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to inactivated influenza vaccine?

choices.text: People who have a severe allergy to chicken eggs
People with a history of anaphylactic reactions or other life-threatening allergic reactions to any of the constituents or trace residue of the vaccine
People with history of a mild reaction to influenza vaccination
People who developed Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS)within 6 weeks of getting an influenza vaccine

questions.solution:
CONTRAINDICATIONS: As a general rule,inactivated vaccines should not be administered to :

(1) People who have a severe allergy to chicken eggs;

(2) People with a history of anaphylactic reactions or other life-threatening allergic reactions to any of the constituents or trace residue of the vaccine;

(3) People with history of a severe reaction to influenza vaccination;

(4) People who developed Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS)within 6 weeks of getting an influenza vaccine;

(5) Children less than 6 months of age (inactivated influenza vaccine is not approved for this age group); and

(6) People who have a moderate-to-severe illness with a fever (they should wait till they recover to get vaccinated).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman contracts toxoplasmosis during her pregnancy and delivers a neonate at 37 weeks of gestation with a severe malformation of the central nervous system. MRI studies of the neonate reveal porencephaly and hydrocephalus. An X-ray film of the head shows irregular densities in the basal ganglia. These X-ray findings are best explained by which of the following mechanisms of disease?
questions.solution:
The answer is B: Dystrophic calcification. Dystrophic calcification reflects underlying cell injury. Serum levels of calcium are normal, and the calcium deposits are located in previously damaged tissue. Intrauterine Toxoplasma infection affects approximately 0.1% of all pregnancies. Acute encephalitis in the fetus afflicted with TORCH syndrome may be associated with foci of necrosis that become calcified. Microcephaly, hydrocephalus, and microgyria are frequent complications of these intrauterine infections. Metastatic calcification (choice D) reflects an underlying disorder in calcium metabolism.
Diagnosis: Dystrophic calcification

questions.text: Which of the following was not expected outcome of national Health Mission by 2017?

choices.text: Reduce MMR to less than 1/1000 live births

questions.solution:
National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) was launched in April 2005 and it morphed into National Health Mission (NHM) with launch of National Urban Health Mission (NUHM) during 2013. Thereafter, NRHM and NUHM became two sub-missions under the overarching NHM.

Expected outcomes of NHM by 2017 : Outcomes for NHM in the 12th Plan are synonymous with those of the 12th Plan, and are part of the overall vision.

  1. Reduce MMR to 1/1000 live births.
  2. Reduce IMR to 25/1000 live births.
  3. Reduce TFR to 2.1
  4. Prevention and reduction of anaemia in women aged 15–49 years.
  5. Prevent and reduce mortality & morbidity from communicable, non- communicable; injuries and emerging diseases.
  6. Reduce household out-of-pocket expenditure on total health care expenditure.
  7. Reduce annual incidence and mortality from Tuberculosis by half.
  8. Reduce prevalence of Leprosy to <1/10000 population and incidence to zero in all districts.
  9. Annual Malaria Incidence to be <1/1000.
  10. Less than 1 per cent microflaria prevalence in all districts.
  11. Kala-Azar Elimination by 2015, <1 case per 10000 population in all blocks.

Outcome of the National Health Mission (as of Mid 2017):

  1. Under 5 Mortality Rate (U5MR): Declined from 59 in 2010 to 43 in 2015. Percentage annual rate of decline during 2010-2015 has accelerated to 6.1% from 3.7% observed during 1990-2010. Annual rate of decline in 2014-15 was 4.4%. India is likely to have achieved the Millennium Development Goal 4 of U5MR at the present rate of decline.
  2. Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR):(number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births) declined from 178 during 2010-12 to 167 during 2011-13. Subsequent data is yet to be notified by RGI. India is likely to have achieved the Millennium Development Goal 5 of MMR at the rate of declines that were achieved.
  3. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR)(number of deaths of children less than one year of age per 1000 live births) – declined from 39 in the year 2014 to 37 in 2015.
  4. Total Fertility Rate (TFR) – declined from 2.5 in 2010 to 2.3 in the year 2015 (Presently it is 2.2 as per NFHS 2015-16). We are likely to achieve the 12thFive Year Plan target for TFR of 2.1 by 2017.
  5. Malaria API has declined from 1.10 in 2011 to 0.84 in 2016. The 12thPlan target in respect of Malaria has been achieved and the API has been kept below 1 case per 1000 population.
  6. Mortality due to TB per 100000 population reduced from 40 in 2010 to 36 in 2015. Prevalence per 100000 population reduced from 465 in 1990 to 195 in 2014. Similarly, incidence of TB per 100000 population also been reduced from 289 in 2000 to 247 in 2010 and to 217 in 2015. The annual prevalence and mortality from TB have been reduced to half as compared to 1990 level.
  7. Leprosy Prevalence Rate at the national level per 10000 population has been reduced from 0.68 as on 31st March, 2012 to 0.66 as on 31stMarch, 2017. By March 2017, 556 districts had achieved the 12th Plan target.
  8. Kala Azar – Number of endemic blocks with prevalence more than 1 case of Kala Azar per 10000 population was 230 in 2010 which has been reduced to 94 by 2016.
