questions.solution:
In HIV positive patients, following organisms cause diarrhea.
Cryptosporidium parvum- 4-6 micron oocyst
Cyclospora – 2-12 micron oocyst
Isospora belli23-36- micron oocyst

questions.text: A diabetic patient is reportedly brought to hospital in coma. Her relatives give a history of a black nasal discharge before the patient went into coma. On examination, there is proptosis and chemosis of her left eye. What could be the identity of the fungus isolated from the sinus aspirate.
questions.solution:
Zygomycetes are aseptate molds which are normal environmental saprophytes.

Eg. Rhizopus, Mucor, Absidia, Saksanea…

Diabetic ketoacidosis is the most important risk factor for zygomycosis/ mucormycosis or phycomycosis.

The most common type is rhino-oculo-cerebral disease (as in the question).

The disease can progress rapidly with invasion of the sinuses, eyes, cranial bones, and brain. Blood vessels and nerves are damaged, and patients develop edema of the involved facial area, a bloody nasal exudate, and orbital cellulitis.

questions.text: The average weight gain by an Indian woman during normal pregnancy is:-
questions.solution:
• Weight gain by a woman during pregnancy: 11 kg
  • Weight gain in Indian during pregnancy: 12 kg
  • Weight gain by poor Indian woman during pregnancy: 6.5 kg

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of pain in his jaw and left arm for six months. He has end-stage renal disease and is currently on renal dialysis. Subsequently, his X-ray of the left arm shows multiple small bone cysts and pathologic fractures. Based on the history and findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica

  • Clinical features point towards osteitis fibrosa cystica caused due to secondary hyperparathyroidism.
  • A complication of chronic renal insufficiency due to renal retention of phosphate & hypocalcemia.
  • Feedback results in excess parathyroid hormone (PTH), which causes renal osteodystrophy, in severe cases, osteitis fibrosa cystica.
  • Osteitis fibrosa cystica is a severe bone deformity that causes "brown tumours" (non-neoplastic).
  • Clinical Features include:
    • Bone pain
    • Bone cysts
    • Pathologic fractures
    • Localised bone swellings (due to brown tumours).
  • Histopathology shows:
    • Brown tumour comprises numerous giant cells with interstitial haemorrhage, hemosiderin, and vascularity

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Chronic Osteomyelitis

  • Chronic osteomyelitis represents a progressive inflammatory process caused by pathogens, resulting in bone destruction and sequestrum formation.
  • It may present with periods of inactivity of variable duration, whereas its occurrence, type, severity, and prognosis are multifactorial.
  • The gold standard for diagnosing chronic osteomyelitis is the presence of positive bone cultures and histopathologic examination of the bone.

Option B: Marble Bone Disease

  • Osteopetrosis, also called marble bone disease, is caused by failure of normal bone resorption due to defective osteoclasts resulting in thickened, dense bones prone to fracture. 
  • Overgrowth of cortical bone fills marrow space, causing pancytopenia and extramedullary hematopoiesis. 
  • It can also result in cranial nerve impingement and palsies due to narrowed foramina. 
  • X-ray shows diffuse systemic sclerosis (bone-in-bone, stone bone) 
  • Bone marrow transplant is potentially curative.

Option D: Osteoid Osteoma

  • Osteoid osteoma is a benign primary bone tumour on the cortex of long bones in the diaphysis region.
  • It occurs mostly in young adult males.
  • It presents as bone pain (worse at night) that is relieved by NSAIDs.
  • It occurs as a bony mass (<2cm) with a radiolucent osteoid core

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the physician for recurrent episodes of shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough for the past 4 months. He has two episodes per week, which resolve spontaneously with rest. Twice a month, he wakes up at night with shortness of breath. His pulse is 73/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 122/70 mmHg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows an FVC of 95%, a FEV1:FVC ratio of 0.85, and an FEV1 of 81%, as predicted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for the 20-year-old man with recurrent episodes of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough would be fluticasone. Fluticasone is an inhaled corticosteroid that helps reduce airway inflammation and control asthma symptoms.

In this case, the patient's symptoms and spirometry results suggest the presence of asthma. The recurrent episodes of shortness of breath, cough, and nighttime awakening with symptoms indicate the need for long-term asthma control. Fluticasone, as an inhaled corticosteroid, is considered a first-line treatment for asthma, especially for persistent symptoms.

Fluticasone works by reducing airway inflammation, preventing symptoms, and improving lung function. It helps to decrease airway hyperresponsiveness and the frequency of asthma exacerbations. It is typically prescribed as a daily maintenance medication for asthma control, even when symptoms are not present.

Incorrect options:

2. Bambuterol: Bambuterol is a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA) similar to salmeterol. LABAs are generally used in combination with inhaled corticosteroids for long-term asthma control, but they are not typically recommended as initial monotherapy.

3. Salmeterol: Salmeterol is another LABA used for long-term asthma control in combination with inhaled corticosteroids. As with bambuterol, it is not considered the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for persistent symptoms or as monotherapy.

4. Albuterol: Albuterol is a short-acting beta-agonist bronchodilator used for quick relief of acute bronchospasm in asthma. While it can provide immediate relief of symptoms, it is not considered the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for persistent symptoms or long-term control.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with epilepsy who is desirous of becoming pregnant is found to be anemic. Examination of a peripheral blood smear reveals oval macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Neurologic examination is entirely normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the anemia?

choices.text: Alloantibodies directed against fetal red cell antigens
Coating of red cells by IgG “warm” autoantibodies

questions.solution: Phenytoin is a commonly used antiseizure medication that can cause impaired folate absorption, with resultant folate deficiency and megaloblastic anemia. The drug is contraindicated for use during pregnancy, because folate is required during embryogenesis to prevent neural tube defects. Aplastic anemia results in a major failure of erythropoiesis. Myelophthisic anemia occurs in some cancer patients with metastatic disease. Warm antibody hemolytic anemia is manifested by anemia and reticulocytosis, often with spherocytosis. Hemolytic disease of the newborn most commonly occurs with Rh blood group incompatibility between mother and fetus.

questions.text: The cause of death of the 30-year-old IT employee, who was found dead in her apartment, was confirmed to be due to asphyxia. Further investigations have been initiated to determine the method employed by the killer to cause suffocation. Any of the following acts can lead to suffocation except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Throttling

  • Throttling is a form of manual strangulation, not a form of suffocation.

Option A: Choking

  • Choking is a form of asphyxia caused by an obstruction within the air passages by a foreign object, like a coin, fruit seed, toffees, candies, fish, or any other material.

Option B: Gagging

  • Gagging is a form of asphyxia that results from pushing a gag (rolled-up cloth or paper balls) into the mouth, sufficiently deep to block the pharynx.
  • It combines the features of smothering and choking.

Option C: Smothering

  • Smothering is a form of asphyxia caused by mechanical occlusion of external air passages, i.e. the nose and mouth by hand, cloth, plastic bag or other material.

questions.text: A 9 year old girl appears listless and inattentive. The physician finds the child thin, and malnourished. The CBC reveals microcytic, hypochromic anaemia, and the fecal examination detects oval, transparent eggs. What is the most likely means by which this child was infected?
questions.solution:
• This is the history of hookworm infection (caused by Ancylostomadoudenale and Necatoramericanus), which is transmitted by skin penetration by filariform larva.
  • Clinical manifestations include: ground itch, loefflers syndrome and microcytic hypochromic anemia.
  • Infection is diagnosed by stool examination for adult worm of eggs (these eggs are oval, non-bile stained with segmented ovum having 4/8 blastomeres)

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant female presented to the OPD with concern regarding her diet to be followed in the entire pregnancy. What is the Extra caloric requirement in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option B: +350 Kcal/day

Additional caloric requirements during pregnancy and lactation

  • Extra caloric requirement during pregnancy is an additional 350 Kcal/ day.
  • During lactation (0-6 months) is an additional 600 Kcal/day.
  • During lactation period (7-12 months) additional 520 Kcal/day.

Important Points

  • Protein intake during 2nd trimester and 3rd trimester should increase additional 9.5 grams/day and 22 grams/day Respectively.
  • Protein intake during first 6 months of lactational period is an additional 16.9 grams/ day.
  • Calcium intake during pregnancy should be 1000 mg/day, and during lactation period 1200 grams/ day.
  • Iodine intake during pregnancy should be 250 mcq/day, and during lactation period 280 mcq / day.

Learning Objective

  • Caloric requirements during pregnancy is an additional 350 Kcal/day, and during lactation is an additional 600 Kcal/day.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child is brought to pediatric outpatient clinic by his father with a complaint of fever and recurrent infections despite proper treatment and hygiene. While reviewing his history, the paediatrician noticed that the child has been infected multiple times with Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas. Which of the following test will be useful to diagnose the condition of the child?
questions.solution:
Option A: Negative nitroblue-tetrazolium test

  • The given scenario suggests the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease.

  • Chronic granulomatous disease.

    • Due to NADPH oxidase defect, resulting in an inability to form reactive oxygen compounds and decreased respiratory burst used to kill certain ingested pathogens.

Subtypes:

X linked recessive Autosomal recessive
  • Gp 91 PHOX defect

  • Gp 47 PHOX defect

  • Gp 67 PHOX defect

Clinical features:

  • Recurrent infections: by the catalase-positive organism. Eg- Staph aureus, Pseudomonas, Nocardia.

  • Granuloma formation.

  • Affected individuals will be more susceptible to catalase-positive organisms.

  • The Nitro Blue Tetrazolium test will be negative.

  • In infections caused by catalase-negative organisms (which lack catalase and do not break hydrogen peroxide), the host with CGD (Chronic granulomatous disease) is successfully able to "borrow" hydrogen peroxide being made by the organism and use it to fight off the infection.

  • Hence, Catalase-negative pathogens like Streptococci and Pneumococci infections are not severe.

  • Diagnosis:

    • Nitroblue-tetrazolium test- No O2 radicals → No formazan → No colour.

    • Flow cytometry: Done using Dihydro Rhodamine (DHR).

Option B: Positive nitroblue-tetrazolium test

  • Nitroblue-tetrazolium test is commonly used to rule out or as a screening test for the chronic granulomatous disease.

  • A positive nitroblue-tetrazolium test means colourless neutrophils will turn blue colour.

  • In CGD (Chronic granulomatous disease), they will not change colour.

Option C: Decreased IgA

  • Decreased IgA or selective IgA immunodeficiency is the most common type.

  • The majority of patients are asymptomatic.

Option D: Increased IgE

  • Increased IgE is found in Job’s syndrome or Hyper IgE syndrome.

questions.text: An emaciated prisoner began coughing up sputum streaked with blood. Examination of the sputum revealed the presence of acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following would confirm a diagnosis of tuberculosis?

choices.text: Inclusion bodies of the nuclei of macrophages

questions.solution:
• M. tuberculosis growth is usually slow, taking 2-8 weeks, and the colonies are rough and nonpigmented (rough, tough and buff colonies).
  • It grows luxuriantly- Eugonic growth.
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis cannot be gram stained because of thick mycolic acid containing cell wall.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the emergency after he had sustained a cut on his right sole after stepping on a glass piece while running barefoot around the picnic spot. The medical officer on duty identified the 2x1 cm incision on the lateral aspect of the mid-sole. All of the following characteristics are true of an incision wound except?

choices.text: Bleeding is generally lesser than in lacerations
The length of the injury does not correspond with the length of the blade

questions.solution:
Option B: Bleeding is generally lesser than in lacerations

  • Blood vessels are clean-cut, profuse bleeding present.

Option A: It has clean-cut margins

  • Margins edges are clean cut, well-defined and usually everted.

Option C: Tailing is often present

  • Tailing is present, suggesting the direction.

Option D: Length of injury does not correspond with length of blade in a stab wound

  • Beveling can be seen if the blade cuts obliquely.

questions.text: Identify the symbol as shown in the photograph?
questions.solution:
Option D: NREGA Act 2005

  • NATIONAL RURAL EMPLOYMENT GUARANTEE ACT (NREGA) 2005.
  • Provide 100 days of guaranteed wage employment every year to every household whose adult members volunteer to do ‘unskilled manual work’.

Option A: Organ Transplantation Act 1994

  • The Act's major goals are to control the removal, preservation, and transplantation of human organs for medical treatment and to forbid the commercial use of human organs.
  • The Act contains specific provisions regarding the authority for organ removal, organ preservation, hospital regulation regarding organ removal, storage, or transplantation, functions of the appropriate authority, hospital registration, and punishment/penalties for offenses relating to the aforementioned matters.

Option B: RTI Act 2005

  • Responses to citizen requests for government information must be made promptly under the Right to Information Act of 2005.
  • The Right to Information Act's main goals is to empower citizens, encourage accountability and openness in government operations, combat corruption, and truly make democracy work for the people.

Option C: MTP Act 1971

MTP Act 1971

  • Indications
    • H - Humanitarian 
    • E - Eugenic 
    • T - Therapeutic/Medical 
    • S - Social 
    • Failure of contraceptive devices
  • Educational Qualification
    •  6 months of housemanship in OBG
    • Postgraduate OBG
    • 3 years of practice in OBG for those registered before the act was passed.
    • 1 year of practice in OBG for those doctors registered after the date of commencement of the Act
  •  Experience: ≥ 25 supervised MTP's
  •  Timing 
    • Permitted only 0-20 weeks Pregnancy of gestation
    •  Low risk 0-12 w (1 doctor opinion)
    •  High risk 12-20 w (2 doctor opinions)
  • Centre:  Authorized by GOI

questions.text: A screening test is applied for screening of liver cancer in a population of 500. The test shows positive result in 80 individual and negative in remaining 420. Out of 80 positive individuals 60 confirmed to be diagnosed with liver cancer by diagnostic test and 20 were ruled out. Out of negative 420 individuals 40 had liver cancer. The sensitivity of the test is:
questions.solution:
In the given question,

Total population (a+b+c+d) = 500

  • Total positive result ( a+b) =80
  • Total negative results (c+d) =420
  • Out of total positives 80 (a+b), 60 (a) confirmed to be diagnosed liver cancer
  • Out of total positives 80 (a+b), 20 (b) ruled out for liver cancer
  • Out of total negatives 420 (c+d), 40 (c) had liver cancer

So, out of total negatives 420(c+d), 380 (d) ruled out for liver cancer

Therefore, 2*2 table construction

Liver cancer present Liver cancer absent Total
Screening Test positive 60(a) 20(b) 80
Screening test negative 40 (c) 380(d) 420
  • Sensitivity = a/(a+c) * 100= 60/(60+40)*100= 60%

questions.text: A 20-year-old female from a rural village presented to the PHC with severe itching in her scalp and numerous white nits visible on her scalp. The physician identified the causative agent of the disease to be a louse. All of the following diseases spread through Louse, except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Filariasis

  • Filariasis - A wide range of mosquitoes can transmit the parasite, depending on the geographic area. In Africa, the most common vector is Anopheles and in the Americas, it is Culex quinquefasciatus. Aedes and Mansonia can transmit the infection in the Pacific and in Asia. not louse.

Other options

Option A: Trench fever

  • Trench fever: A rickettsial disease limited to Central Europe.
    • Causative agent: Bartonella Quintana (earlier, Rochalimaea Quintana).
    • Vector: Louse
    • Reservoir: Humans
    • Mode of transmission: Louse feces
    • Drug of choice: Tetracycline.

Option B: Pediculosis

  • An infection of the hairy areas of the body or clothing with lice eggs, larvae, or adults is known as pediculosis.
  • This bug feeds on human blood in its crawling stages, which can cause intense itching.
  • Crab lice are typically found in the pubic region, head lice on the scalp, and body lice along clothing seams.

 

Option D: Epidemic typhus

  • Epidemic Typhus: It is a type of rickettsial disease of the typhus group.
    • Vector: Louse (P. capitis, P. corporis).
    • Mode of transmission (IS NOT BY LOUSE-BITE): Scratching and inoculation with infected louse feces, Crushing infected louse on the body, and Inhalation of infected louse feces or dust.
    • Clinical picture: Prolonged febrile illness, vasculitis.
    • Drug of choice: Tetracycline

questions.text: A 10-month-old child was given Measles and DPT vaccine at a PHC. After 24 hours he got seizures. The correct statement regarding this is-

choices.text: It is most likely due to Pertussis component
It is most likely due to Measles vaccine
It is most likely due to simultaneous administration of four vaccine antigens

questions.solution: Pertussis causes reactions within 48 hours, while Measles causes reactions between 7-12 days. So, it is most likely to be DPT in this case.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of pain, stiffness, and swelling in all the fingers of his hands for two months. He further gives a history of knee joint pain and states that his joints are very stiff when he wakes up in the morning, and the stiffness gradually resolves as the day progresses. The patient is otherwise vitally stable. The physician advised the patient to have a Rose-Waaler test. The investigation involved in this case is related to which of the following.?
questions.solution:
Option D: Haemagglutination test

  • This is a case of rheumatoid arthritis in which the patient presents with complaints of pain in multiple joints.
  • The pain is usually in the knee joint and the joints of the fingers of the hands.
  • In most cases of rheumatoid arthritis, there is a deformity of fingers.
  • The major complaint of the patient with this disease is morning stiffness. When they wake up in the morning, their joints are stiff and painful, but it gradually decreases in intensity as the day progresses.
  • Rose-Waaler test is a passive haemagglutination test done for rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Agglutination: Insoluble (Particulate) antigen binds to the antibody (at optimal temperature, pH, electrolytes) to form clumps.
    • Autoantibody (RA factor) in the serum acts as an antibody to gamma globulin.
    • RA factor can agglutinate red cells coated with globulins.

Option A: Co-agglutination test

  • Co-agglutination: Shown by Staphylococcus aureus strains.
  • Protein A is present in the Cowan-I strain of Staph aureus and has a binding property with the Fc portion of IgG.
  • Co-agglutination: Protein A with attached IgG molecules directed against a specific bacterial antigen agglutinates bacteria with that antigen.

Option B: Latex agglutination test

  • A sample containing the specific antigen (or antibody) is mixed with an antibody (or antigen) coated on the surface of latex particles.
  • Examples:
    • RF (Rheumatoid factor)
    • CRP (C Reactive protein)

Option C: Slide agglutination test

  • Slide agglutination tests include:
  • Slide Widal test
  • Serotyping
  • Blood grouping

questions.text:
Weight (in kilograms) of 10 students in a class is as follows:
70,72,76,71,72,76,72,73,71
What is the mode weight in the distribution?
questions.solution:
Mode : Most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution In the given question, Weight (in kilograms) of 10 students in a class is as follows;

70,72,76,71,70,72,76,72,73,71

OR

70,70,71,71,72,72,72,73,76,76

Most frequent value is 72 (occurring 3 times)

So, mode is 72 kg

questions.text: Calculate the maintenance dose of a drug X , if it has a clearance of 0.01L/h and you need to achieve steady state plasma concentration of 15microgram/ml at 6 hourly interval
questions.solution:
Putting the values

  • Plasma concentration = 15microgram/ml
  • Dosing interval = 6 hrly
  • Clearance  =   0.01 L/h = 10ml/h

Maintenance dose  = plasma conc. x clearance x dosing interval/ Bioavailability

                                       = 15 X 10 X  6  /  1

                                       = 900 mcg

questions.text: A chest physician observed that the distribution of forced expiratory volume (FEV) is 300 smokers had a median value of 2.5 litres with the first and third quartiles being 1.5 and 4.5 litres respectively based on this data how many persons in the sample are expected to have a FEV between 1.5 and 4.5 litres?
questions.solution:
• Quartile: Divides a distribution into 4 equal parts, so the number of intercepts required will be 3, i.e. Q1, Q2, Q3 -

So, Zero – Q1 covers 25% values

Similarly, Q2 – Q1, Q3 - Q2 and 100 – Q3 all cover 25% values each

Thus, Q2- Zero, 100 - Q2 and Q3 – Q1 all over 50%

- Q1 divides a distribution in a ratio of 25:75 OR 1:3

- Q2 divides a distribution in a ratio of 50:50 OR 1:1, Thus second quartile is equivalent to median

- Q3 divides a distribution in a ratio of 75:25 OR 3:1

In the given question,n=300, Q3 = 4.5 litres and Q1 = 1.5 litres Thus Q3 – Q1 will cover 50% values, i.e. 50% of 300 = 150 values

questions.text: A 63 Yr old male with a known case of Coronary Artery Disease and chronic alcohol now presents with chest pain radiating to the jaw and epigastric region. ECG done revealed ST elevation in leads V1 to V6. The patient was given aspirin, clopidogrel, and atorvastatin which couldn't revive him. An autopsy was done, which revealed necrosis of cardiac tissue. Which of the following types of necrosis has occurred in the heart?
questions.solution:
Option A: Coagulative necrosis

  • Coagulative necrosis occurs due to tissue ischemia in solid organs such as the heart, liver, spleen, and kidneys (e.g., splenic infarction). Ischemia is characterized by decreased oxygen delivery, which reduces the amount of ATP produced via aerobic glycolysis.
  • The hypoxic cells have to switch to anaerobic metabolism, which increases lactic acid production, resulting in acidosis.
  • Acidosis causes the denaturation of proteins (including proteolytic and particularly lysosomal enzymes), preventing the cell from dissolving (autolysis).
  • For this reason, coagulative necrosis is characterized by a temporarily preserved cellular architecture without cell nuclei or nuclei still undergoing karyolysis.

Option B: Liquefactive necrosis

  • Lysosomal enzymes are released in liquefactive necrosis to degrade and liquefy necrotic material. Liquefactive necrosis is classically seen in cerebral infarctions and can also occur in bacterial abscesses (pyogenic renal abscesses), but this patient’s cardiac infarction is not subjected to liquefactive necrosis.
  • Histologic examination of the tissue affected by Liquefactive necrosis would show liquified tissue (due to the release of hydrolytic and lysosomal enzymes) with multiple macrophages and cyst formation.

Option C: Fat necrosis

  • Fat necrosis is most commonly seen in patients with acute pancreatitis or traumatic breast lesions.
  • This patient's infarct was in the heart, which is not subject to fat necrosis.

Option D: Caseous necrosis

  • Caseous necrosis is associated with granulomatous infections such as nocardiosis, tuberculosis (including renal tuberculosis), and histoplasmosis.
  • This patient's ischemic infarct was in the heart, which does not result in caseous necrosis. Granulomas typically appear as focal, round, or lobulated nodules with surrounding oedema.
  • Histologic examination of caseous necrosis would show acellular material that appears granular and is surrounded by macrophages, T-cells and giant cells.

questions.text: A 64-year old man with chronic lymphocytic leukemia develops progressive deterioration of mental and neuromuscular function. At autopsy the brain shows enlarged oligodendrocytes whose nuclei contain naked, icosahedral virus particles. The MOST LIKELY diagnosis is:
questions.solution: JC virus is the cause of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, a fatal brain disease that occurs in some immunocompromised persons, especially those with depressed cell-mediated immunity resulting from immunosuppressive therapies or infection by HIV. It usually occurs due to the reactivation of JC virus, which infects oligodendrocytes and astrocytes.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with a long history of persistent cough, chest pain, and recurrent pneumonia. He denies smoking or consuming alcohol. The patient subsequently dies of sepsis. Autopsy reveals malignant cells that diffusely infiltrating the lung parenchyma. Histopathologic examination of the lung shows well-differentiated, mucus producing, columnar neoplastic cells lining the alveolar spaces (shown in the image). Neoplastic cells are not found in any other organ. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Bronchioloalveolar carcinoma is a primary pulmonary adenocarcinoma originating from stem cells in the terminal bronchioles. The cells may be columnar and mucus producing or cuboidal and similar to type II pneumocytes. They tend to grow along the alveolar septa, as depicted in the photomicrograph. A similar growth pattern may be seen in metastatic adenocarcinomas.
  • None of the other tumors produce alveolar mucus or display alveolar spaces lined by a columnar epithelium.

questions.text: A microbiology intern was studying various organisms. He wants to investigate and differentiate them. He wants differentiation for their identification. He performs a biochemical test for its identification. He performed an oxidase test on the organism, which revealed a positive oxidase test shown in the image (below). Which of the following bacteria is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Neisseria

  • Out of the organisms mentioned above, Neisseria is the bacteria involved in this case.
  • Because out of the above-mentioned bacteria, only Neisseria shows a positive oxidase test.
  • The oxidase test identifies microorganisms that produce the enzyme cytochrome oxidase.
  • The test is a spot method based on colour change and is useful in the initial characterization of gram-negative microorganisms.
  • It is used to differentiate oxidase-positive microorganisms such as Neisseria from oxidase-negative Enterobacteriaceae.
  • To avoid a false-positive reaction, the investigator should not test microorganisms growing on media that contains glucose or dyes, such as EMB or MAC, or use a loop or wire containing iron, such as a nichrome wire, to pick the colony.
  • Instead, use a plastic loop or a stick.

Option A: Shigella

  • Shigella is a coliform bacterium.
  • It is a non-motile gram-negative facultative anaerobe.
  • It shows a negative oxidase test.

Option B: Salmonella

  • Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar is - Best selective indicator medium used for the isolation of Salmonella species.

Option D: E. Coli

  • E. coli is oxidase negative.
  • It shows lactose fermenting and non-mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar.

questions.text: A village has 100 under five children. The coverage of measles vaccine is 60%. Following a measles case 26 children developed measles. The secondary attack rate is:
questions.solution:
• In the given question, a village has 100 under five children and the coverage of measles vaccine is 60%; following a measles case 26 children developed measles,
  • Since coverage of Measles vaccine is 60%, 60% of 100 children i.e. 60 children are vaccinated (not susceptible to measles)
  • So only 40 children are susceptible to Measles
  • Out of 40 children, 1 child develops Measles (primary case) and then out of rest 39 susceptible (primary case excluded from denominator), 26 develop Measles
  • Therefore, SAR = 26/39 X 100 = 66%

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the department with diarrhoea. His medical history is consistent with HIV infection. A drug that interferes with the activity of the enzyme pyruvate ferredoxin oxidoreductase has been administered, to a HIV patient with diarrhea. Which of the following is the most likely organism causing infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cryptosporidium

  • The most likely drug used is nitazoxanide.
  • While the most likely treated disease is cryptosporidiosis.
  • Nitazoxanide:
    • Pharmacodynamic:
      • The general effect of this medication is the prevention of microbe activity through the disruption of important energy pathways for survival and proliferation.
      • Nitazoxanide exhibits antiprotozoal activity by interfering with the pyruvate ferredoxin/flavodoxin oxidoreductase-dependent electron transfer reaction, an essential reaction needed for the anaerobic energy metabolism of various microorganisms.
      • Sporozoites of Cryptosporidium parvum and trophozoites of Giardia lamblia are therefore inhibited, relieving symptoms of diarrhoea.
      • Interference with the PFOR enzyme-dependent electron transfer reaction may only be one of the many pathways by which nitazoxanide exhibits antiprotozoal activity 
    • Indications:
      • For the treatment of diarrhoea in adults and children caused by the protozoa Giardia lamblia and for the treatment of diarrhoea in children caused by the protozoan, Cryptosporidium parvum.
      • Nitazoxanide is not superior to placebo medication for managing diarrhoea caused by Cryptosporidium parvum in patients with HIV/immunodeficiency.

 

Option A: Beef tapeworm

  • Niclosamide and praziquantel have proved effective for Beef tapeworm treatment.
  • The mechanism of action of niclosamide has been demonstrated to block glucose uptake, thus acting as an uncoupling agent for energy-generating oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Praziquantel works by causing severe spasms and paralysis of the worms' muscles. This paralysis is accompanied - and probably caused - by a rapid Ca 2+ influx inside the schistosome.

Option B: Whipworm

  • Mebendazole is used for the whipworm
  • Mebendazole acts by inhibiting the production of microtubules via binding to the colchicine binding site of β-tubulin, thereby blocking the polymerization of tubulin dimers in the intestinal cells of parasites.

Option D: Trypanosoma

  • Nifurtimox is used for the treatment of trypanosoma.
  • The mechanism of action of nifurtimox appears to be related to its metabolism via partial reduction to chemically reactive radicals that cause the production of toxic reduced products of oxygen. The metabolic products then can react with macromolecules such as DNA.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was diagnosed with Hodgkin’s lymphoma and was started on bleomycin. Which of the following is true regarding this drug?

choices.text: It does not cause pulmonary fibrosis
It is metabolised by the lipase enzyme
It has a low risk of causing bone marrow suppression

questions.solution:
Option D: It has a low risk of causing bone marrow suppression

  • This is a Hodgkin’s lymphoma case in which the patient presents with complaints of recurring fever and night sweats for 5-months. He reported that he usually has a fever for a week, which resolves independently. He has had a 6-kg weight loss during the past five months. On his neck, he noticed painless lumps that had increased in size during this period.
  • Bleomycin does not cause bone marrow suppression.
  • Most Anticancer drugs cause bone marrow suppression. However, these drugs are marrow-sparing:
    • Vincristine
    • Bleomycin
    • Asparaginase
  • Bleomycin is an antineoplastics drug.
  • It is used to treat various types of malignancies, such as cervix and uterus, head and neck, testicle and penile, and certain types of other lymphomas.

Option A: It does not cause pulmonary fibrosis

  • It can cause pulmonary fibrosis in the lungs.
  • Bleomycin hydrolase deficient in the lungs
  • Therefore it causes toxicity in the lungs.

Option B: It spares the skin

  • Bleomycin hydrolase is deficient in the lungs and skin.
  • Therefore these organs are at high risk of toxicity.
  • It can cause flagellated skin pigmentation.

Option C: It is metabolised by the lipase enzyme

  • Bleomycin is metabolised by bleomycin hydrolase.
  • It catalyses the bond cleavages by reaction with water.
  • Lipase enzyme is produced in the pancreas, mouth, and stomach to break down fats in food.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented to an outpatient clinic with a complaint of a lump lump in her right breast. Her previous medical history does not warrant any special attention. Physical examination revealed a 0.5 cm rubbery mass in the right upper quadrant. The mass is painless and can move in horizontal and vertical planes. Mammography is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fibroadenoma 

  • It is a common benign breast tumour in women.
  • Although the pathogenesis of fibroadenoma is unknown, two-thirds of patients have MED12 mutations.
  • These tumours are most common in young females. 
  • Because fibroadenoma responds to oestrogen levels, it can grow during the period of high oestrogen (pregnancy) and regress after menopause. 
  • Characteristics of fibroadenoma are 
    • Well circumscribed 
    • Rubbery 
    • Greyish 
    • Mobile 
  • Because of the rapid growth and infarction of tumours during pregnancy may resemble carcinoma.
  • Fibroadenoma can increase the risk of carcinoma when complex features are present 
    • Cyst > 0.3 cm 
    • Sclerosing adenosis
    • Epithelial calcifications 
    • Papillary apocrine change
  • The majority of patients who receive cyclosporin after a kidney transplant are at an increased risk of developing multiple fibroadenomas.
  • Histopathology 
    • Pericanalicular pattern - epithelium is surrounded by stroma 
    • Intracanalicular pattern - compressed and distorted lumen by stroma 

Option A: Fibrocystic disease

  • It is a benign breast condition palpated as "lumpy bumpy." 
  • It causes multiple cysts to form and stromal fibrosis. 
  • Smaller cysts combine to form larger ones. 
  • Fibrosis is caused by material leakage caused by cyst rupture.  

Option C: Medullary carcinoma

  • The majority of medullary carcinomas are caused by hypermethylation of the BRCA 1 promoter, which results in decreased gene expression in approximately 67% of patients.
  • It is not associated with the familial BRCA1 mutation. 
  • The infiltration of T lymphocytes is the most common feature of these tumours. As a result, the outcome is determined by the host's immune response and antigen burden. 
  • It has a better prognosis. 

Option D: Colloid carcinoma

  • It has a soft or rubbery consistency and the appearance of pale grey-blue gelatin. 
  • Tumours appear as small islands of cells surrounded by mucin.

questions.text: The forensic doctor was informed that the patient's body which was sent to him was infected with HIV and thus, he had to follow the necessary precautions during the examination. What solution will the doctor preserve the specimen in, for further virological examination?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glycerol

  • For virological examination: Glycerol in buffered saline.

Option B: Rectified spirit

  • 95% pure ethanol is referred to as the rectified spirit, with 5% water.
  • Rectified spirit is the best preservative for chemical analysis.
  • It is used to manufacture homemade liqueurs like limoncello and cassis, as well as in cooking, where the high alcohol content functions as a solvent to extract flavours. Rectified spirits are also employed as a household solvent and in medical tinctures.

Option C: Formalin

  • For histopathological examination: Formalin.

Option D: Thymol

  • For urine examination: Thymol.

questions.text: In the years of potential life lost (YPLL), what is the usual arbitrary determined age to which a person is expected to live:
questions.solution: Years of potential life lost is based on the years of life lost through premature death. It is defined as one that occurs before the age to which a dying person could have expected to survive (before an arbitrary determined age, usually taken age 75 years). A 30 year old who dies in a road accident could theoretically have lived to an average life expectancy of 75 years of age; thus 45 years of life are lost.

questions.text: In a firearm injury there is burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound and is circular in shape is a:
questions.solution:
Close Shot (Flame Range):

Entry wound is small and circular in shape having inverted and contused lacerated margins.

Skin adjacent to the entry wound shows evidence of grease/ dirt collar on the inner zone and abraded contused collar on the outer zone.

Evidence of burning, singeing , blackening and tattooing  of the skin in and around the entry wound.

questions.text: This drug depolarizes cell membranes of aerobic gram positive bacteria. It is effective against vancomycin resistant enterococcal infections. It may cause myopathy especially in patients taking statins. It is:
questions.solution: Daptomycin is a newer antibiotic that acts by causing depolarization of bacterial cell membranes. It is effective in MRSA, VRSA and even streptogramin resistant SA infections as well as VRE infections. It can cause myopathy in patients taking statins.

questions.text: A 61-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with dyspnea for the past 3 weeks. He also complains of hoarseness of voice and a tingling sensation in his right arm. His vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows temporal wasting, facial puffiness, and prominent chest veins. CT scan reveals a radio-opaque lesion measuring 5 x 4 cm in size over the apex of the right lung. A biopsy is taken for further evaluation under electron microscopy. Which of the following is the most common fixative used in electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
The correct option for the most common fixative used in electron microscopy is 1. Glutaraldehyde.

Explanation of the options:

  1. Glutaraldehyde: Glutaraldehyde is a widely used fixative in electron microscopy. It is a highly effective fixative for preserving cellular ultrastructure, especially for delicate structures like cell membranes and organelles. Glutaraldehyde works by cross-linking proteins and other biomolecules in the cells, preventing their degradation and preserving their structural integrity for electron microscopy analysis.

  2. Formalin: Formalin is a common fixative used in light microscopy, but it is not the primary choice for electron microscopy. It is mainly used for routine histological processing, where preservation of ultrastructural details is not a priority. Formalin fixation is not ideal for electron microscopy because it can cause significant distortion and damage to delicate cellular structures.

  3. Picric acid: Picric acid is a fixative used in histology, especially for tissues with high lipid content, such as the brain. It is not commonly used in electron microscopy because it can interfere with the quality of electron micrographs and cause artifacts.

  4. Absolute alcohol: Absolute alcohol is often used as a dehydrating agent in the tissue preparation process for electron microscopy but is not used as the primary fixative. Dehydration is typically performed after the fixation step to remove water from the tissues before embedding in resin for sectioning and imaging.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a right & privilege of registered medical practitioner?

choices.text: Right to add title to the name
Right to own an organ for transplantation

questions.solution:
Rights & Privileges of a Doctor–

  1. Right to choose a patient
  2. Right to practice medicine
  3. Right to dispense medicine  
  4. Right to possess and supply dangerous drugs to his patients  
  5. Right to add title  
  6. Right to recovery of fees
  7.  Right to issue medical certificate
  8. Right to give evidence as an expert  
  9. Right for appointment in public/govt. hospital  
  10. Exemption from serving as a juror at an inquest.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presented with abdominal pain, diarrhoea, anorexia and weight loss. Laboratory investigations showed markedly increased ESR. On abdominal ultrasound, Club Sandwich appearance of the bowel walls is seen. Which type of ulcer is seen in the given disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Transverse ulcers

  • Intestinal tuberculosis occurs as a result of drinking contaminated milk
  • It is a complication of protracted advanced secondary tuberculosis, secondary to swallowing coughed-up infective material.
  • Organisms are trapped in mucosal lymphoid aggregates of the small and large intestines. Resulting in inflammatory enlargement with ulceration of the overlying mucosa in the ileum.
  • Multiple transverse small intestinal ulcers with undermined edges can be seen.
  • An abdominal ultrasound shows a “Club Sandwich appearance of bowel walls”.

Option A: Longitudinal ulcers

  • Longitudinal ulcers are seen in Typhoid or enteric fever.

Option C: Punched out ulcers

  • Punched-out ulcers are seen in herpes simplex esophagitis.

Option D: None of the above

  • Multiple transverse small intestinal ulcers with undermined edges can be seen in intestinal tuberculosis.

questions.text: 20-year-old woman who ingested a rust-removing solution in a suicidal attempt presents with severe pharyngeal pain, hoarse voice, swollen and blackish lips and tongue, and chalky white teeth .what is the suspected  causative agent?
questions.solution:
Option D: Sulphuric acid

  • In Sulphuric acid poisoning: The voice becomes hoarse and husky. The lips are usually swollen and blackish. Teeth are chalky-white. The tongue becomes swollen, sodden, and black.

Option A: Carbolic acid

  • Poisoning by carbolic acid is known as carbolism. Phenol being fat-soluble, attacks the nervous system and causes paralysis of respiratory and CVS centers leading to death.
  • Grayish or brownish corrosions at the angle of the mouth, chin, front of the body, arms and hands with phenolic odor.

Option B: Oxalic acid

  • Fulminating poisoning: Intake of large dose (>15 g) produces immediate symptoms and death within minutes. There is a burning, sour or bitter taste in the mouth with a sense of constriction around the throat and burning pain from the mouth to the stomach, radiating all over the abdomen.
  • Acute poisoning: All findings are due to hypocalcemia-tingling and numbness of fingers and limbs, weakness, parasthesia, carpopedal spasm, hyperirritability of peripheral nerves (Chvostek/Weiss sign), tetany, convulsions, coma, and death. There may be dilated pupils, metabolic acidosis, ventricular fibrillation, and renal failure.
  • Delayed poisoning: It is characterized by nephritis-uremia, scanty urine, hematuria, albuminuria, oxaluria.

Option C: Nitric acid

  • They are those of poisoning by sulphuric acid. It causes yellow discoloration of the tissues, including the crowns of the teeth, and yellow stains on the clothing. Inhalation of fumes causes lachrymation, photophobia, irritation of air passages and lungs producing sneezing, coughing, dyspnoea, and asphyxia.
  • The Colour of urine is brown.

questions.text: The trial of Mr. Gupta is in court now. After having thoroughly studied the case, the judge declared that a magistrate inquest was not needed in this case. What among the following could be the offence Mr. Gupta is being charged for?
questions.solution:
Option A: Homicide

  • Magistrate inquest is not done in Homicide.

Option B: Exhumation

  • In Exhumation cases (where the body is dug out of a grave), the inquest is done by the Executive Magistrate.

Option C: Police custody death

  • The disappearance or death of a person in police custody or during police interrogation is done by Magistrate inquest.

Option D: Dowry death

  • Dowry deaths (suicide/death of a woman within 7 years of marriage) include in the indication for Magistrate inquest.

questions.text: A community medicine student was posted as an intern at a rural PHC. In the morning session, he was questioned about ‘Lead time’ by his senior doctor. Which of the following is the best suitable answer?

choices.text: Time between Disease onset and first critical diagnosis
Time between Disease onset and first possible point of detection
Time between the first possible point of detection and the final critical point
Time between the First possible point of detection and the usual time of diagnosis

questions.solution:
Option D: Time between the first possible point of detection and the usual time of diagnosis

  • Lead time is the advantage gained by screening (leading the time of diagnosis).
  • It is the time between the first possible point of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Other option

Option A: Time between Disease onset and first critical diagnosis

  • This option does not properly take the lead time into account.

Option B: Time between Disease onset and first possible point of detection

  • This option also does not properly take the lead time into account.

Option C: Time between the first possible point of detection and the final critical point

  • The time between the first possible point of detection and the final critical point is the screening time.

questions.text: A rural PHC worker found that a group of the population in the village did not consume an adequate diet to meet their energy needs which is resulting in an energy deficit. Which of the following is the correct method to assess Protein quantity?
questions.solution:
Option C: PE ratio

Protein-energy Ratio:

  • This is used to assess protein Quantity.
  • The protein content of many Indian foods has been determined and published in food composition tables.
  • One way of evaluating foods as sources of protein is to determine what percentage of their energy value is supplied by their protein content.
  • This is known as Protein-Energy Ratio (PE ratio or percentage).

PE ratio =  Amount of energy from the protein in food product / Total energy from the food × 100

  • This concept is useful because in many population groups, where adequate diet is not consumed to meet energy needs, resulting in energy deficits.

Other options

Option A: Amino acid score

  • Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the test protein expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

Option B: NPU

  • Net Protein Utilization (NPU): It is a product of the digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100.
  • The NPU gives a more complete expression of protein quality than the amino acid score.

NPU = Nitrogen retained by the body / Nitrogen intake × 100

  • Highest NPU: Egg 96

Option D: None

  • This is an incorrect choice because the PE ratio is the correct answer.

questions.text: What drug might a 32-year-old woman have taken if she's brought to the ER confused after overdosing, with low blood pressure, slow heart rate, and her mom takes it for hypertension?
questions.solution:
Option B: Atenolol

  • Based on the history of anti-hypertensive overdose and associated bradycardia with hypotension, the likely drug the patient has ingested is atenolol.
  • It is a beta blocker and blocks response to beta-adrenergic stimulation.
  • It is cardio-selective for beta1 receptors at low doses.
  • The beta-blocker toxicity can cause the following manifestations.
    • Bradycardia
    • Hypotension
    • Arrhythmias
    • Hypothermia
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Seizures 
    • Cardiogenic shock
  • Atenolol can be used in the following conditions.
    • Hypertension
    • Angina Pectoris
    • Post Myocardial Infarction
    • Thyrotoxicosis

Option A: Hydralazine

  • Hydralazine is a direct vasodilator that dilates the arterioles with little effect on the vein, resulting in decreased systemic resistance and eventually reducing blood pressure.
  • Hydralazine is a vasodilator and can result in reflex tachycardia.
  • It can be used in the following conditions.
    • Hypertensive Crisis
    • Congestive Heart Failure
    • Chronic Hypertension

Option C: Amlodipine

  • Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker.
  • Dihydropyridines are more potent as vasodilators. They have less effect on heart contractility and conduction.
  • Amlodipine may lead to sinus tachycardia via a reflex-mediated increase in the sympathetic tone.
  • It inhibits the influx of extracellular Ca+2 across membranes of myocardial cells and vascular smooth muscle cells. This impedes cardiac and vascular smooth muscle contraction, dilating the main coronary and systemic arteries.
  • It is used in the following conditions
    • Hypertension
    • Treatment of chronic stable angina and vasospastic angina

Option D: Hydrochlorothiazide

  • Hydrochlorothiazide can cause a significant and sustained fall in blood pressure with reflex tachycardia.
  • Thiazide diuretics inhibit the reabsorption of sodium and chloride, mainly in the distal tubules. Therefore, they increase the excretion of sodium and potassium in the urine and decrease calcium excretion.
  • They also increase the bicarbonate excretion from the body.
  • It is used in the following conditions.
    • Hypertension
    • Oedema
    • Hypertension in heart failure

questions.text: A rural village is reporting many cases of disease with similar symptoms among the villagers. Which of the following is the most economical and best screening method?
questions.solution:
Option B: High risk screening

  • In High-risk screening, besides effectiveness, economical use of resources is also seen as screening tests are selectively applied to individuals in high-risk groups.
  • High-risk selective screening gives maximum yield. E.g., HIV screening in commercial sex workers.
  • Therefore, it is the most economical and best screening method.

Option A: Mass screening

  • Mass screening simple means screening of a whole population or subgroup.
  • Since in village many villagers developed similar symptoms High risk screening would be appropriate.

Option C: Multiphasic screening

  • Application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time.
  • Frist of all this not economical and there are more than one tests applied in multiphasic screening, so it is incorrect regarding the scenario mentioned above.

Option D: None of the above

  • Since high risk screening is correct answer, so this option is incorrect.

Learning Objective

  • Multiphasic screening means application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time.
  • High risk/ selective screening when applied selectively to high risk groups.
  • Mass screening means screening of a whole population or subgroup.

questions.text: Avoid which anesthesia medications in a 25-year-old male patient diagnosed with pheochromocytoma, presenting with episodic headache, palpitations, perspiration, blood pressure of 188/92 mm Hg, pulse of 110/min, hematocrit of 50%, and elevated catecholamine levels, with normal renal and liver function tests?
questions.solution:
Option C: Halothane

  • Halothane makes cardiac muscles more sensitive and increases the effect of epinephrine and catecholamine. 
  • Pheochromocytoma patients have elevated catecholamine levels in their blood, which can cause arrhythmia with halothane. 
  • In patients with pheochromocytoma, halothane should be avoided. 
  • Halothane can result in malignant hyperthermia.
  • Susceptibility for malignant hyperthermia is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion​​​​​​​

Option A: Desflurane 

  • Inhaled desflurane is used to cause general anaesthesia. It is also used as maintenance anaesthesia in adults and children after receiving other anaesthetics before and during surgery.
  • Desflurane does not have a significant sensitising effect on the myocardium. 
  • It can cause adverse respiratory reactions, including coughing, laryngospasm, and secretions.

Option B: Fentanyl 

  • Fentanyl is an opioid commonly used to treat chronic pain in patients. 
  • It can cause respiratory depression, urinary retention, drowsiness and confusion.

Option D: Midazolam 

  • Midazolam belongs to the benzodiazepine class and lowers blood pressure. 
  • It can be used to induce anaesthesia in patients with pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: All of the following are Live vaccines except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Rabies

  • The rabies vaccine is a killed vaccine.
  •  For immediate protection

1. HRIg (Human rabies Ig)

2. ERIg (Equine rabies Ig)

  • Vaccines approved:

1. PCECV (purified chick embryo cell vaccine)

2. PV (purified Vero cell rabies vaccine)

Option B: Influenza

  • Influenza vaccine can be live attenuated, killed as well as subunit vaccine.

Option C: Yellow fever

  • Yellow fever vaccine is present in both live as well as killed forms.
  • Yellow fever (17D) vaccine is a Live vaccine while Dakar yellow fever vaccine is a killed vaccine.

Option D: Rubella

  • The vaccines available for rubella are Monovalent and combined vaccines. All of the vaccinations are freeze-dried and come with sterile distilled water as a diluent.
  • These vaccinations are live attenuated ones.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female from a large Italian family is screened for a familial blood disorder. The results of laboratory studies include a hemoglobin of 9.5 g/dL and a smear displaying mild microcytosis, hypochromia, and a few target cells. Haemoglobin electrophoresis shows a mild increase in haemoglobin A2 (7.5%). What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
→ Heterozygous β-thalassemia is associated with

  • Microcytosis & hypochromia; degree of microcytosis is disproportionate to severity of anemia, which is generally mild.
  • Target cells, basophilic stippling & mild increase in hemoglobin A2 are present [>3.5%]
  • Most patients are asymptomatic.

→ Homozygous β-thalassemia is a more serious disease associated with high amounts of HbF

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with a complaint of petechiae. O/E, sternal tenderness is present. BM biopsy show hypercellularity and more than 20% lymphoblast. Peripheral smear show ↑↑↑ TLC and the presence of lymphoblast. On X-ray, retrosternal mass is seen. The diagnosis includes which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option D:  An immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive)

  • The above patient is most likely suffering from T-cell ALL.
  • Points in favor of the above diagnosis:
    • Peak at puberty
    • Retrosternal mass
    • More than 20% Lymphoblast (Tdt +, PAS +) in BM
    • ↑↑↑ TLC
    • Lymphoblast present in the blood
  • Less common than B cell ALL
    • Thymus ++
    • Notch gene mutation
    • Gain of function
    • Poor prognosis
    • CD1/2/5/7 positive
  • Immunophenotyping of immature T-cell phenotype: Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive

Other options

Option A: It has a good prognosis

  • ALL have poor prognoses.
  • The major prognostic factors for survival in adult ALL are:
    • Age
    • Cytogenetic abnormalities
    • Immunologic subtype
    • White blood cell (WBC) count
    • Time to achieve complete remission (CR).
  • Determination of these factors is crucial for adapting post-remission therapy in adult ALL.
  • Nearly 98% of children with ALL experience remission. With current regimens, it is anticipated that 85% of patients with newly diagnosed ALL between the ages of 1 and 18 will experience long-term event-free survival, with more than 90% still living at five years.

Option B: Adrenal involvement

  • Thymic involvement is seen in ALL.
  • The thymus, a tiny organ located in the centre of the chest in front of the trachea and behind the sternum, is frequently impacted by the T-cell subtype of ALL.
  •  An enlarged thymus can press on the trachea, leading to coughing or trouble breathing.
  • The thymus is the primary organ involved in developing T lymphocytes which orchestrate the adaptive immune response.

Option C: KDM1A mutation

  • Notch gene mutation is seen in ALL.
  • Similar to established oncogenes and tumour suppressors, established Notch receptor genes exhibit mutation frequency in established cancer cell lines.
  • In contrast to original tumours, tumour cell lines exhibit a higher prevalence of Notch mutations.
  • The KDM1A gene in humans encodes the protein known as lysine-specific histone demethylase 1A (LSD1), often referred to as lysine (K)-specific demethylase 1A (KDM1A).

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the ophthalmologist complaining of severe headache, blurred vision, and redness in both eyes for 5 days. The patient is also hypertensive for 15 years. On examination, there is tenderness around the eyes and the intraocular pressure is raised. The doctor decides to prescribe a topical drug to the patient. Which of the following drugs could be given?
questions.solution:
Option A: Betaxolol

  • The scenario indicates that the patient has glaucoma.
  • Glaucoma is an eye condition that can cause damage and inflammation to the eye's optic nerve. It is a leading cause of inflammation and vision loss in older people.
  • It worsens over time if not treated early and is linked to increasing pressure in the eye. Various topical medicines are used in this condition.
  • Betaxolol is a selective beta-1 adrenergic blocker that is used in the treatment of glaucoma. It can be given in the form of topical drops.
  • Betaxolol is preferred because they lack local anaesthetic activity. Local anaesthesia increases the risk of optic nerve damage.

Option B: Propranolol

  • It is a drug that belongs to the beta blocker class. It can be used in the treatment of glaucoma as it can decrease intraocular pressure.
  • Propranolol has local anaesthetic effects that can reduce pain. In glaucoma, local anaesthetic activity increases the risk of corneal ulcers and is not preferred.

Option C: Atropine

  • Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. It is contraindicated in the case of glaucoma.
  • Atropine can raise intraocular pressure and cause an acute attack of glaucoma. It can also cause irritation, stinging, and oedema.

Option D: Pseudoephedrine

  • It is a sympathomimetic drug that is used to relieve nasal congestion.
  • Pseudoephedrine is contraindicated in case of glaucoma as it can dilate the pupil, which leads to elevated eye pressure. The induction of mydriasis can badly damage the eye, causing vision loss.
