questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented to the eye clinic complaining of pain in the eye associated with decreased vision. Examination of the patient’s medical history revealed that he was operated for cataracts in his left eye and also done pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) for cataracts and proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) in his left eye. The patient with a history of type 2 DM for the last 15 years. On examination of the patient eye, he has diabetic macular oedema with glaucoma. Which of the following drug should be contraindicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Prostaglandin analogues

  • This is the case of Diabetic Macular oedema with Glaucoma in a diabetic patient. The patient has a history of cataract surgery and also has proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which is strongly associated with macular oedema.
  • Diabetic macular oedema (DME) is manifested as retinal thickening caused by the accumulation of intraretinal fluid, primarily in the inner and outer plexiform layers.
  • Macular oedema is strongly positively associated with diabetic retinopathy severity.
  • Prostaglandin analogues like Latanoprost and Bimatoprost etc., can precipitate cystoid macular oedema (CME)
  • Prostaglandin analogue can also cause anterior uveitis, iris pigmentation, and hypertrichosis.

 

Option A: Alpha agonist

  • Alpha receptor agonists are substances that activate the sympathetic nervous system by stimulating alpha receptors, similar to the effects of epinephrine and nor-epinephrine.
  • Alpha receptors are located in smooth muscle, including in the arteries. Stimulation of these receptors results in vasoconstriction increasing after load causing hypertension.

Option B: Acetazolamide

  • It is a carbonic anhydrase enzyme inhibitor that decreases aqueous humour formation, decreasing intraocular pressure.
  • It is used to treat glaucoma, altitude sickness, and congestive heart failure.

Option C: Beta-blockers

  • Beta blockers are drugs which can inhibit the sympathetic system.
  • Beta blockers are drugs used in the treatment of Angina pectoris, atrial fibrillation, cardiac arrhythmia, congestive heart failure, and hypertension.

questions.text: True statement related to expiry date of a drug is:-

choices.text: It is the date up to which the drug is likely to be fully potent and safe to take based on scientifically-sound product testing, if stored properly.
Maximum period of expiry is 3 years from the date of manufacture
After expiry period, there is a fall in efficacy of drug
After expiry period, drug changes to more toxic compounds.

questions.solution:
Expiry date:

  • It is the date up to which the active ingre­dient is expected to remain within specification if stored correctly.
  • The drug can be used by the last date of that particular month displayed by expiry date (if exact date is not specified)
  • The drugs may remain potent, efficacious as well as safe after expiry date, but the manufacturer does not give guarantee.
  • There is no maximum period for expiry date.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about juvenile delinquency except:

choices.text: According to The children Act, 1960 Juvenile means a boy or girl who has not attained the age of 16 years

Delinquency embraces all deviations from normal youthful behavior and includes the incorrigible, ungovernable, and habitually disobedient and those who desert their homes and mix with immoral people, those with behavior problems and indulge in antisocial practices.
The highest incidence is found in children aged 15 and above.
The incidence among boys is 4 to 5 times more than among girls.

questions.solution:
JUVENILE DELINQUENCY

The Children Act, 1960 in India defines delinquent as "a child who has committed an offence". Juvenile means a boy who has not attained the age of 16 years and a girl who has not attained the age of 18 years. In a broad sense, delinquency is not merely "juvenile crime". It embraces all deviations from normal youthful behaviour and includes the incorrigible, ungovernable, habitually disobedient and those who desert their homes and mix with immoral people, those with behaviour problems and indulge in antisocial practices. juvenile delinquency is on the increase in India during thepast few decades, due to changes in the cultural pattern ofthe people, urbanization and industrialization. Thehighest incidence is found in children aged 15 and above.The incidence among boys is 4 to 5 times more thanamong girls

questions.text: In a given population, the total number of births in a year is 4050. There are 50 stillbirths. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life whereas the number of deaths within 8-28 days of life is 150. What is the Neonatal mortality rate in the population?
questions.solution:
Option B: 50

Neonatal mortality rate

  • Neonatal deaths are deaths occurring during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending 28 completed days after birth.
  • The neonatal mortality rate is the number of neonatal deaths in a given year per 1000 live births in that year.

In the given case,

  • Total neonatal deaths = Total early neonatal deaths + Total late neonatal deaths = 50 + 150 = 200
  • Total live births = Total births – Total stillbirths = 4050 – 50 = 4000
  • NMR = Neonatal death / Live births × 1000
  • Thus, the Neonatal mortality rate, NMR = 200/4000 × 1000 = 50 per 1000 live births.

Other options are incorrect

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of epistaxis. After a series of treatments, the bleeding could not be stopped. His medical history is consistent with hypertension and diabetes. His medications include metformin and amlodipine. An attempt to block the external carotid artery is made which does not lead to resolution of the bleeding. Which of the following artery is responsible for the bleeding in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anterior Ethmoidal Artery

  • Both external and internal carotid arteries supply the nose through their branches.
  • The source of epistaxis after ligation of the external carotid artery is from the internal carotid branch, i.e., the anterior ethmoidal artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery ligation is considered for continued epistaxis uncontrolled by other means.
  • The anterior ethmoid artery is an extension of the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery system.
  • As such, this is branch is unable to be addressed by embolization techniques.
  • If epistaxis is severe enough to consider addressing the anterior ethmoid artery, additional consideration of ligating the sphenopalatine artery should be entertained.
  • The posterior ethmoid artery, also a branch of the ophthalmic artery, is not routinely ligated due to its proximity to the optic nerve and inherent risk of injury to the nerve.
  • The anterior ethmoidal artery is identified via subperiostial elevation through a Lynch incision.
  • The artery is approximately 24mm from the anterior lacrimal crest and lies along the frontoethmoidal suture line. The following drawing demonstrates the artery as a distal branch of the ophthalmic artery.

Option A: Maxillary artery

  • The maxillary artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • The bleed should stop when the external carotid is ligated.

Option B: Greater palatine artery

  • The greater palatine artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • The bleed should stop when the external carotid is ligated.

Option C: Superior labial artery

  • The superior labial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • The bleed should stop when the external carotid is ligated.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency with history of sustaining a fall and injuring his neck. On radiology, it’s clear that he has sustained a fracture of the C4-5 vertebrae. The consultant asks the fellow to document the neurological status for the assessment and prognosis of the spinal cord injury. Which of the following scoring will the fellow use?
questions.solution: To clearly document the motor and sensory examination, including the function of the rectal sphincter and the presence of perianal sensation, we have used the ASIA form from ISCoS. Using the ISCoS form,sensation is recorded for light touch and pinprick in 28 dermatomal distributions on each side of the body .Pinprick testing is done using a sterile needle rather than a pinwheel. A score of 2 (normal), 1 (altered), or 0 (absent) is determined for each dermatome, and specific "key" areas are identified on the diagram within each dermatome as optimal test locations. In addition, the presence of sensation for deep anal pressure is made to help determine if a spinal cord injury is complete or incomplete. GCS is the Glasgow coma scale used to determine the brain injury. NEXUS criterion is used to clear the C spine in a poly trauma patient. ATLS is the Advanced Trauma Life Support; a protocol used to treat and assess a person suffering from poly trauma FAST is the focused assessment by sonography in trauma. It's basically the ultrasound used in trauma setting to save time that is wasted in a full ultrasound exam. Learning Objective: it's important to know and perform the ASIA scoring so that the doctor knows what initial neurological status was and how it develops or heals with time. Also it helps in prognosticating post surgery.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, para 1 living 1, presents to the clinic with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge and pain in the lower abdomen. She has regular menstrual cycles with dysmenorrhea and does not use any contraception. The clinician examined her and prescribed her antibiotics, which she was not compliant with. Which of the following complications of the patient's current condition, may arise due to non compliance ?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pyometra

  • The presence of vaginal discharge, abdominal discomfort, and dysmenorrhea suggest pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  • Long-term untreated PID may result in the production of pus in the uterus, which is known as pyometra.
  • Other long-term consequences of PID include:
  • Infertility
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Dyspareunia
  • Increased risk of ectopic pregnancy
  • Pelvic adhesions
  • Hydrosalpinx
  • Pyosalpinx
  • Intestinal obstruction.
  • Pyometra is a complication of the following conditions:
  • Cervical cancer
  • Senile endometritis
  • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Tuberculosis
  • Post radiotherapy
  • The pyometra should also be drained, and antibiotics should be administered to the patient.

Option B: Uterine polyposis

  • The most common uterine polyps are endometrial, fibroid, adeno-myomatous, and placental polyps.
  • Clinical Characteristics
  • Menorrhagia, metrorrhagia, and postmenopausal bleeding are all symptoms of uterine polyps. It may induce postcoital or chronic bleeding in a young female if it protrudes through the os.
  • The uterine polyp may or may not be visible clinically, and the uterus may or may not be enlarged; it is straightforward to detect when the polyp protrudes through the cervical canal.
  • Ultrasound, as well as saline sonosalpingograms and hysterosalpingograms, can identify uterine polyps.
  • Hysteroscopy can be used for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.
  • Uterine polyposis is not a complication of PID

Option C: Pseudopregnancy

  • Psuedopregnancy or pseudocyesis is a clinical phenomenon in which a woman feels she is pregnant despite the lack of an actual pregnancy.
  • Patients may acquire convincing signs and symptoms of pregnancy, such as abdominal enlargement and menstrual irregularities.
  • A pregnancy test and ultrasound can be used to make a diagnosis.
  • This is not a complication of PID

Option D: Cystic endometrial hyperplasia

  • Cystic glandular hyperplasia is seen in older women and is characterised by delayeed cycles followed by heavy menstrual bleeding due to glandular hyperplasia in the endometrium.
  • It is not a complication of PID

questions.text:
Your senior doctor, while examining a patient, uses a slit lamp and focuses on the peripheral cornea near the limbus at an angle of 60 degrees:



Which of the following structures is being examined?
questions.solution:
Option B: Measuring anterior chamber depth

Van Herick’s method

  • Measures anterior chamber depth with a slit lamp, focusing on the peripheral cornea near the limbus at an angle of 60 degrees as shown in the image given in the question.
  • It compares anterior chamber depth with corneal thickness.

Van Herick’s Grading 

  • Grade 4 PAC >= CT
    • Grade 3 PAC = 1/4 to 1/2 of CT
    • Grade 2 PAC = 1/4 of CT
    • Grade 1 PAC < 1/4 of CT

CT: Corneal thickness

PAC: Peripheral anterior chamber depth

  • Grade 4 means the likelihood of angle closure is rare

Option A: Schwalbe’s line

  • The Schwalbe’s line is visible at 10 degrees on gonioscopy which carries a high risk of angle closure.

Option C: Assessing Trabecular meshwork

  • If the trabecular meshwork is visible at 20 degrees on the gonioscopy, there is a possible risk of angle closure.

Option D: Anterior chamber volume

  • At 60 degrees, the Van Herick method detects the depth of the anterior chamber, not the volume.​​​​​​​

questions.text: Provides an image of the blood vessels in the brain to detect a problem with blood flow. Below is a picture of digital subtraction angiography of the carotid artery. Which of the following is the pathology depicted or shown below?

choices.text: Angiofibroma tumour blush in the region supplied by the maxillary artery
Diffused Hemangioma of the head and neck region

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Caroticocavernous fistula

  • Digital subtraction angiography showing Caroticocavernous fistula
  • Prominent blood flow into the Superior ophthalmic vein
  • A dent causing blood or contrast to flow through cavernous sinus → superior ophthalmic vein→ Orbit

Carotid-cavernous fistula:

  • Abnormal communication between the arterial and venous systems within the cavernous sinus in the skull.
  • Type of arteriovenous fistula.
  • Causes pulsatile exophthalmos

Option A: Angiofibroma tumor blush in the region supplied by the maxillary artery

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma:

  • Benign tumors arise predominantly in the nasopharynx of adolescent males.
  • This causes a tumor blush in the area provided by a maxillary artery in angiography.

Option C: Pseudoaneurysm of ICA

  • Pseudoaneurysms of the internal carotid artery are less common than true aneurysms comprising 14% of cases.
  • True aneurysms are most commonly due to atherosclerosis or fibromuscular dysplasia.
  • The major cause of pseudoaneurysm is the previous endarterectomy.
  • Other causes include trauma and infections.

Option D: Diffused Hemangioma of the head and neck region

  • Hemangiomas are common benign vascular tumors of infancy characterized by a proliferative growth phase followed by very slow inevitable regression (involution phase) between one to ten years of age.
  • 70% of the lesions are present in the head and neck region.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old baseball player jumps to catch a ball with his left hand. As his hand contacts the ball, he feels severe pain in his left shoulder. He presents to the emergency department with worsening shoulder pain. You note that he holds his left arm in slight external rotation, supporting its weight with his right hand. On physical examination, he resists internal rotation of his right arm.
Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
While catching the ball, this athlete has sustained forceful abduction and external rotation of his left arm, resulting in anterior dislocation of the humeral head from the glenoid fossa. In anterior shoulder dislocations, the humeral head is displaced anteriorly relative to the glenoid fossa and the anterior capsule of the glenohumeral joint is often torn. Physical exam will reveal prominence of the acromion with an abnormal subacromial space where the humeral head normally resides. Fullness of the anterior shoulder is noted on palpation. Anterior shoulder dislocations is associated with neurologic examination of axillary nerve function, as the axillary nerve courses around the medial undersurface of the humeral head through the quadrangular space and can be injured by anteroinferior shoulder dislocations. Axillary nerve injury can cause paralysis of the deltoid and teres minor muscles as well as loss of sensation over the lateral upper arm.

Option A : Fracture of the humeral midshaft and use of improperly fitted crutches cause radial nerve injury. Symptoms include wrist drop and sensory loss on the posterior arm, forearm, and lateral dorsal hand.

Option B : The ulnar nerve may be injured by fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus or more distally by deep lacerations of the anterior wrist. Symptoms include "claw hand" resulting from paralysis of most of the intrinsic muscles of the hand as well as sensory loss on the dorsal and ventral medial hand.

Option C : The musculocutaneous nerve arises from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus and innervates the biceps, brachialis and coracobrachialis muscles. It is not frequently injured by common forms of upper extremity trauma.

Bottom Line: Acute shoulder pain after forceful abduction and external rotation at the glenohumeral joint suggests an anterior shoulder dislocation, which may cause injury to the axillary nerve or artery

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman who works at a restaurant-bar is dropped by a man at the doorstep of medical emergency. She appears irritable and anxious at the same time, keeps scratching her arms and legs,and jerks them repeatedly while walking towards the emergency. She sits in a tripod posture ,clenches her chest and moans in pain. On examination,she appears confused regarding her whereabouts, has dilated pupils,PR 95/minute,BP 160/90 mm Hg. Which of the following substances has she most likely been using?
questions.solution:
ANSWERS:

(B) Coccaine : The woman in the case scenario has signs of coccaine overdose. They are agitation, chest pain, hallucinations, paranoia, anxiety, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure, and “coccaine bugs”. Vascular and coronary spasms occur in coccaine toxicity and increase the risk of arrythmias. Other complications are blurring of vision, delirium, neurological deficits. ECG and Chest Xray are advised in suspected cases to look for myocardial infarction and pulmonary edema.

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

(A) Cannabis: Marijuana intoxication is characterized by euphoria, sense of relaxation, tachycardia, nystagmus, ataxia and paranoia. Coccaine bugs, dilated pupils are not the signs of cannabis use. Cardiac complications are also rare.

(C) Opioid use : It is characterized by Sedation, Analgesia, Constipation, Respiratory depression, Urinary retention, Miosis (numonic SACRUM). These symptoms are not a part of the presenting woman’s symptoms profile.

(D) Alcohol : Use of alcohol leads to euphoria, increased psychomotor activity, increased talk, elated mood, tachycardia. Intoxication is characterized by incoordination, slurred speech, congested eyes. The symptoms in the given clinical scenario do not suffice the criteria for alcohol intoxication.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

Excessive use of coccaine causes mydriasis, vasoconstriction, coronary vasospasm, hyperthermia, tachycardia, tremors, muscle twitches, vertigo, crack bugs or coccaine bugs (tactile hallucinations giving a sense of insects crawling all over).

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought in neuropsychiatry unit by her son for progressive memory loss and behavioural disturbances of acute onset(1 month duration). The son also mentions his mother;s struggle with navigation leading her to have recurrent falls lately. She would also pass urine frequently in her clothes and when probed she would answer that she had difficulty in holding back the urine. Based on the history, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:

(C) Normal pressure hydrocephalus:

This patient demonstrates the classic triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH): cognitive dysfunction, gait impairment (often termed “magnetic gait”), and urinary incontinence.

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

(A) Delirium :

It is characterized by clouded consciousness, impaired and fluctuating attention, disorientation, affective changes, sleep cycle reversal and motor abnormalities. The person in above scenario does not meet any of the criteria of delirium.

(B) Senile dementia:

It is characterised by Forgetfulness, difficulty in routine daily activities since past 1 year suggest a possibility of onset of dementia in the patient. The patient in the above scenario has an acute onset of memory loss associated with incoordination of gait. (D) Parkinson plus syndrome : It is a group of neurodegenerative disorder with signs and symptoms of Parkinson;s disease along with additional features of Multisystem atrophy, Progressive supranuclear palsy,Cortico-basal degeneration. None of these features are present in the index case.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

MRI brain would be the first best diagnostic test to start with in cases with NPH. MRI in NPH reveals ventriculomegaly, which is out of proportion to cortical atrophy. The triad of NPH is called Hakim’s triad.

questions.text: A middle aged man brought to emergency department due to unsteady walking. His symptoms began a wee prior to presentation and it has progressively worsened. He reports double vision, Prickling and needles sensations in fingers, toes and wrists. On physical examination reveals ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, difficulty breathing, reflex loss, and numbness. cell count of 1/uL, protein is 130 mg/dL and glucose is 75 mg/dL. For frequent conservative acute supportive care like negative inspiratory pressure, plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin he admitted in neurology department. What is the most likely diagnosis?.
questions.solution:
Guillain-Barre Syndrome is a rare neurological disorder immune system mistakenly attacks the healthy peripheral neurones. Classically presents with progressive , symmetric, ascending paralysis .Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. It can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing the body. Symptoms are tingling or pain in the toes and fingertips, weakness or pain in the legs that causes trouble walking, loss of reflexes, facial weakness, breathing problems.

Choice B : Ramsay hunt syndrome is a rare neurological disorder characterized by paralysis of the facial nerve (CN7)

Choice C : Costello Syndrome is caused by mutations in the HRAS gene . This gene provides instructions for making a protein called H-Ras, which is part of a pathway that helps control cell growth and division .

Choice D : lateral pontine syndrome occurs due to occlusion of perforating branches of the basilar and anterior inferior cerebellar arteries .

Educational objective : Guillain-Barré syndrome is a rare but serious autoimmune disorder. The exact cause of Guillain-Barre syndrome is unknown. plasma exchange and immunoglobulin therapy can relieve symptom. The most frequently described causes of death in GBS are respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, pneumonia and autonomic dysfunction.

questions.text: 65 year old Christopher experienced severe abdominal discomfort during a birthday party of his friend. He started vomiting and was taken to hospital. On taking medical history he was having inconsistent bowel habits and bloody stool since 3 months.He was diagnosed with colon tumor and underwent colonic resection for the same. One day later his urine output was 9 ml/hr , K 7 meq/l, Na 135 meq/l, Cl 98meq/l and HCo3 23 meq/l. What is the cause for this metabolic imbalance?
questions.solution:
Peaked T wave is seen in patients with low urine output and hyperkalemia as in this case scenario.

Incorrect Answers

Option A: Cardiac arrest occurs with diastole in case of low urine output and hyperkalemia and not with systole.

Option B: Distention of Abdomen is seen with hypokalemia .

Option C: ECG shows wide QRS wave with hyperkalemia and not narrow one.

Educational objectives: Colorectal tumor is presented with abdominal discomfort, bloody stool, inconsistent bowel habits and changes in stool consistency. Colectomy or colon resection is the removal of part or entire colon. Many risk and damage to nearby organs can occur during the surgery. Low urine output and hyperkalemia is characterized by cardiac arrest during diastole, wide QRS and tall T wave.

Normal urine output – 800-2000 ml/day .

Normal Na level – 135-145 meq/l

Normal K level – 3.6 – 5.2 meq/ l

Normal Cl level – 96-106 meq/l

Normal HCo3 level- 22- 28 meq/l

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is noted to have a blood pressure of 60/62 mm Hg on the evening after laparotomy and small bowel resection for strangulated small bowel obstruction. His heart rate is 112 beats/ minute, respiratory rate is 24 breath/ minute, and temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F); urine output is 20 mL over 2 hours and oxygen saturation by pulse oximeter is 95%. His preoperative hemoglobin value is 12.6 g/ dL. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this patient?

choices.text: Hb value of 12.4 g/dL obtained in the recovery room after surgery is good indication that his hypotension is not caused by blood loss.
Intravenous furosemide (Lasix) should be administered to improve his urine output.
This patient likely is affected by anxiety and a mild anxiolytic should be provided with close observation.
The initial treatment should be a fluid bolus.
CT imaging should be done to assess for possible bleeding or intraabdominal infectious process

questions.solution:
This is a young man who is hypotensive following an operation for strangulated small bowel obstruction. His postoperative urine output is low (< 0.5 mL/ kg/ h) and his pulse rate is elevated. Given the scenario of having strangulated small bowel obstruction that required a bowel resection, it is likely that he is hypovolemic secondary to the third-space fluid losses associated with his bowel obstruction and his recent laparotomy.

Option D : Fluid bolus is the best choice at this point.

Option B : Furosemide is not indicated unless there is clear evidence that his intravascular volume is normal or elevated.

Option E : CT scan is not likely to provide useful information this soon following the operation.

Bottom line

Recognizing third space losses in cases of strangulated hernia and replacing the fluid losses is the key to managing hypovolemia leading to hypovolemic shock.

questions.text: In the following figure, the spiral arteries are identified by which letter?

A professional photographer aged 26 came to your primary clinic complains excruciating pain that is generally situated around one eye and it radiate left side of his face and head. He also reported headaches usually occur every day, sometimes several times a day and each episode last nearly 3o to 45 minutes. He denies recent trauma episodes, aura, vomiting and nausea. Physical examination shows restlessness, excessive tearing, redness of your eye and stuffy or runny nose on the affected side, swelling around his left eye. What is the diagnosis of this patient condition.?

choices.text: Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headaches with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT) syndrome

questions.solution:
Cluster headaches are sudden, excruciating headaches that usually affect one side of the head and the area around the eyes. Primary headache disorder characterized by 1-unilateral periorbital pain, 2-ipsilateral cranial autonomic manifestations. A type of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) that typically a single attack can last from 15 minutes to three hours and occurs "clusters". The exact etiology of cluster headaches is unknown, but cluster headache patterns suggest that abnormalities in the body's biological clock play a role. Treatment is Acute therapy: High-flow O2 or sumatriptan injection. Prophylactic therapy verapamil is first line. Alternatives include lithium, valproic acid, and topiramate.

Choice B :Migraine is more common in women and presents as a unilateral throbbing headache that worsens with exercise.

Choice C :Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache attacks with Conjunctival injection and Tearing more common in males. A pituitary tumor causes SUNCT as a secondary headache. Usually very short lasting and the pain is much less severe as compared to cluster headache.

Choice D :Trigeminal neuralgia manifests as pain in the trigeminal nerve distribution. Pain areas is the mouth and face. Heachaches are inconsistent and symptoms respond to carbamazepine.

Educational objective: Cluster headache is a distinctive episodic syndrome of headaches that affects quality of life. Men are more likely to have cluster headaches. Alcohol use, smoking, age, family history are risk factors. Pathophysiology of cluster headache is vascular dilation, trigeminal nerve stimulation, and circadian effects. Histamine release, an increase in mast cells, genetic factors, and autonomic nervous system activation may also contribute.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl developed a left Bell’s palsy over the course of 1 week. She was given acyclovir and prednisone. Over the next 3 months she seemed to recover almost fully. However,she has noticed involuntary twitching at the left corner of the mouth each time she tries to blink the left eye. This is most likely caused by

choices.text: Aberrant regeneration of the facial nerve

questions.solution:
- After injury to the facial nerve, regenerating fibers may be misdirected. This is especially common with Bell’s palsy (idiopathic facial weakness).
- Aberrant regeneration is possible only if the nerve cell bodies survive the injury and produce axons that find their way to neuromuscular junctions.
- Fibers intended for the periorbital muscles end up at the perioral muscles, and signals for eye closure induce mouth retraction.
- With a habit spasm or idiopathic tic, similar movements may occur, but the movement disorder would not be linked to facial weakness.

questions.text: A child born with multiple congenital defect including cleft palate, neural tube defect, atrial, septal defect and microcephaly which of the following drug is used by mother during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A supplementation is not given in pregnancy due to the possibility of adverse effects. Vit A is category X drug which are contraindicated for use in pregnancy.

The only congener of vitamin A that can be used safely in pregnancy is  carotene.

  • Abortions
  • Central nervous system defects
  • Microophthalmia
  • Thymic changes
  • Cardiovascular defects

Craniofacial dysmorphism including cleft lip and palate.

Pregnancy Category Description
A No risk in controlled human studies:Adequate and well-controlled human studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus in the first trimester of pregnancy (and there is no evidence of risk in later trimesters).
B No risk in other studies:Animal reproduction studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus and there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women OR Animal studies have shown an adverse effect, but adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus in any trimester.
C Risk not ruled out:Animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus and there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks.
D Positive evidence of risk:There is positive evidence of human fetal risk based on adverse reaction data from investigational or marketing experience or studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks.
X Contraindicated in pregnancy:Studies in animals or humans have demonstrated fetal abnormalities and/or there is positive evidence of human fetal risk based on adverse reaction data from investigational or marketing experience, and the risks involved in use of the drug in pregnant women clearly outweigh potential benefits.
N FDA has not yet classified the drug into a specified pregnancy category.

questions.text: Following spontaneous vaginal delivery, your patient complains of right leg weakness. Examination revealsan inability to flex the right hip and extend the leg. A common risk factor for this complication includeswhich of the following?
questions.solution:
Pressure on branches of the lumbosacral nerve plexus during labor may be manifest by complaints of intense neuralgia or cramplike pains extending down one or both legs as soon as the head descends
into the pelvis. If the nerve is injured, pain may continue after delivery, and there also may be variable
degrees of sensory loss or muscle paralysis. In some cases, there is footdrop, which can be secondary to injury at the level of the lumbosacral root, lumbosacral plexus, sciatic nerve, or common fibular (peroneal) nerve. Components of the lumbosacral plexus cross the pelvic brim and can be compressed by the fetal head or by forceps. The common fibular nerves may be externally compressed when the legs are positioned in stirrups, especially during a prolonged second stage of labor

questions.text: A 18 year old boy with sickle cell disease referred to eye clinic for evaluation of two days of blurry vision and new-onset floaters in the left eye that developed while playing basketball. Fundus examination is shown below . Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding this condition

choices.text: Sea fan appearance seen in superotemporal area
HbSS has severe ocular manifestations compared HbSC

questions.solution:
The image shows salmon patches which represent retinal hemorrhage from superficial blood vessels - seen in Sickle cell Retinopathy.

Sickle cell Retinopathy

SS genotype causes more severe systemic disease than SC and S-Thal genotypes and SC and S-Thal genotypes present with ocular manifestations, including proliferative sickle cell retinopathy.

The underlying systemic and ocular manifestations of SCD (Sickle Cell Disease) are a result of vaso-occlusive ischemia.

Non-proliferative Sickle retinopathy (NPSR):

· Occlusion of retinal vasculature first appears in the peripheral retina as “salmon patches”, which represent retinal hemorrhage from superficial blood vessels.

· Migration and proliferation of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) leads to the development of black sunburst spots

· Occlusions in the choroidal circulation with associated breaks in Bruch’s membrane are known to cause angioid streaks.

Salmon-patch

Proliferative Sickle Retinopathy (PSR):

Chronic changes of local hypoxia and ischemia -->up-regulation of vascular growth factors--> retinal neovascularization,vitreous hemorrhage and tractional retinal detachment.

Sea fan formation with neovascularization.

Retinal vascular occlusions including arterial or venous occlusions (both central and branch) can occur as a complication of sickle cell disease though rare.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of chest pain for 6 hours while gardening. He is distressed and sweating heavily. The patient has no history of cardiac diseases. The ECG shows ST segment elevation and cardiac troponin are elevated. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. Which of the following imaging modality is suitable in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Multidetector CT

  • This is a case of myocardial infarction in which the patient presents with complaints of sudden onset of chest pain while working.

  • The patient with myocardial infarction usually has left-sided chest pain, which radiates to the back, neck, jaw and left arm.

  • The symptoms may differ from person to person.

  • This is caused due to decreased blood supply to the heart resulting in ischemia of the myocardium.

  • The diagnosis of myocardial infarction is made based on ST elevation in the ECG.

Multidetector CT:

  • It has a cone-shaped beam of X-ray

  • Multiple slices of detectors and useful in Cardiovascular imaging.

  • Multi-detector CT is particularly suitable for imaging the chest, heart and vessels

  • It is also useful for imaging trauma patients.

 

 

Option A: Second-generation CT

  • In second-generation CT, mini fan beams were used so that fewer translations were needed to acquire each view of CT data.

Option B: Third-generation CT

  • In third-generation CT, the fan beam enabled the complete view to be covered simultaneously.

Option C: Spiral CT

  • Spinal CT is done during arterial portography for preoperative detection and localization of focal liver lesions, renal cell carcinoma staging, or pancreatic disease imaging.

questions.text: An 8 year old kid is brought by his parents to the outpatient department of psychiatry saying the child had become difficult to manage. At school, he would keep running around in the class. He wouldn't wait for his turn in class and also at times hit other kids. Teachers had repeatedly complained regarding his behaviour at school. At home, he would keep running around, changing toys very frequently and often threw them. Which of the following medications would benefit the child?
questions.solution:
Correct answer-

(B) Atomoxetine:

Difficulty in managibility, running around,not waiting for his turn in the child suggest that he has attention deficit hyperkinetic disorder(ADHD). Atomoxetine is used in the management of ADHD.

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

A, C, D

(A) Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor used primarily in the management of major depressive disorder. It is not used primarily in ADHD. (

C) Nitrofurantoin is an antibacterial used in the management of urinary tract infection.

(D) Chlordiazepoxide is a long acting benzodiazepine. It is used in management of alcohol withdrawal. It is not primarily used to treat ADHD.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

Attention deficit hyperkinetic disorder is characterised by hyperactivity, impulsivity and inattention. It can be combined, predominantly hyperactive-impulsive presentation or predominantly inattentive presentation. Pharmacological management of ADHD includes stimulants like methylphenidate, amphetamines and non stimulants like atomoxetine, clonidine and guanfacine.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother for the chief compliant of muscle aches and weakness. The symptoms were lasting for the past week, lasting for past one week. His mom tried giving him syrup paracetamol but no Improvement to be noted. He denies any recent trauma. His mom stated that now a days he is being thirsty always and his urinary fequency is also increased. His vitals are found to be stable. Lab investigations are ordered which revealed hypomagnesemia and normal potassium. His urine studies show decreased calcium. By seeing the lab finding the pediatrician deceided to do a genetic testing which revealed a Autosomal recessive mutation involving the Distal convoluted tubule .what is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Gitelman syndrome is caused by the mutation involving NaCl cotransporter (NCTT) which results in impaired Na+ reabsorption in distal convoluted tubule. It causes mild hypokalemia, mild metabolic alkalosis ,significant hypomagnesemia and normal blood pressure. It is detected in young children but can be detected in adulthood as well. The distal segment is composed of a tight epithelium with little water permeability. Mutation in this segment causes metabolic abnormalities. The symptoms are polyuria, polydipsia, muscle weakness or cramp, fatigue, paresthesias, abdominal pain and vomiting.

Choice A: Fanconi syndrome is caused by the defect in proximal convoluted tubule which results in problems in reabsorption of almost all amino acids, glucose, bicarbonate, phosphate, and potassium. It is caused due to various genetic factors among which cystinosis is the most common .It is also caused by numerous drugs such as cisplatin, tenofovir ,valproic acid and expired tetracyclines.

Choice B : Batter syndrome is caused due to the defect in thick ascending loop of henle. Autosomal recessive mutation involving the Na-K-2cl cotransporter .

The symptoms includes Hypokalemia ,Hypochloremia ,Metabolic alkalosis, Hypomagnesemia ,Hypocalciuria and Normotension.

CHOICE D : It is caused due to the defect in Collecting tubule. It is an Autosomal dominant mutation leading to increased activity of epithelial Na+ channel (EnaC). Symptoms include Hypertension, Hypokalemia and Metabolic alkalosis.

Objective learning : Gitelman syndrome is a Autosomal recessive disorder involves the mutation in the Distal convoluted tubule .

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to his family physician with complaints of vertical diplopia. He further explains that he feels unsure while descending stairs. He can eliminate the double vision by tilting his head toward the opposite side. The patient is otherwise vitally stable and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following extraocular muscles is responsible for ocular malalignment in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Superior oblique

  • This is a case of superior oblique palsy in which the patient presents with complaints of vertical diplopia.
  • The patient further explains he feels unsure while descending stairs.
  • The superior oblique depresses, abducts, and intorts the eye.
  • Paralysis of this muscle results in extorsion and weakness of downward gaze.
  • Head tilting compensates for extorsion.
  • Chin depression would be seen in superior oblique palsy.

Option A: Inferior rectus

  • One of the seven extraocular muscles, the inferior rectus, is principally in charge of depressing the eye (downgaze).
  • One of the four rectus muscles is the inferior rectus.
  • Other rectus muscles are the superior rectus, medial rectus, and lateral rectus.

Option B: Inferior oblique

  • The inferior oblique causes the movements of extorsion, elevation, and abduction.
  • The only muscles that can lower or raise the eye when the eye moves in adduction are the superior and inferior oblique muscles due to their courses.

Option C: Lateral rectus

  • The flat-shaped anterior portion of the lateral rectus is wider than the rest of the muscle.
  • Along with the medial rectus, an adductor, the lateral rectus muscle moves the eye laterally and side to side.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. He gets the pain when he takes his meal. He has never had similar symptoms before. The patient had sustained injury with handlebar of the bicycle 3 days back. His vital signs are normal. Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the epigastric area. Bowel sounds heard. Ultrasonography does not demonstrate free intraperitoneal fluid. Plain abdominal radiograph shows dilated stomach with scanty distal gas. Laboratory results are as follows Hemoglobin 12.8 g/dL Leukocytes 9000/mm. Total bilirubin 1.4 mg/dL Amylase 87 U/L Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Duodenal hematomas (DHs) most commonly occur following blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) They are more commonly seen in children due to thinner abdominal wall musculature. DH commonly occurs when a blunt force rapidly compresses the duodenum against the vertebral column. Following trauma, blood collects between the submucosal and muscular layers of the duodenum causing partial or complete obstruction. Patients with DH due to BAT may initially have only symptoms of abdominal wall trauma, which may improve before subsequent clinical deterioration as the DH expands Patients classically present 24-36 hours after the initial event with epigastric pain and vomiting due to failure to pass gastric contents beyond the obstructing hematoma. Diagnosis is confirmed with CT imaging of the abdomen. Most DHs will resolve in 1-2 weeks. Management involves decompression by nasogastric tube and, in many patients, parenteral nutrition. Surgery or percutaneous drainage may be considered to evacuate the hematoma if nonoperative management fails.

Option B : Liver laceration is one of the most common complications of BAT However, this patient's lack of right upper quadrant tenderness, lack of intraperitoneal free fluid, hemodynamic stability, and normal blood counts make a liver laceration less likely (

Option C : The pancreas is infrequently injured during BAT, but occasionally patients can develop pancreatic pseudocysts subacutely (days to weeks) after an event with nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and a palpable abdominal mass. It would be unlikely for a pancreatic pseudocyst to develop within 2 days

Option D : Pyloric stenosis classically presents with nausea, vomiting, and poor feeding in a 1-month-old infant It would be an extremely rare presentation in a preadolescent child.

Bottom Line: Duodenal hematomas are more commonly seen in pediatric patients and most often occur following blunt abdominal trauma. They present with epigastric pain and vomiting 24-36 hours after the initial injury Management involves gastric decompression and parenteral nutrition.

questions.text: A patient has facial symmetry at rest but obvious right facial weakness when she smiles. She is just able to close her right eye, and there is definite but minimal movement of the right forehead. Under the House-Brackmann system, she would be described as grade
questions.solution: House Brackmann Grading

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl is mugged by a tall man while she was going to the market. She was held at gunpoint and her wrist watch, wallet and mobile phone were taken. The tall man hit her on head and she started bleeding from the same. She was found by a policeman on patrol sitting by the pavement bleeding and terrified. In subsequent months, she refused to sleep alone in a room and constantly looked towards the window, scared that her assailant has found her again. On the rare occasion that she falls asleep, she would wake up screaming due to a terrible nightmare during which she sees the entire event unfold in front of her. Whenever she used to step out of home, every time she sees a tall man, she would experience palpitations, diaphoresis, and an intense sense of fear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER:

(C ) Post Traumatic Stress Disorder: The patient in the given clinical scenario has classical symptoms of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). It is characterized by presence of recurrent,involuntary,intrusive memories,traumatic nightmares ,”flashbacks’’, dissociative reactions, associated with prolonged distress after exposure to trauma related stimuli. Avoidance of the related cues is classical of PTSD.

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

(A) Major depressive disorder: Other symptoms of major depression including major criteria are missing in the given scenario. They are pervasive sadness of mood, decreased activity or energy levels, anhedonia.

(B) Acute stress disorder: Symptoms of Acute stress disorder share similar profile with that of PTSD,but they usually resolve withing 4 weeks of the traumatic event.

(D) Acute psychosis: It is characterized by abrupt or acute onset of hallucinations,paranoid symptoms including fixed,false unshakeable beliefs,,marked psychomotor agitation with rapid fluctuations in mood states.Other symptoms in the given scenario cannot be explained by psychosis

(E )Generalized anxiety disorder: Persons with GAD have excessive preoccupation with worrying about most activities ,ranging from one to another (free-floating anxiety). It is associated with autonomic symptoms and are present for most time of the day . Associated symptoms are abdominal cramps,headache,muscle aches and unexplained pains.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

Treatment of choice of PTSD is Trauma focussed psychotherapy, CBT,Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR).

questions.text: which grip is represented by the image below:
questions.solution:
Option A : The image represents the fundal grip or first leopold

The palpation is done facing the patient’s face.

The whole of the fundal area is palpated using both hands laid flat on it to find out which pole of the fetus is lying in the fundus:

(a) broad, soft and irregular mass suggestive of breech, or

(b) smooth, hard and globular mass suggestive of head.

In transverse lie, neither of the fetal poles are palpated in the fundal area.

 

 

Option B : Second leopold : Image B : involves palpation of the lateral uterine surfaces. Facing the maternal xiphoid cartilage, both hands slide down from the uterine fundus towards the lateral uterine walls. The clinician's hands are placed flat and parallel to each other along the abdominal wall at the level of the umbilicus. It allows establishing if the fetus is in a longitudinal, transverse, or oblique situation, and to determine the position of the back and small parts.

Option C : Third leopold : The examination is done facing towards the patient’s face. The overstretched thumb and four fingers of the right hand are placed over the lower pole of the uterus keeping the ulnar border of the palm on the upper border of the symphysis pubis. When the fingers and the thumb are approximated, the presenting part is grasped distinctly (if not engaged) and also the mobility from side to side is tested. In transverse lie, Pawlik’s grip is empty.

Option D : Fourth leopold : Image D : This maneuver resembles the first maneuver; however, the examiner faces towards the maternal pelvis. The examiner places the palms of both hands on either side of the lower abdomen, with the tips of the fingers facing downward toward the pelvic inlet. It is possible to identify the characteristics of the part presented and confirm the findings detected with the third Leopold maneuver. It is possible to evaluate the degree of descent of the presented part and to identify which presenting part is in the lower uterine pole.

questions.text:
Due to increased calcium levels in blood secondary to elevated parathyroid hormone level cause recurrent episode of renal stones and dehydration a male professional website disinger aged 42 undergoes parathyroidectomy.He is fully recovered from the anesthesia and no evidence of complications and now he is prepared to return to the nursing unit. His vital signs are temperature 36.7°C , respiration 14 breaths/min, oxygen saturation is 97% with normal blood pressure. Now he is complaining about perioral numbness. which management is more more appropriate for this patient?
Choices
questions.solution:
Hyperparathyroidism is disorder of parathyroid gland. It cause excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone. Symptoms are kidney stones, bone pain, constipation, abdominal pain, depression. Risk factors includes female gender is more affected, prior radiation therapy , ongoing severe prolonged vitamin D and calcium deficiency, multiple endocrine neoplasia,etc.

In this case treatment with IV calcium gluconate is more appropriate in symptomatic hypocalcaemia. Because after parathyroidectomy followed by perioral numbness is suggests hypocalcaemia.

Choice A : conservation treatment is better to asymptomatic hypocalcaemia not for symptomatic hypocalcaemia

Choice B : Pottasium phosphate is use to treat Hypophosphatemia

Choice C : Vitamin D supplement can't resolve hypocalcaemia quickly.

Choice D : Calcium gluconate is more appropriate.

Educational objective:

Hyper parathyroid is a common endocrine disorder.Three types of hyperparathyroidism; primary, secondary, and tertiary. Complications includes peptic ulcer disease, acute pancreatitis,CNS dysfunction.

questions.text: An 85 yr old lady with history of fracture neck of femur, during GA under halothane anesthesia for internal fixation of fracture suddenly develops severe hypotension, bradycardia, capnogram shows sudden fall end tidal carbon dioxide, and most probable diagnosis is:-
questions.solution:
Sudden fall of CO2 the answer will always be embolism.

A decrease in end tidal Co2 is seen with a decrease in cardiac output if ventilation remains constant A rapid decrease of PET Co2 in absence of massive blood loss represents EMBOLISM.

questions.text: A senior consultant visits all patients for a round in labor room. All of the following four patients have been admitted in labor, however the consultant immediately sends one of these for a cesarean section :
questions.solution:
Vaginal delivery is contraindicated in Classical C.S because there is more chance of rupture of the uterus.

This is because this portion of the uterus is taking part in active contractions and will predispose to uterine rupture.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic patient presented with eye pain, gradually worsening, and blurred vision. He also complained of shapes floating in the field of vision, for which he had recently undergone pan-retinal photocoagulation for proliferative diabetic retinopathy. He now presents with corneal edema, neovascularization over the iris, and an IOP of 55 mm Hg. All of the following medications are appropriate except?
questions.solution:
In a patient with acute angle-closure glaucoma secondary to neovascularization and high intraocular pressure (IOP), the goal of treatment is to lower the IOP quickly and relieve the symptoms. Here's how each option fits in:

Option A. Atropine: Atropine is a mydriatic agent that dilates the pupil. It is contraindicated in angle-closure glaucoma as it can further obstruct the angle, leading to an increase in IOP. Incorrect.

Option B. Dorzolamide: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to lower intraocular pressure. It can be used in this scenario to decrease IOP. Correct.

Option C. Apraclonidine: Apraclonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces aqueous humor production. It is used to lower IOP in acute angle-closure glaucoma. Correct.

Option D. Pilocarpine: Pilocarpine is a miotic agent that constricts the pupil and pulls the iris away from the angle, allowing aqueous humor to flow out more freely. It is used in acute angle-closure glaucoma to open the angle and reduce IOP. Correct.

So, the correct answer is Option A. Atropine, which is contraindicated in angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient presented to the clinic with a history of chronic diarrhea, bloating, weight loss, and poor appetite for the past several months. A trial of antibiotic treatment a couple of months ago produced no significant clinical improvement. Her pulse rate was 82 beats per minute, BP was 110/78 mm of Hg. Laboratory investigations revealed anemia. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the histopathological findings are suggestive of celiac disease.

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluteninduced enteropathy. It is associated with HLA DQ2 and DQ8. The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin (gluten-derived peptide). In the small intestine, gliadin is deamidated by the tissue transglutaminase (tTG), an intestinal enzyme. The deamidated gliadin is more immunogenic and is presented to helper T cells which mediate mucosal inflammation and cause tissue damage.

Microscopic findings on biopsy of the proximal small intestine will show villi atrophy, villi flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes.

Clinically, patients with celiac disease present with malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, chronic refractory anemia, and marked unintentional weight loss. Some patients may also present with dermatitis herpetiformis characterized by herpes-like vesicles that are caused due to the deposition of IgA at the tips of the dermal papillae.

Antiendomysial and anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies are found in serological studies. Symptoms can be reversed by a gluten-free diet.

OTHER OPTIONS

OPTION A

Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is associated with tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy.

OPTION C

Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T.whipplei. Small intestine biopsy shows, PAS-positive macrophages.

OPTION D

Chronic pancreatitis affects the phase of intraluminal digestion is affected in which proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into forms suitable for absorption. These patients have fat malabsorption that presents as steatorrhea.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten induced enteropathy. It is associated with HLA DQ2 and DQ8. The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin (gluten-derived peptide). In the small intestine, gliadin is deamidated by the tissue transglutaminase (tTG), an intestinal enzyme. The deamidated gliadin is more immunogenic and is presented to helper T cells which mediate mucosal inflammation and cause tissue damage.

questions.text: The orthopaedic fellow on call is called from the paediatrics department. He is told that a child has been born with some spinal defect. The fellow is busy on a case so he asks the residents calling to describe it. The paediatric resident says that the child appears like a ‘seated Buddha’. What is the diagnosis that should come to his mind?
questions.solution:
Clubfoot and metatarsus adductus are the deformities of the foot.

CDH will be diagnosed at birth via performing ortolnai and Barlow test.

Learning Objectives: Sometimes certain catch phrases help you reach an answer. This is one of them.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the ophthalmology department for a routine eye check-up. However, she reports frequent headaches, eye strain and a feeling of heaviness in the head for the past month. Her blood pressure was 110/70 mmHg, and her pulse rate was 75 beats per minute. The ophthalmologist takes complete history, and her evaluation for eyesight is done. On Snellen chart, she reads 6/6 in both her eyes. What is the largest approximate distance she could read the first topmost letter in the chart?
questions.solution:
Option C: 60 m

  • It means that the patient, with or without glasses, can see the letter at a distance of 6 m which a person normally should have seen at 6 m.
  • 6/12 means a letter that a normal patient should see at 12 meters. This patient can see only when he is nearer, which means 6 meters from the target, 6/60 means that a normal patient should see at 60 meters, but this patient has to be much closer, which means 6 meters ·
  • This also means that the letter written at 6/60 is big enough that a 6/6 vision person can read it at even 60 meters.
  • Snellen chart
  • The Snellen chart is used to test distant vision.
  • In the distant vision, the shape of the eye lens is thin and less convex.
  • The ability to see a relatively far-away image (greater than about 36 inches).

Option A: 36 m

  • A patient without glasses can see the letter at a distance of 6 m which is normal.
  • 6/36 means that a patient should see at 30 meters, but this patient has to be much closer, which means 36 meters.

Option B: 24 m

  • A patient can see normal without glasses at a distance of 6 meters.
  • 6/24 means that a patient should see at 24 meters, but this patient has to be much closer, which means 24 meters.

Option D: 1m

  • One can see letters from a distance of 6 meters without any aid.
  • One meter means that a patient should see at 1 meter, but this patient must be much closer than 1.

questions.text: You are working as a nephro senior resident in a hospital. A 50 year-old man presents to you for a longstanding chronic kidney disease (CKD) secondary to uncontrolled hypertension and diabeties. He says that he is having severe shortness of breath. His extremities are noted with pitting edema. X ray was taken which revealed bilateral pleural effusion. His glomerular filtration rate (GFR) continues to decline, and he is approaching initiation of hemodialysis . So you got opinion with surgery resident and Plans are made to obtain vascular access at the appropriate time .The patient undergoes the requisite screening to be enrolled as an end stage renal disease (ESRD) patient. Among patients on chronic hemodialysis, which of the following is the most common cause of death?
questions.solution:
Heart failure can be a consequence of diastolic or systolic dysfunction, or both. A form of “low-pressure” pulmonary edema can also occur in advanced CKD, manifesting as shortness of breath and a “bat wing” distribution of alveolar edema fluid on the chest x-ray. Diabetes mellitus and hypertension are the two most frequent causes of advanced CKD, it is not surprising that cardiovascular disease is the most frequent cause of death in dialysis patients.

Choice A : There is no intuitive strong evidence between ESRD and developing neoplasm .

Choice B : Hemodialysis patients are more susceptible for Infections but it is unlikely to be the most common cause of death.

Choice c : stroke is common in hemodialysis patients but it tends to cause more morbidity than mortality. so it is unlikely to be the most common cause of death overall.

Objective learning : The most common cause of death among dialysis patients is cardiovascular disease, which includes sudden cardiac death, acute myocardial infarction, heart failure, and other etiologies.

questions.text:
A 21 year old man is brought to emergency department after motor vehicle collision. Paramedical personel immobilize his cervical spine, obtain intravenous access, and start normal saline infusion. In the emergency department, the patient is found in respiratory distress with respirations of 42/min. Heart rate is 124/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg after receiving 2 L of normal saline over 20 minutes. He develops progressive respiratory failure and receives right chest tube. Endotracheal intubation is performed and mechanical ventilation is initiated. Pulmonary examination reveals bilateral coarse breath sounds. Chest x-ray post intubation is shown in the image below.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple rib fractures (white arrows on chest x-ray) likely has flail chest. This condition is usually caused by blunt thoracic trauma ( eg, steering wheel hitting the chest in a motor vehicle collision), and describes what occurs when 2:3 adjacent ribs fracture in 2:2 places The fractured portion of the rib cage (flail segment) separates from the rest of the chest wall and moves in a paradoxical motion on respiration Due to negative intrathoracic pressure during inspiration and positive intrathoracic pressure during expiration, the flail segment tends to retract inward during inspiration (versus moving outward with the chest wall) and bulges outward during expiration (versus retracting inward) Patients with flail chest present with respiratory distress and tachypnea with shallow breaths. Muscle splinting may attenuate the paradoxical motion of the flail segment and make the diagnosis difficult on physical examination alone. Pain control and supplemental oxygen are early steps in management Respiratory failure can occur, often due to associated pulmonary contusion and resultant collection of edema and blood in the alveoli (evidenced by the left-sided alveolar opacity on chest x-ray) Acute respiratory distress syndrome and pneumonia are other potential complications Intubation with mechanical positive-pressure ventilation (and chest tube placement) is often required.

Option A : Diaphragmatic tear typically appears on x-ray as an abnormality in the diaphragmatic shadow, with herniation of abdominal contents into the left pleural space The tip of the nasogastric tube is typically seen in the left hemithorax rather than below the diaphragm (as in this patient)

Option B : Esophageal rupture typically presents with subcutaneous crepitus in the chest and appears on x-ray as a pneumomediastinum (not seen in this patient) (Option D) Myocardial dysfunction may result from myocardial contusion and lead to cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Bilateral alveolar infiltrates and interstitial markings would be expected on chest x-ray (not seen in this patient).

Option E : Tension pneumothorax can cause respiratory distress, hypotension, and tachycardia Tracheal and mediastinal displacement to the contralateral side (yellow arrow) and radiolucence on the affected side (red arrow) are typical features on chest x-ray Lack of improvement with bilateral chest tubes makes pneumothorax unlikely.

Bottom line: Flail chest should be suspected in patients with multiple rib fractures and respiratory distress. Classic x-ray findings show multiple rib fractures overlying a lung contusion.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents 8 hours after sexual assault. It is the 13th day of her menstrual cycle. Which emergency contraceptive should be prescribed to her?

choices.text: OCP from day 1 of next cycle

questions.solution:
In the question it should be noted that this patient has undergone sexual assault on her 13th day of menstrual cycle . So there is a higher chance of getting pregnant and action must be done immediately .

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is a progesterone only pill which is used to prevent pregnancy immediately.

Option B : Injections of DMPA are usually not preferred in such type of patients due to its slow onset of action .

Option C : OCP from day 1 of next cycle . This cannot be done in this patient because the action must be taken immediately.

Option D: Misoprostol is used as an abortifacient.

questions.text:
A 11-month-old boy presents with fever and a cough. His mother is concerned because he has had several respiratory and ear infections over the past few months. Serum analysis shows:
IgG: 200 mg/ dL (Normal range: 700-1600 mg/dL)
IgA: 10 mg/ dL (Normal range: 70-400 mg/dL)
IgM: 12 mg/ dL (Normal range: 40-230 mg/ dL)
IgE: Undetectable (Normal range: 0.002-0.2 mg/ dL)
The numbers of T cells are normal. Lymph Nodal Tissue is scarce. This boy is most likely suffering from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This boy most likely has Bruton agammaglobulinemia, which results from an X-linked defect in a BTK gene required for the production of mature B lymphocytes. Most often seen in boys (X linked) and is characterized by low levels of immunoglobulin of all isotypes (no mature B lymphocytes to produce the immunoglobulin). T lymphocyte number (CD4+ and CD8+ counts) are normal. Such children present with increased Bacterial and enteroviral infections.

INCORRECT OPTIONS

Selective Deficiency is Incorrect because all immunoglobulin classes are at low levels In this patient. (A)

Job syndrome (hyper-IgE syndrome) is a T cell disorder with deficiency of T helper 17. (C)

Ataxia-telangiectasia is caused by a defect in DNA repair enzymes. (E)

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

Bruton agammaglobulinemia classically presents with recurrent bacterial infections in boys older than 6 months. Laboratory findings include low levels of all immunoglobulin classes and normal T lymphocyte counts.

questions.text: A 32 year old female came to the emergency bay complaining of severe headache and several episodes of vomiting few hours ago. There are no other signs and symptoms. CT scan of the head revealed subarachnoid hemorrhage. There at the imaging room she lost consciousness and developed seizures. The Glasgow Coma score is 8. which of the following is the first step in management after controlling the seizure ?
questions.solution:
Intubation is the most important step in cases of Glasgow Coma Scale(GCS) score is 8 or less. Intubation should be mostly considered in cases whom the patient is not conscious, including apnea, decreased mental status, impending airway compromise (e.g burn injury or maxillofacial trauma), closed head injuries.

Choice A - trauma survey. Full trauma survey is ideal if the patient was presented to the emergency bay with GCS score of 8 or less, but that is not the case here. Once the patient is secured after controlling the seizure, additional components of the survey can be done.

Choice B - cervical spine evaluation is indicated in patients who presents to the emergency bay with trauma. The patient in the question stem was initially conscious, so the initial evaluation would not be cervical spine evaluation.

Choice C- antiepileptic and mannitol. Antiepileptics for seizure and mannitol for volume status are indicated, but securing the patients airway is the main concern. Mannitol an osmotic diuretic is used for the patients presenting acutely with findings suggestive of elevated intracranial pressure.

Learning objective

Securing the airway is the most important first step in managing patient who is unconscious and GCS is 8 or below.

questions.text: James is a 34-year-old American businessman working on an electronics export company with branches in 14 countries. He recently had a visit to one of his branches of his office in China. A week after his return. he noticed his leg getting swollen and reddening, there was no acute injury of any kind. Panicked by the whole situation, he rushed to the local emergency department the physician recorded his vitals listed as follows: His temperature is 97.2°F (36.3°C), blood pressure is 127/80 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination findings show the image A. The physician also ordered an ultrasound of the leg which is shown in the image B, which did not change when compressed. What would be the next best step?
questions.solution:
Figure A demonstrates what an initial physical exam of a patient with cellulitis may look like with mild erythema without well-defined borders. Figure B is an ultrasound demonstrating edema and cobble stoning which is suggestive of cellulitis.

This patient presents with erythema of his lower extremity with edema/cobblestoning without a fluid collection suggestive of cellulitis. Cellulitis is treated with oral antibiotics like cephalexin.

Cellulitis is characterized by inflammation of the skin and subcutaneous tissues in response to an acute infection. A breach in the skin is often the cause of the infection. Clinically, cellulitis presents as acute and progressive onset of a red, warm, and edematous area of skin. The diagnosis is made clinically. Ultrasound can show edema and cobblestoning. The treatment of cellulitis is an oral antibiotic that covers staphylococcus and streptococcus such as cephalexin.

Choice B : Heparin is indicated in the management of a DVT which presents with an observed clot in the vein and a non-compressible vein.

Choice C: Incision and drainage are indicated in the management of an abscess which would present with a tender/fluctuant mass and an ultrasound demonstrating a focal fluid collection.

Choice D & E: Piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin are broad-spectrum antibiotics which would be given in necrotizing fasciitis (in addition to surgical debridement) which presents with a red, hot, and inflamed rash with crepitus, fever, and a rapidly spreading/progressing condition.

Educational Objective:

Cellulitis is characterized by inflammation of the skin and subcutaneous tissues in response to an acute infection. A breach in the skin is often the cause of the infection.

questions.text: A 12-year-old male patient presents complaining of abdominal pain for 2 days and a rash on his buttocks and legs that appeared 3 days ago (see image below.) He also reports pain in his right ankle and his knee. He was seen in the clinic 2 weeks ago with symptoms of an upper respiratory infection, but his medical history is otherwise unremarkable. On physical examination, the patient's abdomen is tender to palpation, and he has multiple palpable purpuric lesions on his buttocks and upper thighs. His ankle is swollen and tender, but there is no warmth or erythema. The knee is tender, but otherwise his exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies reveal a normal complete blood count and microhematuria on urine dipstick. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

Palpable purpura on the buttocks and lower extremities, polyarthralgia (which often occurs in the hip, ankle, or knee joints), GI symptoms (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, intussusception, and ileus), and hematuria all point to a diagnosis of Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP).

For a diagnosis of HSP, the patient must demonstrate purpura or petechiae with lower limb predominance, without thrombocytopenia or coagulopathy plus one of following: abdominal pain, renal involvement, and leukocytoclastic vasculitis or proliferative glomerulonephritis with predominant IgA deposition.

HSP is a common immune complex vasculitis that occurs most often in children between the ages of 3 and 11. It is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection. Histopathologically, it is a leukocytoclastic angiitis that affects small blood vessels (arterioles and venules) in the skin or GI tract. It is characterized by C8 complement deposition and IgA deposition with predominant neutrophils and monocytes. Although the disorder is self-limited, it can result in acute glomerulonephritis with hematuria, as seen in this patient. Unlike other types of systemic vasculitis, it is not associated with thrombocytopenia or coagulopathy.

OTHER OPTIONS

OPTION A Child abuse

Although child abuse should always remain in the differential, it is often characterized by multiple injuries in various stages of healing. The patient's symptoms appeared within 2-3 days of each other. He also presented with purpura (not ecchymoses) during the physical examination, suggesting an underlying physiological reason for his symptoms.

OPTION C Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis can present with hematuria, and it often occurs after an infection of the skin or the pharynx with group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus. This patient had a previous URI, which could be caused by streptococcus. However, acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis does not present with arthralgias, abdominal pain, or purpura.

OPTION D Kawasaki disease Kawasaki disease most commonly occurs in Asian children under age 4 years. It is characterized by conjunctivitis, a fever for longer than 5 days, and strawberry tongue. Skin manifestations include hand and foot erythema and periungual desquamation, not palpable purpura.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

Palpable purpura on the buttocks and lower extremities, polyarthralgia (which often occurs in the hip, ankle, or knee joints), GI symptoms (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, intussusception, and ileus), and hematuria all point to a diagnosis of Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP)

questions.text: A 50 year old former javelin thrower is brought to the outpatient department with chronic pain in the shoulder. On history it’s revealed that he has suffered numerous ‘insignificant’ injuries to his throwing shoulder over the years but he never stopped the sport. On x rays of the shoulder, radiologist has defined a GOAT’S BEARD sign. What does this sign signify?
questions.solution:
Those with osteoarthritis reliably demon-strate subchondral sclerosis and a large osteophyte on the inferior aspect of the humeral head. This so-called “goat’s beard” is pathognomonic of advanced glenohumeral degeneration. These osteophytes can enlarge the humeral head to twice its normal size, resulting in capsular distention. Joint space narrowing, which is so reliably seen in hip and knee osteoarthritis, is not commonly seen in the shoulder until very late in the disease process owing to the non-weight-bearing position of the shoulder under standard radiography.

1 - Rotator cuff tears are seen on MRI and not x-rays

3 - GCT has a soap bubble appearance on x rays

4 - Osteosarcoma has a sunburst appearance on x-rays

5 - Posterior dislocation of shoulder has a light bulb appearance on x-rays

questions.text: Blake is a 20-year-old guy working as an animal caretaker at Brookfield zoo, Illinois. This morning he noticed a red and blistering rash on the back of his left calf after shower. He was late for work so he ignored the symptoms and continue doing this journey to work. During his afternoon lunch he experienced severe itching on the area and was unable to continue his work. He asked his colleague to accompany him to the hospital. He was taken to the emergency department of Morris Hospital & Healthcare Center. The consulting physician took a detailed history and recorded his vitals as follows : temperature is 97.7°F (36.5°C), blood pressure is 120/74 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He told the doctor that he never experienced this kind of symptoms before. The doctor did a physical examination which showed the following findings as seen in the image A. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image A demonstrates typical rash in a patient with a contact dermatitis with pruritic vesicles.

This patient is presents with pruritic and vesicular rash pointing to a diagnosis of contact dermatitis. Pathology will show spongiosis (intercellular edema in the epidermis) in acute contact dermatitis.

Contact dermatitis is a type IV (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction, occurring in a patient during contact with an allergen to which they have been previously sensitized. The antigen substance penetrate the skin, are phagocytized by Langerhans cells, and are carried to lymph nodes where they are presented to T lymphocytes. Repeat exposures, cause a reaction to appear in 24-48 hours. Pathological findings include mild spongiosis, intraepidermal vesicles/bullae, and necrosis of keratinocytes. The treatment involves topical steroids unless the face or a cosmetic region is affected. Oral steroids are prescribed in case of substantial skin involvement.

Incorrect Answers:

Choice A: Caseating granulomas are a classic presentation in tuberculosis and certain infections.

Choice B: Extra-epidermal vesicles with keratinocytes are not related with contact dermatitis; however, intraepidermal vesicles with keratinocytes are features of herpes virus infections.

Choice C: Langerhans giant cells are found in fungal infections, syphilis, sarcoidosis, leprosy, and tuberculosis.

Educational Objective: Contact dermatitis is a type IV (delayed) hypersensitivity reaction, occurring in a patient during contact with an allergen to which they have been previously sensitized. The treatment involves topical steroids unless the face or a cosmetic region is affected. Oral steroids are prescribed in case of substantial skin involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about below image :

choices.text: Fold of skin and conjunctiva turned inwards

questions.solution:
Epiblepharon comprises an extra horizontal fold of skin stretching across the anterior lid margin.
