  • It can be seen in hypertelorism and congenital epicanthus.
  • Since it is a congenital condition, it has no relation to trauma
  • fold of skin and conjunctiva turned inwards.
  • Usually resolves within the first few years of life.
  • Surgery indicated if it persists or there is significant corneal trauma due to the associated trichiasis. Surgery involves removal of the excess fold of skin

questions.text: A 70 year old man comes to the emergency department due to chest pain. Past medical history is of MI 2 weeks ago. He localizes the pain to the middle of the chest and says that he can only take shallow breaths because deep breaths make the pain worse. Leaning forward in his chair makes the pain somewhat better. He notes some associated neck pain and general malaise, but has not had any shortness of breath, palpitations, syncope or cough. He is afebrile temperature , blood pressure is 135/84 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. ECG shows ST segment elevations in all limb and precordial leads except in aVR, where ST depression is seen. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's chest pain characterstics (worse with deep inspiration, improved on leaning forward) and ECG findings (diffuse ST elevation wthreciprocal depression in AVR) are consistent with pericarditis. Given his recent hospitalisation, He most likely has post-cardiac injury syndrome (PCIS, Dressler syndrome), a pericarditis that can occur weeks after myocardial infarction (MI).

PCIS represents an immunologic response to damaged mesothelial pericardial calls and blood in the pericardial space Malaise and sometimes fever are also characteristic. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is typically elevated. High-dose nonsteroidal anti -inflammatory drugs(NSAIDs) are the mainstay of therapy (eg, aspirin 1000 mg or ibuprofen 800 mg every 6-8 hours)i they are usually given with colchicine (which is sometimes prescribed prophylactically in patients undergoing cardiac surgery), although data are limited. Anticoagulation should be avoided to prevent development of a hemorrhagic pencardial effusion. Corticosteroids can be used in refractory cases or when NSAIDs are contraindicated.

In contrast to PCIS, pehinfarct pericarditls usually develops within days (rather than weeks) of MI and is self-limited; if it develops, management generally includes avoidance of NSAIDs (other than aspirin) for 7-10 days.

OTHER OPTIONS

OPTION A Warfarin is used for long-term anticoagulation, and should probably be avoided in a patient with pericarditis to prevent the development of a hemorrhagic pencardial effusion.

OPTION C Nitroglycerin and beta b]ockers are treatments for M], but are not he]pfu] in the treatment of pericarditis.

OPTION D

Bread-spectrum antibiotics are not indicated for PCIS since it is caused by an immunologic abnormality and not infection.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE Post-cardiac injury syndrome (Dressler syndrome) presents weeks after a myocardial infarction with chest pain that is improved by leaning forward. Nonsteroidal anti-innammatory drugs are the treatment of choice and are usually administered with colchicine. Anticoagulation should be avoided to prevent development of a hemorrhagic pericardial effusion.

questions.text: From proximal (uterus) to distal (fimbria), the correct progression of fallopian tube anatomy is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Fallopian Tubes
These tubular extensions from the uterus vary in length from 8 to 14 cm, and each tube is divided into an interstitial portion, isthmus, ampulla, and infundibulum. The interstitial portion is embodied within the muscular wall of the uterus. The isthmus, or the narrow portion of the tube that adjoins the uterus, passes gradually into the wider, lateral portion, or ampulla. The infundibulum, or fimbriated extremity, is the funnel-shaped opening of the distal end of the fallopian tube . The fallopian tube varies considerably in thickness. The narrowest portion of the isthmus measures from 2 to 3 mm in diameter, and the widest portion of the ampulla measures from 5 to 8 mm. The fimbriated end of the infundibulum opens into the abdominal cavity.

questions.text: A teenage boy presents with High fever, sever unrelenting headache, sensitive to bright light and vomiting. On history taking revels that he had a tour with his classmates to Sahel region of West Africa he returned 3 days before. On the physical examination bradycardia, disorientation, papilledema, altered sensorium, neck stiffness, positive brudzinski's and kernig's sign are present. Physician is strongly doubt for pyogenic meningitis, which criteria is true about CSF finding in pyogenic meningitis.?
questions.solution:
Pyogenic meningitis is inflammation of meninges then affects pia matter, arachnoid, sub arachnoid space and spinal cord. pyogenic meningitis is a acute onset disease with serious infection and associates marked inflammatory exudation, usually caused by bacterial infection. pyogenic meningitis maybe fatal if untreatend. Early symptoms of meningitis include: nausea and vomiting, fever, headache and a stiff neck, muscle pain, sensitivity to light, confusion, cold hands or feet and mottled skin ,in some cases, a rash that does not fade under pressure. csf finding shows increased protien and decreased sugar. Protein leaks into the subarachnoid space from the blood, resulting in markedly increased CSF protein.

Educational objective:

Meningitis due to S. pneumoniae occurs most commonly in the very young and the very old.Several strains of bacteria can cause acute bacterial meningitis, most commonly: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus).This bacterium is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in infants, young children and adults

questions.text: A 43 year old male presents to the surgeon with his MRI of lower back. The sugeon asks the resident about the types of disc herniations. Which of the following is NOT a type of herniation of intervertebral disc?
questions.solution: Learning Objectives: Knowing the extent of disc herniations is important to the start of treatment. Small bulges can be managed conservatively while extrusions may need surgery.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to a prolonged cough. The patient started having rhinorrhea 5 weeks ago. A week later, she developed a cough with occasional expectoration of whitish sputum; the rhinorrhea resolved at that time. For the past 5 weeks, the patient's cough has continued throughout the day and night, occasionally awakening her and with no improvement. Her father tried using a humidifier, with no relief of her symptoms. The patient has been afebrile and has had no vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, or sick contacts. She takes no daily medications. Immunizations are up to date. The patient's mother has atopic dermatitis. Height and weight are at the 25th percentile Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F) and respirations are 24/min. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally; no retractions or use of accessory chest muscles are present Which of the following is the best next step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Chronic cough in children is defined as a cough lasting >28 days(4 weeks). Initial evaluation includes a detailed history and thorough physical examination to potentially identify a specific underlying cause. For example, poor growth may suggest a chronic illness (eg, cystic fibrosis (CF]), or peripheral edema may suggest cardiovascular disease.

In the absence of specific historical (eg, concomitant upper respiratory symptoms) or examination findings, initial evaluation begins with spirometry Spirometry is a simple pulmonary function test that can be performed in a cooperative child to detect obstructive airway disease (eg, asthma) Cough due to asthma may be associated with wheezing, shortness of breath, or a history of atopy, as in this child with a family history of atopic dermatitis. However, the sole finding in asthma can be isolated chronic cough with a normal lung examination.

The chest x-ray is also recommended for the evaluation of chronic cough It may help identify abnormalities such as mediastinal widening (eg, chronic infection, neoplasm), hyperinflation (eg, foreign body aspiration), or cardiac defects.

Choice A : CT scan of the chest in children is typically reserved to evaluate abnormal findings (eg, mass) found on less-invasive imaging (eg, x-ray) due to radiation exposure This child warrants imaging if spirometry is normal, but an x-ray is indicated first

Choice B : Pertussis can present with a chronic cough following the paroxysmal stage and classically presents with a 'whoop" in children age <10. Vaccinated children are less likely to develop pertussis and typically have a less severe illness. Pertussis testing could be considered if spirometry and imaging are normal.

Choice D : Sputum culture is obtained for patients with suspected active tuberculosis (TB). Although TB causes chronic cough, this patient has no risk factors (eg, high-risk travel, known contacts with TB) or other symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss) of TB.

Educational objective: Chronic cough (>4 weeks) without specific historical or examination findings warrants spirometry testing to identify underlying obstructive lung disease (eg, asthma).

questions.text: The dosage of vitamin A in keratomalacia in a 2 year old boy who is 12 kg weight is:-

choices.text: Vitamin A: 2 lakh in oral, 1st, 2nd, 14th day

questions.solution:
1. All patients above the age of 1 year (except women of reproductive age): 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU by intramuscular injection should be given immediately on diagnosis and repeated the following day and 4 weeks later.
  2. Children under the age of 1 year and children of any age who weigh less than 8 kg should be treated with half the doses for patients of more than 1 year of age. iii.Women of reproductive age, pregnant or not: (a) Those having night blindness (XN), conjunctival xerosis (X1A) and Bitot’s spots (X1B) should be treated with a daily dose of 10,000 IU of vitamin A orally (1 sugar coated tablet) for 2 weeks. (b) For corneal xerophthalmia, administration of full dosage schedule (described for patients above 1 year of age) is recommended.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old boy comes to the physician with a complaint of fever, decreased hearing, and painless foul-smelling discharge from his left ear. The patient was treated with antibiotics before but did not respond to antibiotic therapy. On physical examination, there is an enlargement of preauricular lymph nodes. From the otoscopic examination, the patient has shown multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane. A biopsy was done, showing pale granulation tissue. According to the given information, which of the following statements is correct about the given condition?


	Multiple perforations in tympanic membrane
	Pale granulation tissue is seen
	No extra auricular complications
	Painless condition
	Corticosteroids - The mainstay of treatment
questions.solution:
Option C: 1, 2, and 4 are correct

  • Multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane: This statement is correct. The patient has multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane, which is the thin membrane that separates the outer ear from the middle ear. The perforations can lead to hearing loss and the foul-smelling discharge observed in the case.

  • Pale granulation tissue is seen: This statement is correct. Granulation tissue is a type of healing tissue that forms in response to injury or infection. In this case, the granulation tissue observed on biopsy is pale, indicating that it is not as vascular or red as it would be in a typical inflammatory response.

  • No extra-auricular complications: This statement is correct. The information provided in the case does not mention any complications outside the ear. The patient's symptoms and findings seem to be localized to the ear and surrounding lymph nodes.

  • Painless condition: This statement is correct. The patient's condition is described as painless. This is important to note because ear infections or other ear-related conditions can often be associated with significant pain, but in this case, the patient does not report any pain.

Option A: Only 1, 2, and 3 are correct

  • This option is incorrect because, according to statement 3, no extra auricular complications are present in tubercular otitis media, which is a wrong statement.
  • The complications of tuberculous otitis media are fever, meningeal signs, headache, convulsions, loss of appetite, and focal neurological deficit.

Option B: Only 1, 2, 3, and 4 are correct

  • This option is incorrect because, according to statement 3, no extra auricular complications are present in tubercular otitis media, which is a wrong statement.

Option D: All are correct

  • This option is incorrect because, according to statement 3, no extra auricular complications are present in tubercular otitis media, which is a wrong statement.
  • According to statement 5, the mainstay of treatment of the tympanic membrane is a corticosteroid, which is wrong.
  • The tuberculous otitis media can be treated by systemic antituberculous therapy, aural toilet and control of secondary pyogenic infection, and mastoid surgery.

questions.text: A 45-year old woman presents to her primary care physician for the compliant of muscle weakness symmetrically. She says that she is experiencing difficulty in getting up from a chair, climbing the stairs and symptoms have progressively worsened over months .Her past medical examination is unremarkable and she is not taking any medications . On physical examination she is notable for muscle weakness in the deltoids and hip flexors .Biceps, triceps, patellar, and ankle tendon reflexes are around 2+. Laboratory testing demonstrates a creatine kinase level of 3,200 U/L (normal is 10-100 U/L), lactate dehydrogenase level of 160 U/L (normal is 45-90 U/L). Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the symptoms and laboratory it is evident that this is a case of polymyositis (PM).

Polymyositis is a progressive, systemic connective tissue disease characterized by immune-mediated striated muscle inflammation. with dermatomyositis, there can be associated heart, lung, and joint involvement as well as an increased risk of cancer. Creatine kinase levels are always elevated in uncontrolled Polymyositis.

Histologically, most often the patients have non-specific inflammatory cells present in perimysial more often than endomysial locations have been categorized as PM. A small minority of patients have mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate that surround fibers with sarcolemmal major histocompatibility (MHC-I) expression.

The inflammatory infiltrate predominatly consists of CD8+ T cells and macrophages located in the endomysial, perimysial and perivascular regions.

The best initial treatment is high-dose corticosteroids with taper after 4–6 weeks to decrease the maintenance dose.

Choice A : Bevacizumab is a immuno therapeutic agent which is used in cancer. This patient does not have any symptoms of cancer .It does not play a role in Polymyosistis.

Choice B : Physostigmine is indicated for the treatment of patients with myasthenia gravis who also presents with weakness. But this patient has no other symptoms such as ptosis and diplopia .

Choice C : Intravenous immunoglobin is used for the treatment of Guillain-Barre syndrome which also presents with distal weakness . But it is usually precedes by the respiratory infection or gastrointestinal infection a few weeks prior to the development of weakness.

Choice D : Azathioprine and/or methotrexate can be used only in the patients with steroid-resistant or intolerant polymyositis.

Objective learning : Initial treatment for polymyositis is with systemic glucocorticoids, such as prednisone.

questions.text: Amy is a 50-year-old female who works as a cleaner in a cafe. While she was on her work she suddenly started feeling unwell. She had an episode of nausea followed by vomiting. Despite her symptoms she continued to work. But the nausea and vomiting repeated and her condition became worse. She had severe retrosternal pain. She was taken to the hospital 2 hours after her symptoms began. A CT scan was performed and extraluminal gas was found in the mediastinum. What could be the possible diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Boerhaave syndrome is caused by repeated vomiting and retching (e.g., as a result of high alcohol intake). Increase in intrathoracic pressure results in elevated intraesophageal pressure which leads to full-thickness rupture of the esophageal wall.

Incorrect answers :

Option A : Pulmonary embolism can cause sudden-onset, severe chest pain . But other manifestations like dyspnea, cough, tachycardia, and hypotension will also be present. CT imaging (helical spiral CT/CT pulmonary angiography) usually shows an intraluminal filling defect of the pulmonary arteries; the presence of a wedge-shaped infarction with pleural effusion is a specific finding.

Option C : Acute myocardial infarction can also cause nausea, vomiting, and retrosternal pain. CT imaging (e.g., coronary CT angiography) can show atherosclerotic plaques and coronary artery stenosis.

Option D : Aortic dissection can cause retrosternal pain that radiates to the back. Patients usually have a history of hypertension and presents with severely elevated blood pressure (or hypotension in cases of shock and/or cardiac tamponade). Other manifestations include asymmetrical blood pressure readings between the arms and syncope. CT scan of patients with aortic dissection usually shows an intimal flap that separates a true and false lumen.

Educational objective : excessive vomiting and retching leads to boerhaave syndrome which is the full thickness rupture of the esophageal wall due to due to increased intracranial thoracic pressure leading to elevated pressure in the esophagus. Patients experience symptoms like severe retrosternl pain that radiates to the back.

questions.text: Eiza is a 5 year old healthy girl. After her birth she never had any health issues other than viral fever and common cold a couple of times. Recently her mother rushed to the emergency department of the hospital at night with Eiza. Eiza was having rectal bleeding in the past 24 hours and was dizzy. She experienced no other gastrointestinal symptoms. She looked pale on examination. Her heart rate was 175 beats per minute. She was having a 20mmhg postural drop in systolic blood pressure. On examination of the abdomen, it was non distended and non tender. Fresh blood and clots were observed in the rectal vault on rectal examination . What Could be the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Hemorrhage due to Meckel’s diverticulum usually presents with painless rectal bleeding in the absence of other gastrointestinal symptoms. The hemorrhage sometimes is enough to cause hypovolemia, pallor, tachycardia, and postural hypotension.

incorrect answers :

A. An anal fissure can cause bleeding but the amount will be so limited that it is usually seen only on the surface of the stool.

B. Hemorrhoids can also cause bleeding but in little amounts.

C. Bleeding due to intussusception is usually secondary to mucosal ischemia of the lead point. It is usually described as ‘current jelly’ bleeding.

Educational objective : Hemorrhage due to Meckel’s diverticulum usually presents with painless rectal bleeding in the absence of other gastrointestinal symptoms. The hemorrhage sometimes is enough to cause hypovolemia, pallor, tachycardia, and postural hypotension.

questions.text: G2P1L1, Diabetic pregnant lady with 32 weeks pregnancy,blood sugars are well controlled on insulin and the on USG the fetal weight is 3.11 kg. The previous pregnancy was terminated by emergency LSCS for fetal distress. The best plan of action is :
questions.solution:
Diabetes on insulin will generally come in the category of Paragraph 2 of this guidelines

In this question the lady is a case of previous 1 LSCS and has a fetus of 3.1 kgs at 32 weeks, and hence she is likely to have a macrosomic baby, the best plan of action would be an planned elective repeat CS at 38 weeks.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician's office complaining of anxiety and a recent 4.5-kg (9.9-lb) weight loss. Her physical examination exophthalmos and pretibial myxedema. Thyroid gland is diffusely palpable. Laboratory studies show a serum TSH of 2.00 mU/L, serum total thyroxine(T 4) of 15 g/dl, and free T 4 of 6 ng/dl.
The drug of choice for this disorder acts at what step in thyroid hormone synthesis?

choices.text: Active absorption of iodide from the blood
Proteolysis of colloid to release thyroxine and triiodothyronine

questions.solution:
This patient has Graves disease, an autoimmune disorder resulting from the presence of elevated levels of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI), an IgG that binds to and stimulates the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor of the thyroid gland. This causes a hyperthyroid state. Graves disease is associated with the HLA-DR3 subtype. The three basic findings associated with Graves disease are hyperthyroidism, ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos), and dermopathy/ pretibial myxedema. Anti thyroid drugs like Propylthiouracil and methimazole are used to treat hyperthyroidism. They work by blocking organification and coupling. PTU also blocks peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

Incorrect Options

PTU does not affect iodide trapping. (A)

Lithium has been shown to reduce thyroid hormone release by decreasing colloid formation through decreased pinocytosis. Hypothyroidism is a major adverse effect of long-term lithium use. (B)

Iodide cleaves Colloid by proteases to release thyroxine and triiodothyronine. It is not commonly used as a first-line treatment.(C)

TSH regulates many steps in the synthesis of thyroid hormone and is released from the anterior pituitary gland. Due to negative feedback, one would expect to see a low serum TSH level in this patient. Thus, blocking this step would not help a patient with Graves disease. (D)

Educational Objective

In Grave disease, propylthiouracil works by blocking tyrosine iodination and coupling and decreasing peripheral conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with left lower abdominal pain.She has noted recent enlargement of her breasts. Her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago. She denies having had sexual intercourse. Serum levels of hCG are markedly elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
(a) Choriocarcinoma
Sol:
- Choriocarcinoma of the ovary is a rare tumor that mimics the epithelial covering of placental villi (cytotrophoblast andsyncytiotrophoblast).
- Choriocarcinoma of germ cell origin manifests in young girls as precocious sexual development, menstrual irregularities, and rapid breast enlargement.
- In women of reproductive age, ovarian choriocarcinoma may represent metastasis from an intrauterine gestational tumor.
- Microscopically, it displays an admixture of malignant cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast.
- The syncytial cells of choriocarcinoma secrete hCG, which accounts for the frequent fi nding of a positive pregnancy test result.
- The tumor is highly aggressive but responds to chemotherapy.
- Hydatidiform mole secretes hCG but is a gestational trophoblastic disease.

questions.text: A 24 year old woman had a history of spontaneous abortion at 7 weeks gestation. The patient now complains that she has not yet had her periods since the abortion. Ultrasound is normal and pregnancy test is negative. FSH 6 IU/l. Which of the following may be a cause:
questions.solution:
Option D : Uterine synechiae, called Asherman syndrome, do cause amenorrhea mostly after an ‘Over zealous” curettage but even a spontaneous abortion can cause a post abortal endometritis which may lead to healing of the endometrium with scarring and fibrosis. Thus causing secondary amenorrhea. Here FSH levels are not high as ovaries are functioning normally, producing normal estrogen, causing normal feedback inhibition of FSH.

Option A : Ovarian Failure is when the FSH is 40 IU/L or more. Here since ovaries are not functioning normally, there is no estrogen to cause feedback inhibition of FSH, hence FSH is high.

Option B : Pituitary failure has FSH values lesser than 1 IU/L as FSH is made from pituitary

Option C : Since she came after an abortion, UPT is negative, then an ongoing pregnancy is ruled out.

questions.text: Which of the followings are contraindications of non invasive(NIV) positive pressure ventilation
questions.solution:
Indications and contraindications of NIV in adults

Indications: at least 2 of the following factors

  • RR >25 /min
  • pH 7.25-7.30 or paCO2 45-60 mm hg
  • Moderate to sev dyspnea with use of accessory muscles and paradoxical breathing pattern

Contraindication (absolute)

  • Respiratory arrest
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Unstable cardiovascular
  • Non respiratory organ failures
  • Patent tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Inability to protect the airway or high risk of aspiration
  • Uncooperative patient
  • Facial or head surgery

Relative contraindication

  • Copious or viscous secretions
  • Fixed nasopharyngeal abnormalities
  • Extreme obesity

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was involved in an road traffic accident when the motorcycle is slipped on broken pavement and he hit a parked truck. Patient was rushed to emergency, he is diagnosed to have multiple rib fractures, a right femur fracture, and left radio-ulnar fractures. While being managed in the emergency , he is found to have episodes of supraventricular tachycardia each lasting approximately 3minutes that resolved spontaneously. Which of the following is the most likely etiology for this rhythm abnormality?
questions.solution:
This man has multiple injuries secondary to road traffic accident. With the injuries like multiple rib fractures he has sustained and description of its mechanism, the period of supraventricular arrhythmia is likely due to blunt cardiac injury

Option B Fat embolism is not often associated with any specific cardiac rhythm abnormalities.

Option D Caffeine can cause some arrythmias but the SVT should not be attributed to that given the significant injuries that this patient has.

Bottom line Blunt cardiac injuries are suspected when patients develop supraventricular arrythmias especially when it is associated with multiple rib fractures after significant trauma to chest.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with complaints of dyspnoea and productive cough with a postural variation. The patient gives a history of 20 pack-years of smoking. The Patient also has a history of recent binge drinking. A chest X-ray was taken and is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
For patients with a lung abscess and a low likelihood of malignancy (e.g., smokers <45 years old) and with risk factors for aspiration, it is reasonable to administer empirical treatment with clindamycin.

INCORRECT OPTION

OPTION B In patients with risk factors for malignancy or other underlying conditions (especially immunocompromised hosts) or with an atypical presentation, earlier diagnostics should be considered, such as bronchoscopy with biopsy or CT-guided needle aspiration. Bronchoscopy should be performed early in patients whose history, symptoms, or imaging findings are consistent with possible bronchial obstruction.

OPTION C Gemcitabine and Paclitaxel should be given only after confirmation of Lung Carcinoma in a patient.

OPTION D In patients from areas endemic for tuberculosis or patients with other risk factors for tuberculosis (e.g., underlying HIV infection), induced sputum samples should be examined before considering ATT.

Educational objective For a lung abscess and a low likelihood of malignancy (e.g., smokers <45 years old) and with risk factors for aspiration, it is reasonable to administer empirical treatment with clindamycin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old G3P3 with a Pap smear showing high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion of the cervix (CIN III) has an inadequate colposcopy. Cone biopsy shows squamous cell cancer that has invaded only 1 mm beyond the basement membrane. There are no confluent tongues of tumor and there is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. The margins of the cone biopsy specimen are free of disease. How would you classify or stage this patient’s disease?

choices.text: Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance

questions.solution:
• Microinvasive carcinoma of the cervix includes lesions within 3 mm of the base of the epithelium, with no confluent tongues or lymphatic or vascular invasion.
  • The overall incidence of metastases in 751 reported cases is 1.2%. Simple hysterectomy is accepted therapy.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a routine physical examination. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), her pulse is 74/min, her respirations are 14/min, and her blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals six light brown skin macules and patches measuring up to 3 cm in diameter, dispersed on the torso. Small, firm masses are also felt in the hypodermis below the two macules. These masses are most likely to be closely associated with which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The underlying mass lesions are seemingly peripheral nerve tumors (neurofibromas). The skin lesions described are café-au-lait spots, which present as flat, uniformly pigmented macules and patches. Isolated café-au-lait spots are common inside the overall population, but the presence of five spots is extremely implication of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). NF1 is an autosomal dominant inherited syndrome by Mendelian inheritance resultant from a mutation of the NF1 gene on chromosome 17.

Features of NF1 are often: Café-au-lait spots, Axillary Freckling, "Eye" (Lisch) nodules, Scoliosis, Pheochromocytoma, and Optic "Tumor" (glioma).

Incorrect Options:

Adipose tissue (choice A) can produce lipomas. They present as circumscribed, soft subcutaneous mass lesions, but the occurrence of café-au-lait spots makes this diagnosis less relevant.

The arrector pili (choice B) are the tiny muscles of the follicle that produce the sensation of “goosebumps." it's believed that some leiomyomas of the skin may rise from these tiny muscles.

Skeletal muscle (choice D) can result in rhabdomyosarcoma. Although, these lesions usually occur asonelesion without change in pigmentation, and occur in deep tissues and organs (heart ventricles, bladder, vagina).

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE: café-au-lait spots, which present as flat, uniformly pigmented* macules* and patches and quite five spots are extremely implicational of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). NF1 is an autosomal dominant inherited syndrome mutation of the NF1 gene on chromosome 17. Features of NF1 are Café-au-lait spots, Axillary Freckling, "Eye" (Lisch) nodules, Scoliosis, Pheochromocytoma, and Optic "Tumor" (glioma).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man with 20 pack-year history of smoking presents to the physician's office with a complaint of hoarseness of voice for the past few months. On laryngeal examination, there was an outgrowth covering the vocal cords bilaterally, and the biopsy sample was taken. He was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma of stage T4a and subsequently underwent a total laryngectomy. Which of the following statements are true about total laryngectomy?

1. Usually done for carcinoma larynx

2. Speech difficulty present

3. High tracheostomy is done in total laryngectomy

4. After total laryngectomy, the patient presents with dysphagia
questions.solution:
Option B: 1, 2, 3 and 4 are correct  

This man presents a complaint of hoarseness of voice and a 20-pack-year smoking history with a biopsy of the laryngeal lesion showing stage T4a laryngeal carcinoma. The most appropriate treatment is total laryngectomy.

  • Total laryngectomy involves the removal of the entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more trachea rings. The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the lower tracheal stump is sutured to the skin for breathing.
  • Total laryngectomy with or without post-operative radiotherapy offers the best chances for a cure for carcinoma larynx.
  • It is associated with a significant reduction in quality of life and functional sequela:
    • Loss of normal speech quality and quantity
    • Loss of airway protection, ineffective coughing, and inability to strain.
    • Loss of nasal air conditioning, sense of taste and smell, normal nasal homeostasis, and immunity.
    • Defective swallowing
    • Psychological problems due to Body image issues with the stoma
    • A high tracheostomy is done and following laryngectomy, the patient breathes through the permanent tracheostomy (so loss of smell).
  • Therefore, it is reserved for advanced T4a stage tumors or in cases of locally recurrent disease after radiation treatment.

Option A: Only 1, 2, and 3 are correct.

  • As it involves high tracheostomy and speech difficulty, total laryngectomy is only done for laryngeal carcinoma. Also the patients present with dysphagia due to loss of pharyngeal constrictors.

Option C: Only 1, 2, and 4 are correct.

  • A high tracheostomy is done, which is permanent as well as loss of pharyngeal constrictors which leads to dysphagia; therefore, it is only done for laryngeal carcinoma.

Option D: Only 1 and 4 are correct.

  • It is usually done for laryngeal carcinoma as it can result in complications such dysphagia due to loss of pharyngeal constrictors and therefore not used for early stages.

questions.text: A 20 year old female was brought to the emergency bay for severe headache and fever associated with vomiting. She had sinusitis few days ago. No consultation done. No meds taken. Physical examination revealed nuchal rigidity. MRI done (given below). The abnormal finding/s is most probably is seen in which of the following ?
questions.solution:
The abnormal finding in the given image is Pott’s puffy tumor and is associated with subdural empyema. Subdural empyema refers to an infective collection in the subdural space. This may result as a result of sinusitis, mastoiditis or meningitis, and can complicate trauma or surgery. In empyema, pus will generally collect in the parafalcine region and over the convexity, triggering inflammation and thrombosis in the cortical veins, which helps to explain the high mortality of 8-12%. Presentation mimics that of meningitis and cerebral abscess;, typical CT appearances are of hypodense or isodense subdural collection, with contrast enhancement at the margins and a degree of swelling and midline shift. The empyema may be difficult to visualise especially on non-contrast CT. LP should not be performed given the risk of herniation. Craniotomy or craniectomy allows drainage of the collection and relieves raised intra cranial pressure and is the treatment of choice. Burrhole drainage, and occasionally IV antibiotics without surgical intervention, may also be considered.

Choice A : meningitis. It describes inflammation of the meninges of the brain and spinal cord, most commonly and most seriously due to bacterial infection. The clinical features of meningeal irritation or meningism are fever, headache, neck stiffness and photophobia.

Choice B : brain abscess and empyema. Abscesses arise when the brain is exposed directly, for example as a result of fracture of infection of an air sinus, or at surgery. They also result from hematogenous spread, typically in association with respiratory and dental infections, or endocarditis.

Choice D : tuberculous meningitis. Tuberculosis infection of the central nervous system represents hematogenous spread from primary pulmonary foci. Tuberculous meningitis commonly affects young children, CT demonstrates intense meningeal enhancement and hydrocephalus is a common sequela.

Learning objective Subdural empyema presenting features are similar to those of meningitis (fever, headache, neck stiffness and photophobia) or cerebral abscess. Typically a cresenteric collection with a contrast enhancing rim is evident on CT. Drainage is the main stay of treatment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive muscle weakness that is more prominent in his legs. There are no alleviating or exacerbating factors. He has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, gout, and asthma. Current medications include simvastatin, colchicine, metoprolol, and prednisone. He has had no changes in his medication for 2 years. Examination shows muscle atrophy of his quadriceps. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the proximal lower extremities, 5/5 in the distal lower extremities, and 5/5 in the upper extremities. Laboratory studies show CK 80 mU/mL (normal, 25–145 mU/mL). An EMG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient's prolonged use of steroids along with muscle weakness that is more prominent in his lower extremities is suggestive of corticosteroid induced myopathy. Patients with this condition present with progressive proximal muscle weakness followed by atrophy after weeks to months of corticosteroid therapy. Muscle enzymes (CK) and EMG are usually normal, however, the latter can show low amplitude motor unit action potentials. Management is a dose reduction or complete taper of corticosteroid therapy, which usually results in full resolution of weakness.

Causes of Myopathy in Adults

Corticosteroid-induced myopathy

  • Progressive proximal muscle weakness followed by atrophy after weeks to months of corticosteroid therapy
  • Lower extremities are affected early
  • Normal ESR and CK

Statin-induced myopathy

  • Marked muscle pain that can be accompanied by muscle weakness. It can rarely present with rhabdomyolysis.
  • Normal ESR and increased CK

Inflammatory myopathies (dermatomyositis, polymyositis, inclusion body myositis)

  • Proximal muscle weakness with muscle pain and tenderness
  • Patients can have associated dermatological (skin rash) and joint pathologies
  • increased ESR and increased CK

Polymyalgia rheumatica

  • Pain and stiffness in proximal muscles without weakness, along with constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss)
  • It is associated with giant cell (temporal) arteritis
  • increased ESR and normal CK

Hypothyroid myopathy

  • Proximal muscle weakness and muscle pain
  • Delayed deep tendon reflexes and myoedema
  • Patients have other classical features of hypothyroidism (weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation) Ø Normal ESR and CK

OTHER OPTIONS

OPTION A

Acetylcholine receptor antibody assay Corticosteroid-induced myopathy does not usually cause an increase in muscle enzymes, and the EMG is normal.

OPTION B

Increase the dose of prednisone will lead to worsening of patients condition.

OPTION C

Muscle biopsy is usually not indicated in drug induced myopathy.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

Drug-induced myopathy should be considered in a patient who presents with muscle weakness and who is receiving statins, corticosteroids, and other immunosuppressants. Corticosteroid-induced myopathy does not usually cause an increase in muscle enzymes, and the EMG is normal. Diagnosis of steroid-induced myopathy is confirmed with improvement in muscle strength 3 to 4 weeks after decreasing the dose of steroid medications.

questions.text: A 4.5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to snoring. For the past 6 months, his mother regularly heard loud snoring at night time, with pauses in between his breathing which is followed by gasping for air. history suggests 2 episodes of otitis media in the past that resolved with antibiotic therapy. The boy is up to date with vaccinations as per schedule. His father is a regular smoker and smokes outdoor. his family has a cat which roms in house. The height of the boy is at the 40th percentile and his weight is at the 15th percentile of reference. On examination, the patient appears normal. Oral examination reveals good dentition and tonsillar hypertrophy. The lungs appear clear on auscultation and heart sounds are normally heard. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Removal of the cat from home

questions.solution:
Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea
Pathophysiology
  • Aden tonsillar hypertrophy
Clinical manifestations
  • Night symptoms
    • Loud snoring, pauses in breathing, gasping
    • Enuresis parasomnias (e.g. Sleepwalking, sleep terrors)
  • Day symptoms
    • Inappropriate naps or falling asleep during school
    • Irritability, inattention, learning problems, behavioral problem
    • Mouth breathing, nasal speech
Complications
  • Poor growth (i.e. failure to thrive)
  • Poor school performance
  • Cardiopulmonary (e.g., hypertension, structural heart changes)
Management
  • Tonsillectomy & adenoidectomy

This child with the complaints of loud snoring along with pauses in breathing, and gasping for breath during sleep most likely has been suffering from obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

OSA in kids is a sleep disorder that results in episodic upper airway obstruction and difficulty breathing along with disrupted sleep. This often manifests as restless sleep, loud snoring, periods of apnea, and gasping for breath at night. Other symptoms of OSA may include enuresis and parasomnias. In adults, obesity is associated with OSA, so weight loss is typically recommended. In contrast, young children with OSA are underweight, and many times severe cases result in failure to thrive of the patient. It is seen that, In these patients, adenoid hypertrophy contributes to a substantial narrowing of the upper airway, causing an intermittent obstruction. Therefore, tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy are first-line management for pediatric OSA.

Choice A : Recurrent infections early in life might contribute to adenoid hypertrophy, but this child has not shown any symptoms of a bacterial infection that would require the course of antibiotics. Though antibiotics occasionally decrease tonsil size, they would not result in permanent improvement in the OSA.

Choices Band C : Changing sleep position and continuous positive airway pressure is recommended as therapy for OSA in adults. In young children, adenotonsillectomy is often beneficial, removing the need for an intervention that is unlikely to be successful due to significant difficulty with its adherence at such a young age.

Choice D : Some cases of children with OSA benefit from evading environmental allergens (eg, cat) or irritants (eg, tobacco smoke), but it doesn't resolve OSA symptoms alone. So, this is recommended as an additional, rather than initial, therapy.

Educational objective: In contrast to the treatment for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in adults, first-line therapy for OSA in children is tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy

questions.text: Which of following is not true about hereditary spherocytosis?

choices.text: It occurs due to due to defect in proteins interacting with RBC membrane skeleton and plasma membrane (eg, ankyrin, band 3, protein 4.2, spectrin).
It is characterized by small, round RBCs with less surface area and no central pallor (elevated MCHC).
Osmotic fragility test is negative in hereditary spherocytosis.

questions.solution:
INCORRECT ANSWERS

All the other statements are true about hereditary spherocytosis.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE: Hereditary spherocytosis occurs due to due to defect in proteins interacting with RBC membrane skeleton and plasma membrane (eg, ankyrin, band 3, protein 4.2, spectrin). It is mostly inherited in a autosomal dominant manner. It is characterized by small, round RBCs with less surface area and no central pallor (elevated MCHC). Osmotic fragility test is positive in hereditary spherocytosis.

questions.text: 67 year old Anny was diagnosed with gastric cancer 4 months ago and underwent distal gastrectomy a month ago. The surgery was succesful and there was no post operative complications . 2 weeks after the surgery Anny experienced diarrhea and weakness after her meals. After every meal she had the urge to defecate. She couldn't hold no longer than 20 minutes after every meal. She went to the physician to raise the issue . She had 3-6 bowel movements per day. this is the situation for the last 2 weeks. She feels tired after every meal and often experience palpitations and sweating after the meal. Her immunizations are upto date . She didn't travel to any place recently. Her vital are all normal. On examination, abdominal midline surgical scar is well healed. Abdomen is soft and non-tender. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. Rectal examination is unrevealing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management ?
questions.solution:
In a patient who has undergone a distal gastrectomy, symptoms like diarrhea, urge to defecate, weakness, sweating and palpitations soon after eating is suggestive of early dumping syndrome. Treatment for early dumping syndrome is dietary modifications.

Incorrect answers :

Option A : stool microscopy is done to diagnose parasitic infection which is a potential cause of diarrhea particularly in patients returning from travels abroad. In this case patient didn't travel abroad recently.

Option B : roux-en-y reconstruction surgery is a late option for dumping syndromes refractory to conservative and medical management.

Option C : octreotide is a medication used to dicrease the motility of intestine and delay gastric emptying which is useful in severe dumping and post vagotomy syndromes.

Educational objective : dumping syndrome is the rapid emptying of the food into the small intestine usually seen after surgery like distal gastrectomy. In early dumping syndrome, the treatment involves frequent small carbohydrate meals.

questions.text: The image shows the uterine sutures in a woman with PPH. Identify.
questions.solution:
Option A: B-Lynch suture

  • B-Lynch suture
  • Two sutures are applied longitudinal, which look like a "brace-suspender,"
  • The b-Lynch suture is referred to as the "brace suture."

Option B: Hayman suture

  • Hayman procedure is considered a uterine compression suture using two longitudinal threads and transfixing the entire uterine wall.
  • This suture is simpler than the B-Lynch suture, sometimes called the "simple brace."

Option C: Cho suture

  • Also called 'multiple square sutures.'
  • In an atonic uterus, four to five square sutures should be made.
  • If the bleeding point is evident, suturing should be performed to compress the bleeding site

Option D: Arterial embolization

  • Arterial embolization is done through interventions such as radiological guidance, and the artery is blocked with an embolizing agent.

questions.text: Imprinting of the fetus in the diabetic mother suggests that exposure to hyperglycemia leads to hyperinsulinemia, causing an increase in which fetal cell type and leading to obesity and insulin resistance in childhood?
questions.solution: In utero exposure to maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperinsulinemia, causing an increase in fetal fat cells, which leads to obesity and insulin resistance in childhood . This in turn leads to impaired glucose tolerance and diabetes in adulthood.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of falls and trauma to the head is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state; a CT scan shows "EDH," and he undergoes a decompressive craniotomy. He was shifted to ICU for elective postoperative ventilation. The patient was sedated and paralyzed with infusions of propofol, midazolam, and Injection vecuronium. On 3rd day, his Blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse rate is 48/minute, and SpO2 is 96% at room air. Blood investigations showed Hb-13g/dl, blood urea-80 mg/dl, serum creatinine is 3 mg/dl, PH-7.15, PO2-200 mmHg, PCO2-20 mmHg, HCO3--15 mmol/l, Na+ 140 mEq/l, K+ 5.8 mEq/l, blood cholesterol-350 mg/dl, triglycerides are 300 mg/dl. Ultrasonography Abdomen revealed hepatomegaly. Chest X-ray is normal. The most probable diagnosis will be?
questions.solution:
Option B: Propofol infusion syndrome

  • According to the above scenario, there is metabolic acidosis, and potassium and sodium are also mildly deranged. Hence the suitable answer is propofol infusion syndrome (PRIS) because it causes unexplained metabolic acidosis, arrhythmias, acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, and cardiovascular collapse.
  • Propofol infusion syndrome is a rare but lethal syndrome seen when the dose of propofol infusion is greater than 4 mg/kg/hour or more for 48 hours or longer.
  • This syndrome is common in children and critically ill adults.
  • Clinical features include acute refractory bradycardia leading to asystole in the presence of one or more of the following:
    • Metabolic acidosis (base deficit >10 mmol/L)
    • Rhabdomyolysis
    • Hyperlipidemia
    • Enlarged or fatty liver
  • Other features include cardiomyopathy with acute cardiac failure, skeletal myopathy, hyperkalemia, hepatomegaly, and lipemia.
  • The symptoms and signs are the results of muscle injury and the release of intracellular toxic contents.
  • Lipemia is a sign as increasing lipemia was the first indication of propofol infusion syndrome. It is due to defects in mitochondrial metabolism and electron transport chain function.
  • Poor oxygen delivery, sepsis, serious cerebral injury, and large propofol dosage are the major risk factors.

Option A: Critical illness polyneuropathy/myopathy

  • This disease is characterized by more proximal than distal weakness, sensory preservation, and atrophy.

Option C: Hepatic encephalopathy

  • Hepatic encephalopathy is a nervous system disorder brought on by the severe liver disease.
  • When the liver is damaged, toxins build up in the blood. These toxins travel to the brain and affect brain function.

Option D: Central pontine myelinolysis

  • It is a neurological disorder that most frequently occurs after too rapid medical correction of sodium deficiency (hyponatremia).
  • Symptoms include confusion, delirium, slurred speech and weakness of muscles.

questions.text: In a 40-year-old male undergoing total thyroidectomy, induction with Inj. Thiopentone sodium and intubation facilitated with the Injection of succinylcholine are planned. Which type of endotracheal tube cuff will be used to prevent tracheal mucosal injury?
questions.solution:
Option A: Low pressure – high volume

  • In the case discussed above, the patient is posted for total thyroidectomy.
  • Total thyroidectomy: It is a delicate procedure in which there could be damage to the trachea, so the low-volume and high-pressure cuffs are suitable while doing the procedure.
  • Low pressure – high volume type cuffs have a comparatively large volume and consequently large contact areas between the cuff and trachea.
  • The advantage of a high-volume, low-pressure cuff is the lesser incidence of tracheal mucosal damage as the intracuff pressure closely approximates pressure on the tracheal wall, provided the cuff wall is not stretched. With proper use, cuff-induced complications of prolonged intubation are reduced.
  • Disadvantages of high-volume, low-pressure cuffs include:
    • Sore throat (due to larger mucosal contact area).
    • Aspiration (it may not prevent fluid leakage into the lower airway even at cuff pressures as high as 60 cm H2O).
    • Unplanned extubation.
    • Difficulty insertion (the floppy cuff may obscure the view of the tube tip and larynx).

Option B: High pressure – low volume

  • Advantages:
    • Better protection against aspiration.
    • Better visibility during intubation.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Damage to the tracheal mucosal wall on prolonged intubation (as the pressure exerted on the tracheal wall is above the mucosal perfusion pressure).
    • It is controversial for use in short-duration procedures, and if the surgery is expected to last for a few hours or must be in place following surgery, low-pressure cuffed tubes should be used.

Option C: Variable pressure – low volume

  • Low-volume cuffs with variable pressures are not indicated.
  • With variable pressures of the cuff, there is a high risk of tracheal mucosal damage, which can exert pressure on the tracheal wall.

Option D: Low pressure – low volume

  • Low-pressure and low-volume cuffs are not safe to use in thyroidectomy or any other tracheal surgery.
  • There is a potential risk of tracheal mucosal damage and difficulty in insertion.

questions.text: A doctor is planning on a volar approach to the distal radius for surgery. The approach involves the retraction of radial artery. The patient has been a smoker all his life and the surgeon is concerned about radial and ulnar artery thrombosis and patency. Which of the following tests will the surgeon perform?
questions.solution:
Lachman test for ACL rupture detection.

Adson test for thoracic outlet syndrome detection.

Learning objective: Allen test is important for vascular examination specially in surgeries involving the arteries or surgeries involving mobilization of the arteries.

questions.text: Which type of cervical lesion cannot be detected using visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA)?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cervical polyps

  • A cervical polyp is a common benign tumour on the surface of the cervical canal, with tissues like the smooth muscle cells seen in a fibroid.
  • The polyp does not pick up active staining with acetic acid because it has mostly 'resting' cells.
  • Acetic acid is used to coagulate the proteins → make the area acetowhite.

Acetic acid staining of the cervix shows

  • Cervical carcinoma in situ.
  • Cervical dysplasia.
  • Squamous metaplasia.

Option A: Squamous metaplasia

  • Squamous metaplasia can be seen on VIA
  • Squamous Atypia
    • ASC-H.
    • ASC-US.
    • Squamous atypia/benign with inflammation.
  • Mild dysplasiaLSIL (Low grade squamous inter epithelial lesion)
    • CIN I (including HPV).
  • Severe dysplasia, moderate dysplasia, and carcinoma in situ are all HSIL (High grade squamous inter epithelial lesion):
    • CIN (cervical intraepithelial neoplasia) II
    • CIN (cervical intraepithelial neoplasia) III
  • Invasive cancer
    • Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
    • Glandular cells
    • Atypical glandular cells (AGC)
    • CIN I/CIN II/CIN III

Option B: Cervical carcinoma CIN (cervical intraepithelial neoplasia) in situ

  • CIN carcinoma in situ (CIS) is a term for early-stage cancer.
  • It is also referred to as stage 0 cervical cancer.
  • It's non-invasive, which means that the cancerous cells are confined to the surface of your cervix and haven't penetrated more deeply into the tissues.

Option D: Cervical dysplasia

  • It is the abnormal growth of cells on the surface of the cervix.
  • It is considered a precancerous condition.
  • A sexually transmitted infection caused by common human papillomavirus (HPV).

questions.text: 4 week old Dimitri was bought to the hospital because of a progressive non bilious emesis for the past 1 week. Since last day, his urine output has significantly reduced. Dimitri is active and eager to feed. The pediatrician did a detailed examination on the infant and found that he has a sunken Fontanelle ,decreased skin turgor and a scaphoid abdomen. A test feed was done and visible peristaltic waves were found in the epigastrium. What could be the possible cause of the findings on Dimitri ?
questions.solution:
Pyloric stenosis patients usually presents after the third week of life with symptoms of progressive pyloric outlet obstruction secondary to increasing hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle. clinical signs of dehydration are often present, but the infant usually appears well and is eager to feed.

Incorrect answers :

A. Urinary tract sepsis : patients with urinary tract sepsis usually presents with systemic illness lethargy, poor feeding and in some cases , fever.

C. Milk protein allergy is associated with symptoms like diarrhea and colicky abdominal pain.

D. Viral gastroenteritis is also associated with symptoms like lethargy, poor feeding and fever.

Educational objective : pyloric stenosis patients usually presents with symptoms of progressive pyloric outlet obstruction secondary to increasing hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle. Presentations are usually after 3rd week of life. clinical signs of dehydration are often present, but the infant usually appears well and is eager to feed.

questions.text: A 50-year-old women was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has had recurrent vaginal candidiasis in the past 6 months. She also has a history of chronic hypertension, heart failure and has had recurrent pancreatitis due to alcohol abuse. She is abstinent from the past 1 year, does not smoke and does not take illicit drugs. She takes enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin and spironolactone. Her blood sugar is high despite of healthy diet and exercise. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Metformin is the drug of choice in this patient who is recently diagnosed with with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Incorrect answers

B) dapagliflozin is a sodium- glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor which works by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule and thus decrease blood glucose levels by increasing urinary excretion of glucose. SGLT-2 inhibitors increase the risk of Vulvovaginal candidiasis, and UTI’s. Therefore, they are not indicated in this patient who has a history of Vulvovaginal candidiasis.

C) Liraglutide is a GLP-1 analogue and these drugs can cause pancreatitis. Therefore, are not indicated in this patient with a history of recurrent pancreatitis

D) Pioglitazone belongs to the class thiazolidinediones and are not indicated in this patient with heart failure

Educational objective : metformin is a first-line therapy in type 2 DM. Side effects of the drugs are considered before prescribing any medication.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, ectopic 1, presents to your clinic for an advice for next child.Her menstrual cycles are regular, occurring every 28 days. You advice her that it is very important for her to give you a call or to come back to the clinic if she misses her period. The reason for this advice is:

choices.text: Given her history, she has a 33% chance of delivering a live infant
She needs a urine pregnancy test to rule out another ectopic
Her risk of a recurrent ectopic is approximately 15%
Her risk of a recurrent ectopic is approximately 30%

questions.solution:
- Of those women who achieve pregnancy after an ectopic pregnancy, as many as 27% will have another ectopic pregnancy.
- All patients should be counseled about the risk of recurrence. A urine pregnancy test is not as sensitive as a serum hCG and should not be used as the definitive test to determine if a patient is pregnant.
- Also, a pregnancy test alone cannot differentiate between ectopic and intrauterine pregnancy. This patient is not at increased risk for PID based on the information provided.
- Although the patient with a history of a prior ectopic does have a 33% chance of delivering a live infant, this would not be the reason to bring her back to the office if she misses a period.

questions.text: Chest radiographic signs of acute pulmonary embolism include all the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
CXR features of acute PE

1.  Wedge-shaped zone of local oligemia (Westermark’s sign)

2.  Dilated/prominent central pulmonary artery (Palas sign) / Fleischner sign: Enlarged pulmonary artery  

3.  Pleural-based areas of increased opacity that represent intraparenchymal hemorrhage (Hampton’s hump)

4.  In 12–15% patients CXR is normal        

5. pleural effusion 

  Melting snow sign is seen in the pulmonary infarct, which resolves from center to its periphery like a melting snow, viz., consolidation, which resolves from the periphery to center.

questions.text: A professional photographer aged 26 came to your primary clinic complains excruciating pain that is generally situated around one eye and it radiate left side of his face and head. He also reported headaches usually occur every day, sometimes several times a day and each episode last nearly 3o to 45 minutes. He denies recent trauma episodes, aura, vomiting and nausea. Physical examination shows restlessness, excessive tearing, redness of your eye and stuffy or runny nose on the affected side, swelling around his left eye. What is the diagnosis of this patient condition?

choices.text: Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headaches with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT) syndrome

questions.solution:
Cluster headaches are sudden, excruciating headaches that usually affect one side of the head and the area around the eyes. Primary headache disorder characterized by 1-unilateral periorbital pain, 2-ipsilateral cranial autonomic manifestations. A type of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) that typically a single attack can last from 15 minutes to three hours and occurs "clusters". The exact etiology of cluster headaches is unknown, but cluster headache patterns suggest that abnormalities in the body's biological clock play a role. Treatment is Acute therapy: High-flow O2 or sumatriptan injection. Prophylactic therapy verapamil is first line. Alternatives include lithium, valproic acid, and topiramate.

Choice B :Migraine is more common in women and presents as a unilateral throbbing headache that worsens with exercise.

Choice C :Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache attacks with Conjunctival injection and Tearing more common in males. A pituitary tumor causes SUNCT as a secondary headache. Usually very short lasting and the pain is much less severe as compared to cluster headache.

Choice D :Trigeminal neuralgia manifests as pain in the trigeminal nerve distribution. Pain areas is the mouth and face. Heachaches are inconsistent and symptoms respond to carbamazepine.

Educational objective: Cluster headache is a distinctive episodic syndrome of headaches that affects quality of life. Men are more likely to have cluster headaches. Alcohol use, smoking, age, family history are risk factors. Pathophysiology of cluster headache is vascular dilation, trigeminal nerve stimulation, and circadian effects. Histamine release, an increase in mast cells, genetic factors, and autonomic nervous system activation may also contribute.

questions.text: A 3 yrs old child presented with profound Sensorineural deafness, not responding to hearing aids with intact auditory nerve function. Which of the following procedure is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
• In a given case, a 3-year-old child with profound SNHL and auditory nerve is intact so it is basically a cochlear hearing loss where the cochlea is not working.
  • COCHLEAR IMPLANT implant an electrode in Scala Tympani (nearest to VIII th nerve).
  • We enter Scala Tympani through cochleostomy near round window or some times through round window.
  • Cochlear implants are auditory implantable prostheses that electrically stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the cochlear nerve directly in circumstances when the cochlear hair cells themselves do not function effectively to give adequate speech intelligibility. The external components of the cochlear implant i.e. transmitter coil (rounded structure held to the skin with a small magnet), the microphone and the speech processor (worn on the ear).
  • For this patient we can’t apply hearing aids because it is not responding to it.
  • Bone Anchored Hearing Aids use in case of EAC atresia. Titanium screw has osseointegration property.
  • The auditory brainstem implant (ABI) is indicated in severe to profound hearing loss when congenital or acquired abnormalities of the cochlea or auditory nerve (or sometimes both) preclude cochlear implantation (CI). The congenital group (invariably infants and children) includes those with dysplastic or aplastic cochleas and/or auditory nerves while the acquired group predominantly comprises neurofibromatosis type 2 (usually adults) and occasionally acquired cochlear diseases such as otosclerosis or post-meningitic cochlear ossification.
    • Implantation on the brain stem.
    • Cochlear nucleus is in the 4th ventricle.
    • 4th ventricle is entered through the foramen of Lushka.

Learning Objective

  • COCHLEAR IMPLANT PARTS

1. External Body Worn Part

Components

  • Microphone → Receives sound.
  • Speech processor → Converts sound to Electromagnetic waves.
  • Transmitter → Transfers EMW across the layers of skin.

2. Implantable Part

Components

  • Receiver Stimulator
    • Stimulates electrode array
  • Electrode array

3. Contraindications

  • MICHEL’S APLASIA
  • 8TH NERVE APLASIA
  • 8TH NERVE TUMOR

questions.text:
A 59-year-old Caucasian man presents to your office because of recent onset dyspnea on exertion. He is physically active, but his dyspnea now restricts his physical activities. He can hardly climb a flight of stairs without having to stop to rest. He denies any chest pain, palpitations, leg swelling, and loss of consciousness. He has frequent coughing, sometimes with yellowish or greenish sputum He has been smoking one-and-half to tv,o packs of cigarettes daily for the last 35 years He does not consume alcohol. He is currently not taking any medications. The physical examination is significant for bilateral scattered expiratory wheezes. Pulmonary function testing shows the following findings (as a percentage of predicted values):
FEV1 38
RV 120
FEV25-75 45
His airway response to bronchodilators is poor What is the best indicator of this patient's poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has manifestations of advanced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) A FEV1 below 40% of predicted indicates severe obstruction. The prognosis of patients with COPD varies with each individual. The two most important predictors of survival are FEV1 and age. After adjusting for age, FEV1 remains as the single most important factor in determining the prognosis.

Choices B, C, and D : Other prognostic indicators described in several studies are airway responsiveness, cigarette smoking, decreased exercise capacity, decreased BMI, airway bacterial load, and HIV status.

Educational Objective:

After adjusting for age, FEV1 remains as the single most important factor in determining the prognosis of patients with COPD.

questions.text: 77 year old Adam is alone in his home . His children are working abroad. On a fine evening he started having back pain and increasing difficulty with initiating a urinary stream. He was taken to the hospital the next day morning by his Neighbour . Doctor did a digital rectal examination and found that he had a hard, irregularly enlarged prostate. prostate specific antigen(PSA) was elevated and osteoblastic lesions were found on the vertebral column and bones of the pelvis. Well differentiated adenocarcinoma was found on the needle biopsy of the prostate. Which of the following is the treatment of choice ?
questions.solution:
The patient Is suffering from metastatic adenocarcinoma of the prostate. The management is aimed at controlling the tumor for the palliation of the symptoms. Hormonal manipulation by orchiectomy or exogenous estrogen therapy is how we achieve the tumor control.

Incorrect answers :

A. Transurethral prostatectomy not an adequate surgical therapy for prostate malignancy. It is usually done for benign prostatic hyperplasia.

B. Chemotherapy is used as a an adjunct to radical surgical excision of localized disease. It is not indicated for metastatic disease.

C. Radiotherapy is used for the management of the localized disease.

E. Radical prostatectomy is done in patients whose malignancy is confined to the prostate gland alone.

Educational objective : the management of the metastatic adenocarcinoma of the prostate is aimed at controlling the tumor by orchiectomy or exogenous estrogen therapy for the palliation of the patient’s symptoms.

questions.text: A 33-year-old, G3P2, at 32 weeks of gestation, is brought complaining of decreased fetal movements. The physician advises her to do a biophysical profile test to assess fetal well-being. Which of the following is not a part of this test?
questions.solution:
Option C : VIBROACOUSTIC STIMULATION

In this, an artificial sound producing device is kept on the maternal abdomen which emits a sound for several seconds. If there is a non reassuring pattern during a cardiotocographic monitoring, then this test may help in providing fetal well being.

The resultant startle reflex in the fetus and subsequent fetal heart rate acceleration following vibroacoustic stimulation provides assurance of fetal well-being.

Mannings score/ Biophysical profile

Component Score 2 Score 0
Non-stress Test > 2 accelerations of > 15 beats / min for > 15 sec within 20-40 min 0 or 1 acceleration within 20-40 min
Fetal breathing > 1 episode of rhythmic breathing lasting > 30 sec within 30 min < 30 sec of breathing within 30 min
Fetal movement > 3 discrete body or limb movements within 30 min < 3 discrete movements
Fetal Tone > 1 episode of extremity extension and subsequent return to flexion 0 extension / flexion events
Amniotic fluid volume A pocket of amniotic fluid that measures at least 2 cm in two planes perpendicular to each other (2x2 cm pocket) Largest single vertical pocket < 2 cm

 

Modified Biophysical score

  • Non stress test
  • Amniotic fluid volume

Option A, B, D : NST, fetal body movement and fetal respiration are all components of Biophysical profile.

questions.text:
A 7-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents with the complaint of high-pitched whistling sounds with breathing since two weeks of age. The parents report that her condition has gradually worsened over time and is aggravated when the child lies down or cries. Examination findings are significant for inspiratory stridor that is relieved in the prone position. There are no signs of respiratory distress. Laryngoscopy shows the following picture:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above laryngoscopy image shows an Omega-shaped epiglottis (elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself) characteristic of laryngomalacia.

Option A: Laryngomalacia

  • Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.
  • It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx, which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis.
  • Stridor is increased on crying but subsides on placing the child in a prone position; crying itself is normal.
  • The condition manifests at birth or soon after and usually disappears within 2 years.
  • Direct laryngoscopy shows elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself (omega-shaped Ω), floppy aryepiglottic folds, and prominent arytenoids.
  • A flexible laryngoscope is very useful for making the diagnosis.

Option B: Foreign body

  • The patient's chronic history since birth and absence of respiratory distress are less suggestive of the possibility of a foreign body.
  • No evidence of the foreign body is present in the above laryngoscope image.

Option C: Vocal nodule

  • Vocal nodules are benign lesions caused by frequent microtrauma to the vocal cords, such as voice overuse.
  • They can develop in children who cry and scream a lot.
  • They are visible as variable-sized benign growth on the vocal cords. The above laryngoscopy image does not show any evidence of a vocal nodule.

Option D: Laryngeal web

  • The laryngoscopy finding of a membrane joining the anterior portions of the vocal cords is a characteristic of a congenital laryngeal web. In the above image, no such finding is seen.

questions.text: 26 years old female came with a complaint of deviated nasal septum. On examination, You found that there is neither nasal obstruction nor symptoms troubling the day-to-day activities. Which of the following is needed for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Minor degrees of septal deviation with no symptoms are commonly seen in patients and require no treatment.
  • Only when deviated septum produces mechanical nasal obstruction or symptoms then operation is indicated.

SUBMUCOSAL RESECTION-

In this technique, A Killian incision is placed about 1 cm cephalad from the caudal end of the septum. At this point the perichondrium is less adherent to the underlying cartilage and the flap can be raised more easily. The deviation is corrected.

SEPTOPLASTY-

Hemitransfixion incision is designed to provide access to the whole septum. The incision is placed at the caudal edge of the septum. The length of the incision depends on the access required.
Generally, raising the mucosal flap on the concave side would be enough to allow access for excision of septal cartilage and bone, to detach the septal osseocartilaginous junction, to score the concave side and apply other relevant techniques. It also reduces the chance of septal perforation by keeping the opposite mucosa intact.

questions.text: Lady presented 5 days after normal vaginal delivery with heaviness in breast. She complaints that her baby is ‘unable to latch on’ for breast feeding. The most likely reason amongst the following for this is?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of lactation failure is breast engorgement.
  • In 10% of breast engorgement patients may lead to mastitis.
  • Common in women who do not breastfeed.
  • Milk leakage and breast pain peaks 3 to 5 days after delivery

Rx:

  • Analgesia,Cool packs
  • Breasts support/binder/sports bra.
  • Not recommened to suppress lactation.

Other causes: -

  • Sore and cracked nipples
  • Inverted nipples
  • Engorged breasts
  • Mastitis
  • Previous surgeries on breast
  • Neonatal causes
  • Insufficient/Unsuitable milk

questions.text: A 4 year old boy was brought to your clinic for wetting his pants in day time. The parents claim that, he has been like this from the beginning. Upon a examining his genital system, the urethral opening was seen more proximal and ventral when comparing to a normal person. Among which of the following, circumcision is contraindicated ?
questions.solution:
In hypospadias the urethra opens proximally and ventrally. Most commonly, the opening is just proximal to the glans but it can open on the penile shaft or onto the perineum. It is attributed to failure of complete urethral tubularisation in the fetus. The foreskin is deficient ventrally and there is variable degree of chordee (a ventral curvature of the penis most apparent on erection). Glanular hypospadias needs correction fro cosmetic reasons but more proximal anomalies interfere with micturition and erection. A distal hypospadias is usually repaired before 2 years of age in one or two stages. Surgery aims to achieve a terminal urethral meatus so that the boy can stand to micturate with a normal stream, a straight erection and a penis that looks normal. Ritual circumcision is contraindicated in infants with hyposapdias because the foreskin is often required for the reconstriction.

The medical indications for circumcision are:

Phimosis (choice A) - this term is often wrongly applied to describe a normal, non-retractile foreskin. True phimosis is seen as a whitish scarring of the foreskin and is rare before 5 years of age. It is caused by the localised skin disease balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO), which also affects the glans penis and can cause urethral meatal stenosis

Recurrent balanoposthitis (choice B) - a single episode of inflammation of the foreskin, sometimes with a purulent discharge, is not uncommon and usually resolves spontaneously; antibiotics are sometimes needed. Recurrent attacks are unusual but may be an indication for circumcision

Recurrent urinary tract infection (choice D) - Circumcision is occasionally justified in boys with an abnormal upper urinary tract anomaly and recurrent urinary infection. It may also help boys with spina bifida who need to perform clean intermittent urethral catheterization.

Learning objective

The medical indication for circumcision are phimosis, recurrent balanoposthitis and recurrent urinary tract infection. Circumcision is contraindicated in hypospadias.

questions.text: A 38 year ols P3L3 woman presents with secondary dysmenorrhea and on USG there is a uniform enlargement of uterus upto 10 cms. What is the provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Adenomyosis is benign but invasive growth of the endometrium into the muscular layer of the uterus. The patients are usually multiparous, around the age of 40 years.

  • Menorrhagia and progressively increasing dysmenorrhea.
  • Pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia.
  • Clinical examination : symmetrical enlargement of uterus if adenomyosis is diffuse but if it is localized the enlargement is asymmetrical.
  • Uterus is enlarged but seldom more than a ’14 weeks’ pregnant size uterus.
  • Progesterones can be used for relief but the definitive treatment is Hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to you with the complaints of muscle pain accompanied by stiffness in her shoulders, neck and hips for the past several months. She also complains of difficulty in rising from a seated position and combing her hair . she has had fatigue and occasional fever episodes for the past month .On physical examination she has normal muscle strength, tenderness on muscle and limited range of motion of the neck, shoulders, and hips. There is no evidence of giant cell (temporal) arteritis in the history or physical examination . Laboratory work reveals a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL on a complete blood count . Further laboratory results are still pending . Which of the following results would be expected in the work-up of this patient's presenting condition?

choices.text: Increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate and normal serum creatinine kinase
Normal ESR and normal serum creatinine kinase
Normal ESR and increased serum creatinine kinase
Increased serum C-reactive protein and normal ESR

questions.solution:
This is a case of Polymyalgia rheumatica( PMR ) .Its clinical diagnosis is made by the presence of typical symptoms of stiffness, aching, and pain in the muscles of the hip and shoulder girdle, an increased ESR, the absence of clinical features suggestive of giant cell arteritis, and a prompt therapeutic response to low-dose prednisone . While on medication we should also consider supplementing with calcium and vitamin D for prevention of osteoporosis . Methotrexate can be added to treatment regimen for patients on prolonged therapy and with inadequate response to steroids .

Choice B : In Polymyalgia rheumatica the erythrocyte sedimentation rate is markedly increased since it is an inflammatory condition .

Choice C : Increase in serum creatine is seen in Dermatomyositis and polymyositis where this patient do not possess any symptoms of it .

Choice D : In Polymyalgia rheumatica both serum C-reactive protein and ESR will be elevated .

Objective learning : PMR is characterized on laboratory work-up by markedly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), normal serum creatinine kinase (CK), and mild anemia (from chronic disease) on complete blood count.
