questions.text: A 70-year-old male came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain and easy fatigability. He has also been treated twice for urinary tract infections in the last 3 months. An X-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with this diagnosis?

choices.text: Hypercalcemia, high alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, high alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR

questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR is consistent with the suspected diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma in this case. The skull demonstrates the typical "punched out" lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone.

Bone pain is the most common symptom in multiple myeloma. It is caused by the proliferation of tumor cells and increased osteoclast activity. There is also suppression of osteoblast activity to form new bone. This results in hypercalcemia. Bone alkaline phosphatase is a marker of bone growth and is not increased in this patient due to suppressed osteoblast activity.

Recurrent bacterial infections causing pneumonia and urinary tract infections may be the presenting complaint in - 25% of the patients. This is due to reduced immunity because of hypogammaglobulinemia and abnormalities in T-cell functions.

Normocytic normochromic anemia is seen as a result of the replacement of bone marrow by tumor cells and reduced renal function. Chronic inflammation, increased plasma cells and anemia result in increased ESR in multiple myeloma patients.

OTHER OPTIONS

OPTIONS A AND B

Hypercalcemia and increased alkaline phosphatase are seen in hyperparathyroidism.

OPTION C

Multiple myeloma is associated with an increase in ESR.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR is consistent with the suspected diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma . The skull X RAY demonstrates the typical "punched out" lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 70 year old male who has been chewing tobacco for the past 50 years present with a six months history of large, fungating, soft papillary lesions in the oral cavity. The lesion has penetrated into the mandible. Lymph nodes are not palpable. Two biopsies taken from the lesion proper show be­nign appearing papillomatosis with hyperkeratosis and acanthosis infiltrating the subjacent tissues. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option C: Verrucous Carcinoma

  • Typical presentation is on buccal mucosa (50%)thick zone of nonproliferation and nonkeratinizing cells distinguish this histologically Low-grade variant of SCC and is exophytic in appearance. It has the capacity to invade locally and yet carries a low risk of regional spread. Traditionally, this lesion has been considered to be radioresistant.

Option A: Squamous cell papilloma

  • Squamous cell papilloma may be defined as asmall benign (non-cancerous) growththat begins in squamous cells (thin, flat cells) that are found in the tissue that forms the surface of the skin (epidermis), the passages of the respiratory and digestive tract and in the lining of hollow organs of the body.

Option B: Squamous cell carcinoma

  • The site of predilection is the helix . It may present as a painless nodule or an ulcer with raised everted edges and indurated base. Metastases to regional lymph nodes occur very late. Disease is more common in males in their fifties who had prolonged exposure to direct sunlight. Fair-complexioned people are more prone.

Option D: Malignant mixed tumor

  • Malignant mixed tumoris thought to be the mostmalignanttype of myoepithelial tumors, which range from low-grade or benign, high grade and highlymalignant.

Learning Objective:

BUCCAL CARCINOMA

  • Site of origin. Most common site is the angle of mouth or the line of occlusion of upper and lower teeth. It may also arise from the buccal sulcus where “pan” or tobacco quid is kept. As the whole of buccal mucosa is “condemned,” carcinoma may be multicentric.
  • Gross appearance. Lesion may be exophytic or ulceroinfiltrative; the latter may infiltrate deeply. Exophytic type may be associated with erythroleukoplakia.
  • Buccal mucosa is also the most common site for verrucous carcinoma which is a white papillary growth with considerable keratinization. Local spread. From its site of origin, the lesion may spread deeply involving submucosa → muscle → subcutaneous fat → skin. Involvement of buccinator muscle or anterior masseter causes trismus. Tumour may spread radially from its site of origin and involve angle of the mouth and lip anteriorly, retromolar trigone and medial pterygoid posteriorly, upper gingivobuccal sulcus and maxilla superiorly, lower gingivobuccal sulcus and alveolar ridge and gums inferiorly.
  • Lymphatic spread. Nodal involvement occurs in about 50% of cases. Submandibular and later the upper jugular nodes may get involved. Upper jugular nodes may also be involved, directly skipping the submandibular group.
  • Clinical features. Early lesions are asymptomatic. Pain and bleeding are seen when lesions are ulcerative and invade deeply. Involvement of the buccinator, masseter or the pterygoid muscles causes trismus. Fungating mass over the cheek, or a foul-smelling bleeding mass in the oral cavity are late feature

questions.text: Frank is a 5 year old kid living with his parents at a small community housing colony at Hampshire . He usually spends his evening outside playing with his friends or sometimes playing with their dog, Tim, who he got as a birthday present from his aunt . He is from a middle class family and his parents are very open minded and lets him play for long as he wishes. 4 days ago, while playing Frank complained to his mother about a pain on lips and inside mouth. He also complained of muscle aches all over his body. His concerned mother brought it to the attention of a pediatrician. On examination, vesicular lesions were found on the tongue, gingiva, and lips, with some vesicles having ruptured and ulcerated, as well as palpable cervical and submandibular lymphadenopathy. The physician recorded his vital signs which came out as follows : T 39.1, HR 110, BP 90/62, RR 18, SpO2 99%. Which of the following organisms would be the most to probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Image shows a patient with acute herpetic gingivostomatitis.

This patient presents with acute herpetic gingivostomatitis caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1).

Acute primary Herpes Simplex Type 1 virus infection presents in children ages 6 month to 5 years. The oral and labial lesions lasts for 10-14 days, but viral shedding occurs for as long as 20+ days after initial presentation. The initial presentation includes fever, malaise, myalgias, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Many initial acute HSV-1 infections are asymptomatic, with evidence of infection at viral reactivation later in life.

It is usually transmitted during childhood by non-sexual contact. The diagnosis can be made by observation of the vesicular lesions on examination; however, the diagnosis can also be confirmed by culture, PCR, serology, fluorescent antibody testing, or Tzanck smear.

Incorrect Answers:

Choice A : Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the most common etiological agent in infectious mononucleosis.

Choice C: This patient's presentation of oro-labial vesicular lesions, adenopathy, and fever of acute onset at 5 years of age is not consistent with acute HIV infection.

Choice D: HSV-2 more commonly manifests with genital infection; the majority of orolabial infections are caused by HSV-1.

Choice E : Cytomegalovirus (CMV) causes mononucleosis and other potential infections including hepatitis, retinitis, colitis, and pneumonia in immunocompetent patients; It is also a TORCH infection that may lead to congenital abnormalities when transmitted perinatally.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE :

Acute primary Herpes Simplex Type 1 virus infection presents in children ages 6 month to 5 years. The oral and labial lesions lasts for 10-14 days. It is usually transmitted during childhood by non-sexual contact. The diagnosis can be made by observation of the vesicular lesions on examination; however, the diagnosis can also be confirmed by culture, PCR, serology, fluorescent antibody testing, or Tzanck smea

questions.text:
A 22-year-old make presents with the following. His father was recently diagnosed with colorectal adenocarcinoma.



What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
IMAGE 1 shows osteoma of the mandible

IMAGE 2 shows colonic polyps

IMAGE 3 shows epidermoid cyst

Hence , The patient most likely has Gardner’s syndrome .

Familial adenomatous polyposis(FAP)

Eponymous polyposis syndromes now recognized to belong to the general disorder of FAP include: -

  1. Gardner's syndrome (colonic polyps, epidermal inclusion cysts, osteomas)
  2. Turcot's syndrome (colonic polyps and brain tumours)

Osteomas usually present as visible and palpable prominences in the skull, mandible, and tibia of individuals with FAP. They are virtually always benign.

Radiographs of the maxilla and mandible may reveal bone cysts, supernumerary and impacted molars, or congenitally absent teeth.

Desmoid tumours can present in the retroperitoneum and abdominal wall of affected patients, usually after surgery.

Surgical treatment of patients with FAP is directed at removal of all affected colonic and rectal mucosa

OTHER OPTIONS

OPTION A

Turcot's syndrome = colonic polyps and brain tumours

OPTION B

Peutz–Jeghers syndrome(often abbreviated PJS) is an autosomal dominant geneticdisordercharacterized by the development of benign hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and hyperpigmented macules on the lips and oral mucosa (melanosis).

OPTION C

Cowdensyndrome (also known asCowden's diseaseand multiple hamartoma syndrome) is an autosomal dominant inherited condition characterized by benign overgrowths called hamartomas as well as an increased lifetime risk of breast, thyroid, uterine, and other cancers.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

Gardner's syndrome is a subtype offamilial adenomatous polyposis(FAP). It is characterized by colonic polyps, epidermal inclusion cysts, osteomas.

Turcot's syndrome = colonic polyps and brain tumours

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with a family history of multiple malignancies was diagnosed with Paget disease of the nipple. She underwent modified left radical mastectomy, followed by prophylactic contralateral adenomastectomy and bilateral reconstruction with a silicone implant. Five years later, in the follow-up of the breast reconstruction, the patient presented with right-sided recurrent breast swelling for the past 8 months. She is sent to the radiological department for further evaluation for breast imaging. Which of the following is the preferred investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: MRI

Changes in breast shape, size, pain, firmness, and swelling can indicate a ruptured silicone implant, as seen in this patient.

  • MRI is the technique of choice for assessing the integrity of breast implants, with a sensitivity and specificity of over 90%.

  • When imaging breast implants, no contrast agent is required unless malignancy is suspected.

  • Imaging should be performed in the prone position using a dedicated breast coil.

  • The main goal is to determine whether the implant has ruptured and if so, to establish the location of the leaked filler (usually silicon).

Option A: USG

  • Ultrasound can show a "snowstorm appearance" of extracapsular rupture or stepladder sign of intracapsular rupture (a normal implant should usually be anechoic).

  • Ultrasound's sensitivity and specificity are low and are between 59-85% and 55-79%.

Option B: Mammography

  • Mammograms are a screening tool for the early detection of breast cancer.

  • Mammograms are not sensitive enough to detect implant rupture.

  • A mammogram cannot see through a breast implant, so it is not recommended for cancer screening in patients with implants.

Option D: CT scan

  • CT scan is inferior to MRI in delineating soft tissue masses, so it is not recommended to diagnose breast masses.

questions.text: A cataract is an opacity in the transparent lens that leads to blurry vision. The most common type is the senile cataract. A senile cataract passes through different stages of maturation. What is the most common complication of the cataract stage shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Option B: Phacolytic glaucoma

  • The cataract shown in the image is a morgagnian cataract.
  • It is a hyper-mature cataract in which the cortex liquefies, and the nucleus settles at the bottom.
  • There is a risk of leakage of lens proteins through the lens capsule in morgagnian cataract.
  • These proteins can lead to open-angle glaucoma due to a rise in IOP.
  • This type of glaucoma due to leaking lens proteins is called phacolytic glaucoma.
  • It is the most common complication of morgagnian cataracts.

Option A: Angle-closure glaucoma

  • It is due to acute blockage of the iridocorneal angle leading to a rapid rise in IOP due to outflow obstruction to the aqueous humour.
  • The risk factors for this glaucoma are a shallow anterior chamber, shorter axial length and genetic factors.
  • The morgagnian cataract is not associated with angle-closure glaucoma.

Option C: Phacoanaphylactic glaucoma

  • It is due to a granulomatous reaction to the retained lens material.
  • It can occur due to incomplete lens removal during cataract surgery.
  • It is not associated with morgagnian cataracts.

Option D: Phacomorphic glaucoma

  • Phacomorphic glaucoma is a lens-induced secondary angle-closure glaucoma that may occur as a result of mature cataract formation.
  • Narrowing of the angle can occur slowly with formation of the cataract by pushing the iris forward or acutely precipitated by an intumescent cataractous lens leading to obstruction of aqueous flow between the border of the pupil and the anterior capsule of the lens (pupillary block)
  • It is associated with the intumescent cataract, not the morgagnian cataract

questions.text: While doing an ultrasound scan you notice that the echoes at a depth of 4 - 6 cm appear relatively weak. The appropriate action to increase their brightness in the image would be to adjust the:
questions.solution:
The time-gain compensation (TGC) is the control which can be used to selectively amplify the echoes from any specific depth.

There is a tendency for the amplitude of the ultrasound to decrease with time as it travels in tissue. • Time gain compensation (TGC) compensates for the attenuation of the ultrasound wave with time as it travels  in tissues. If THC is not adjusted significant artefacts may result.

questions.text: A female newborn presents with a square shaped skull with a short occipital–frontal diameter. Premature closure of which of the following sutures is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution: Brachycephaly is the premature closure of the coronal sutures, which leads to a square-shaped skull with a short occipital–frontal diameter.

questions.text: 25 year old Aidan was going to a party. The time was already midnight. He didn’t put the seat belt on while driving. His car involved in a road traffic accident came to the emergency department. On arrival in the emergency department, the patient is noted to have stridor, with marked respiratory distress, and an oxygen saturation of 88% despite 100% oxygen by mask. He has extensive facial injuries, a flail chest, and poor chest expansion. Bag-mask-valve ventilation is ineffective. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer:

Option E: This patient has an obstructed airway from maxillary-facial trauma. The patient is stridorous, hypoxic, and cannot be ventilated with bag and mask. Immediate cricothyroidotomy will be lifesaving.

Incorrect answers:

Option A: With severe facial trauma, orotracheal intubation is likely to be difficult because of distortion of landmarks and excessive oropharyngeal secretions.

Option B: Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in this setting.

Option C: Stabilization of the airway is the first resuscitation priority, before placement of bilateral chest tubes to relieve potential pneumothoraces.

Option D : A definitive tracheostomy is more time consuming than a cricothyroidotomy and requires specific surgical expertise.

Educational objective:

  • Endotracheal intubation: Preferred method, even in setting of cervical spinal trauma.
  • Nasotracheal intubation w/fiberoptic bronchoscope: Preferred if tracheobronchial tree is ruptured. Contraindicated if basilar skull fracture (risk for intracranial penetration).
  • Emergency cricothyroidotomy: Attempt only if other methods are ineffective.
  • Emergency tracheostomy: In general, never do this. Choose cricothyroidotomy instead.

questions.text: The national plan of action of the Government of India focuses on under-served areas with an emphasis on community participation. It facilitates the formation of state-level Vision 2020- plans of action and programmes led by the state governments, along with intensive input from local and international NGOs. According to the Indian version of Vision 2020, which of the following diseases is not included?
questions.solution:
Option D: Onchocerciasis

  • Onchocerciasis is absent in India. Therefore, it is not included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by the WHO.
  • 'Vision 2020: The Right to Sight',10 is a global initiative launched by WHO in Geneva on Feb. 18, 1999, in a broad coalition with a 'Task Force of International Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs) to combat the massive problem of blindness in the world.
  • The objective of Vision 2020:

This new global initiative aims to eliminate avoidable blindness by the year 2020 and to reduce the global burden of blindness, which currently affects an estimated 45 million people worldwide.

  • Strategic approaches of Vision 2020: Right to Sight (Global perspective) are:
    • Disease prevention and control,
    • Training of eye health personnel,
    • Strengthening of existing eye care infrastructure,
    • Use of appropriate and affordable technology, and
    • Mobilisation of resources.
  • Disease prevention and control: Globally, WHO has identified five major blinding eye conditions for immediate attention to achieve the goals of Vision 2020, which are:
    • Cataract
    • Childhood blindness
    • Trachoma
    • Refractive errors and low vision
    • Onchocerciasis
  • These conditions have been chosen based on their contribution to the burden of blindness, feasibility and affordability of interventions to control them.
  • Each country will decide its priorities based on the magnitude of specific blinding conditions in that country.

Option A: Diabetic retinopathy

  • Diabetic retinopathy is considered in place of onchocerciasis in the Indian version of the right to sight.

Option B: Glaucoma

  • Glaucoma has been included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by WHO.

Option C: Refractive error

  • Refractive errors and low vision have been included in Vision 2020: Right to sight by WHO.

questions.text: A woman, gravid 0, para 0,underwent infertility evaluation. The infertility was diagnosed as being secondary to an ovulation because of polycystic ovary syndrome. Which of the following statements is most likely to be true?

choices.text: She has a low body mass index
Androgen production is primarily from adrenals

questions.solution:
- The underlying mechanism in polycystic ovary syndrome is a tonically elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) level that results in absence of normal menstrual hormone fluctuations.
- The body mass index is usually high, not low. Although hirsutism is common, virilization is not seen.
- The androgen production is largely from the ovary, rather than the adrenals.

questions.text: Madison is a 4-year-old girl living in Tennessee. She is daughter of Rebecca who works as a fitness instructor at a New Orleans Gym. She had left her job ever since she gave birth to Madison. She usually takes good care of Madison at home and is not ready to hire anyone to babysit her. Recently She noticed that Madison had been scratching her head a lot. She also is losing considerable amount of her Hair every time she combs. She is concerned that her daughter is balding. She immediately brings this to the attention of her family paediatrician. The Doctor measured her vital which given below : temperature is 101°F (37.6°C), blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg, pulse is 99/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination showed that the child's scalps as in image A. The Doctor did a Wood's UV lamp examination which caused the hair to fluorescence bright green. which confirm the diagnosis. What is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Figure A shows a ring-shaped, scaly eruption on the scalp of a child with microsporum canis infection.

This patient is diagnosed with tinea capitis., Fluorescence under Wood's UV lamp indicates microsporum canis infection.

Tinea capitis is a fungal infection leading to ring-shaped lesions on the scalp. The infection is most often caused by dematophytes in the genera Microsporum and Trichophyton. These can be differentiated with the Wood's UV lamp, as Microsporum fluoresces while Trichophyton does not. Tinea capitis is most commonly seen in children, but is also common in immunocompromised adults.

Tinea infections are communicable and most develop after direct contact with humans or animals that are infected, or indirectly from fomites. Diagnosis is often derived from history and physical examination and KOH microscopy. While most tinea infections typically responds to topical anti-fungal therapy, some tinea infections, including tinea capitis, require oral anti-fungal medications such as terbinafine, fluconazole, itraconazole, or griseofulvin.

Incorrect Answers:

Choice A: Trichophyton tonsurans is a common ethology of tinea capitis; however, it does not fluoresce under Wood's UV lamp exam.

Choice B: Toxocara canis is a nematode that causes visceral larva migrans

Choice C: Malassezia furfur commonly causes tinea versicolor, a cutaneous mycosis that presents as hypo- and hyper-pigmented patches of skin.

Educational Objective:

Tinea capitis is a fungal infection leading to ring-shaped lesions on the scalp. The infection is most often caused by dematophytes in the genera Microsporum and Trichophyton. These can be differentiated with the Wood's UV lamp, as Microsporum fluoresces while Trichophyton does not.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department for severe pain and swelling in her lower extremity . He stated the pain scale to be 9/10 and it happened in a short duration. The patient has a past medical history of obesity, diabetes, and seizures disorder . He is currently on metformin, insulin, and valproic acid. The patient is a IV drug abuser and alcoholic. His vitals are BP-140/90,PR- 98, RR-18. On physical exam you note anasarca and asymmetric lower extremity swelling. Lab investigations and ultasound was done .Based on the ultrasound finding the patient was started on Heparin. Urinalysis showed a fatty cast . Laboratory studies are shown below. 
Na+: 139 mEq/L, K+: 5.7 mEq/L, HCO3-: 23 mEq/L, Urea nitrogen: 20mg/dL , Ca2+: 5.5 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL ,random Glucose: 70 mg/dL
what do you think be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
It classically presents with heavy proteinuria,minimal hematuria, hypoalbuminemia, hypercholesterolemia, edema and hypertension.Edema secondary to salt and water retention can be controlled with the judicious use of diuretics, avoiding intravascular volume depletion. Venous complications secondary to the hypercoag- ulable state associated with nephrotic syndrome can be treated with anticoagulants. In this case heparin is started due to DVT .( ulrasound finding)

Choice A : Based on the given information such as alcohol use and iv drug use Liver failure is possible placing the patient at risk for chronic hepatitis C infection. But the other symptoms of liver failure such as jaundice or ascites is absent , making the nephrotic syndrome more likely.

Choice B : Antithrombin III deficiency may lead to hypercoagulable state and it is the closest variant among all choices to provide a possible explanation for this patient's DVT. however, it does not explain his hypocalcemia. Patients with nephrotic syndrome NS) lose 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 (25OHD3) in the urine and have low blood levels of this metabolite. This abnormality may be responsible for the hypocalcemia, i.e. low ionized calcium. The mechanism of the hypocalcemia is not evident.

Choice C: Factor V Leiden is the most common cause of a hypercoagulable state and explains patient's DVT. Same like anti thrombin III deficiency it does not explain his profound hypocalcemia.

Objective learning : In nephrotic syndrome venous insufficiency can also happen secondary to the hypercoagulable state.

questions.text: Arilla was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 2 years ago when she was 13 years old. She was managed with steroid therapy. Now she presents to the emergency department with a 36 hour history of nausea, severe bloody diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain. On examination she is febrile and pale . She has a blood pressure of 90/60 mmhg and a heart rate of 128 bpm. On examination her abdomen is distended and diffusely tender. Leukocytosis is demonstrated in a CBC with a left shift. The patient receives IV fluid resuscitation and nasogastric tube decompression. Which of the following could be the choice for further therapeutic intervention?

choices.text: high-dose IV steroids and broad-spectrum antibiotics

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option E, high-dose IV steroids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

This patient presents with an acute exacerbation of ulcerative colitis with systemic toxicity. Toxic megacolon is potentially life threatening and requires aggressive fluid resuscitation, bowel rest, and systemic antibiotics. High-dose steroids are initiated to treat the colonic inflammation.

Incorrect answers :

  1. Azathioprine is an immunosuppressive agent that may be beneficial in the treatment of steroid refractory colitis, but they are not indicated in the management of an acute toxic exacerbation.
  2. Opioid antidiarrheals are contraindicated in this case, because they may increase colonic distention and increase the risk of perforation.
  3. Colonoscopy may cause increased colonic distention with perforation.
  4. 6-mercaptopurine is also an immunosuppressive agent that may be beneficial in the treatment of steroid refractory colitis, but they are not indicated in the management of an acute toxic exacerbation.

Educational objective : acute exacerbation of ulcerative colitis with systemic toxicity such as Toxic megacolon is a potentially life threatening condition that requires aggressive fluid resuscitation, bowel rest, and systemic antibiotics. High-dose steroids are initiated to treat the colonic inflammation.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at term pregnancy in labour. On examination she has good uterine contractions and fetal heart. Vaginal examination reveals a cervical dilatation of 4 cm, fetal head at +1 station and a clinically adequate pelvis. The most likely position of the fetal head in this case is?
questions.solution:
The most likely position of the fetal head in this case is:

  1. Right occipito anterior

Explanation: During labor, the fetal head's position in the maternal pelvis is an essential aspect of the progress of labor and the delivery process. Fetal head positions are described using three letters: the first letter indicates the location of the fetal head in the right (R) or left (L) side of the mother's pelvis, the second letter indicates the fetal head's location in relation to the mother's pelvis as anterior (A), posterior (P), or transverse (T), and the third letter indicates the specific fetal head position in relation to the mother's pelvis as either occiput (O), sacrum (S), or mentum (M).

In this case, the description given in the question is "+1 station," which means the fetal head is 1 cm below the ischial spines. Since the station is +1, this indicates that the fetal head is descending into the pelvis.

Let's analyze the options:

  1. Right occipital posterior: This position indicates that the fetal head is on the right side (right occipital), but it is located posteriorly. In this position, the back of the fetal head (occiput) is towards the mother's back. This position is not the most likely choice in this case because the fetal head is at +1 station, indicating it is actively descending into the pelvis, which is more consistent with an anterior position.

  2. Left occipito transverse: This position indicates that the fetal head is on the left side (left occipito), but it is located transversely. In this position, the back of the fetal head is facing the mother's side. Again, this position is less likely as the fetal head is actively descending into the pelvis.

  3. Right occipito anterior: This position indicates that the fetal head is on the right side (right occipito) and located anteriorly. In this position, the back of the fetal head (occiput) is facing the mother's front. Given that the fetal head is at +1 station and actively descending into the pelvis, the right occipito anterior position is the most likely choice.

  4. Left mento anterior: This position indicates that the fetal chin (mento) is on the left side (left) and located anteriorly. This position is not the most likely choice because the question mentions the fetal head's position, and the fetal chin is not typically used to describe the fetal head's position in this context.

questions.text: Margot was cleaning her toilet. She didn’t notice that her 5 year old child was playing with the drain cleaner liquid. Her child spilled the liquid to his hands . His hands were injured and he started crying. Margot immediately took him to the nearby clinic in her car. It took her 15 minutes to reach there. On arrival at the clinic, the boy was holding his right hand in the flexed position. His temperature was normal. He had a blood pressure of105/70. His heart rate was 100 bpm. He was not able to flex or extend his hands completely. Palpable radial pulses were present. On examination he had a 4x4 area of reddened blistered skin. It was very tender to light touch. Capillary refill time is less than 3 seconds. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in the management?
questions.solution:
irrigation with warm water is the initial step in management for the majority of chemical skin burns. It dilutes and washes off the offending agent from the skin. Irrigation should be done until the pH of the affected tissue has become neutral, which may take several hours in case of alkaline burns.

Incorrect answers :

Option A : Wound debridement is done to promote wound healing and decrease the risk of infection from the necrotic tissue. This patient may require wound debridement, but first the offending agent has to be removed from the skin to prevent further burn progression.

Option B : Mineral oil is applied to treat skin burns caused by elemental metals (e.g., lithium, potassium, sodium, or magnesium).

Option C : Silver sulfadiazine is a topical antibiotic which is used in cases of severe and/or widespread, full-thickness burns. this patient's burn lacks Eschar and is tender which are suggestive of a partial-thickness burn. he may require antibiotics eventually, but topical antibiotics would not be the most appropriate next step in management.

Educational objective : irrigation with warm water is the initial step in management for the majority of chemical skin burns. It dilutes and washes off the offending agent from the skin. Irrigation should be done until the pH of the affected tissue has become neutral, which may take several hours in case of alkaline burns.

questions.text: A 40 year old male was brought to the emergency bay after a motor vehicle accident. The prior incident; when he was hanging out with his friends in his garden, he was stung by a bee. Knowing that he is allergic to bee sting, he was rushed to the hospital for treatment. On the way, he met with an accident and landed on his spine and lost a lot of blood. Upon arrival he vitals were, BP- 90/70 mmHg; RR- 12 bpm; HR- 125 bpm; TEMP- 35 C. This patient is in which type of shock ?
questions.solution:
Distributive shock describes the pattern of cardiovascular responses characterizing a variety of conditions, including septic shock, anaphylaxis and spinal cord injury. Inadequate organ perfusion is accompanied by vascular dilatation with hypotension, low systemic vascular resistance , inadequate afterload and a resulting abnormally high cardiac output.

In anaphylaxis, vasodilation is due to histamine release, while in spinal cord injury there is a failure of sympathetic outflow and adequate vascular tone (neurogenic shock). The cause in sepsis is less clear but is related to the release of bacterial products (endotoxin) and the activation of cellular and humoral components of the immune system. There is maldistribution of the blood flow at a microvascular level with ateriovenous shunting and disfunction of cellular utilization of oxygen. In the later phases of the septic shock there is hypovolemia from fluid loss into interstitial spaces and there may be concomitant myocardial depression, complicating the clinical picture.

Choice A - hypovolemic shock. Hypovolemic shock is due to a reduced circulating volume. Hypovolemia may be due to haemorrhagic or non-haemorrhagic causes.

Choice B - cardiogenic shock. It is due to primary failure of heart to pump blood to the tissues. Causes include myocardial infarction, cardiac dysarrhythmias, valvular heart disease, blunt myocardial injury and cardiomyopathy.

Choice C - obstructive shock. There is a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling. Causes include cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, massive pulmonary embolus or air embolus.

Learning objective

Distributive shock describes the pattern of cardiovascular responses characterizing a variety of conditions, including septic shock, anaphylaxis and spinal cord injury. Inadequate organ perfusion is accompanied by vascular dilatation with hypotension, low systemic vascular resistance , inadequate afterload and a resulting abnormally high cardiac output.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents to his physician with the complaint of loss of peripheral vision. Which of the following findings are demonstrated by the subsequent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan, shown here?
questions.solution:
This T1-weighted sagittal MRI scan shows a dumbbell-shaped homogeneous mass involving the sella turcica and the suprasellar region. This lesion is most consistent with a pituitary adenoma, a benign tumor arising from the adenohypophysis. Pituitary adenomas are the most common sellar lesion and constitute 10% to 15% of all intracranial neoplasms. Macroadenomas are greater than 1 cm in size and microadenomas less than 1 cm. Pituitary adenomas may be functional, resulting in endocrinopathies from excessive hormone secretion, such as prolactin (amenorrhea or galactorrhea), growth hormone (gigantism or acromegaly), or adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH) (Cushing syndrome). The tumor pictured is a macroadenoma; these larger tumors may cause symptoms secondary to mass effect; for example, a bitemporal visual field defect can result from compression of the optic chiasm. This tumor’s dumbbell shape results from impingement on the adenoma by the diaphragm of the sella turcica. The suprasellar extension seen here makes a frontal craniotomy rather than the more commonly utilized transsphenoidal approach more appropriate.

Bottom Line

Macroadenoma may cause symptoms secondary to mass effect and bitemporal visual field defect can result from compression of the optic chiasm.

questions.text: Which of the following can deliver 100% oxygen?
questions.solution:
Anesthetic face mask

  • delivers 100% oxygen.
  • These face masks have a cuff that allows for a complete seal to be achieved between the mask and the patient's face. Anesthetic face masks can therefore be used to deliver non-invasive ventilation (NIV). In order to ventilate with an anesthetic face mask you'll need a pressurized gas source (anesthesia gas supplies) such as a cylinder or gas wall supply.If no pressurized gas source is available,a self-inflating bag will allow for positive pressure-ventilation through an anesthetic face mask.
  • The cuff volume can typically be adjusted through a valve.A somewhat under-inflated cuff usually achieves a better seal than a fully inflated one.
  • Most manufacturers supply these masks with a detachable hook ring which allows for the mask to be held in place with a head strap for delivering NIV.

USES

Anaesthetic facemasks are generally used in two different settings/ scenarios:

1. For bag-mask ventilation (BMV) in the resuscitation setting.

2. To provide non-invasive ventilation (NIV) or respiratory support,most commonly as either continuous or biphasisc positive airway pressure (CPAP or BIPAP) in patients with respiratory compromise.

questions.text: An 35 year old male illegal immigrant from tropical regions of South East Asia residing near the sea, was brought to the emergency bay for fever and upper abdominal discomfort associated with malaise and anorexia. He complains of generalized itching. He also exhibited signs of biliary colic and jaundice. Stool examination revealed eggs of the Clonorchis sinensis. What is the ideal drug of choice in this patient ?
questions.solution:
The signs and symptoms of this case is consistent with ‘Asiatic Cholangiohepatitis’ and is confirmed by the presence of the eggs (of Clonorchis sinensis ) in the stool sample. It has high incidence in the tropical regions of South East Asia. In humans, the parasite matures into the adult worm in the intra hepatic biliary radicles where they may reside for many years. The intra hepatic bile ducts are dilated, with epithelial hyperplasia and periductal fibrosis. These changes may lead to dysplasia, causing cholangiocarcinoma. Parziquantel and albendazole are the drugs of choice. Cholecystectomy with exploration of the common bile duct is performed when indicated.

Choices A & C - Metronidazole and Albendazole are given in roundworm infection.

Choice B - Metronodazole and tinidazole. This combination is given in Amoebiasis.

Choice E - Diethylcarbamazine. This drug is used to treat Filariasis.

Learning objective

Praziquantel and albendazole are the drugs of choice for treating Asiatic Cholangiohepatitis.

questions.text: A 32 year old , G3A2, presents with 32 weeks of pregnancy and labour pains. She has a history of previous 2 miscarriages in the 4th and 5th months of pregnancy. On examination, uterine contractions are present and cervix is 2 cm dilated. Management of this patient includes all of the following, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Option A : A cerclage is best done between 12 to 24 weeks ( American Guidelines). In India we do cerclage even up till 28 weeks since fetus is said to be viable after 28 weeks in India still.

  • If a patient is 32 weeks and already in labour, performing a cerclage is not of much benefit since viability of the fetus is already achieved . Management protocol here will include steroids to make sure that the newborn does not get Respiratory distress of Newborn.
  • Any cervical handling will only increase the local prostaglandins which will further increase the preterm labour contractions.

Incompetent OS (Short Cervix [<2.5 cm])

  • Short cervix effaces early
  • Predisposes to both Preterm Labor & Abortion
  • Characterized by painless dilatation followed by expulsion of fetus
  • Mx by Encerclage: Applied > 12 weeks, removed after 37 weeks
  • Most Commonly used→ MC Donald’s cerclage, other : Shirodkar stitch (more complicated), abdominal encerclage.

Contraindications to encerclage

  • Active preterm labor
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • PPROM
  • Fetal compromise
  • Fetal anomaly
  • Fetal death

Option B : Steroid coverage must be given with betamethasone or dexamethasone as the patient is in preterm labor.

Option C : Antibiotic cover may be given if any vaginal or pelvic or urinary infection is suspected.

Option D : Tocolytics may be given as she is in latent preterm labor, the main role of which would be to give time for steroids to act or to transfer the patient to another facility.

questions.text: Ben is a 7 year old is a preschool kid, studying at Parma Preschool, Ohio. His mother Jenny, working as a beautician at Clintonville Beauty Salon. A week ago, Jenny notices a diffuse itchy rash over Ben's abdomen, back and upper legs. He had no there associated symptoms and was well and had no sick contacts. She decided to visit the doctor at the weekend. At the doctors office, a physician examination was performed. he was afebrile and cooperative. A skin examination was done. The examination revealed single large, well-circumscribed pink plaque over his mid-abdomen, and many pink papules of varying sizes over his abdomen, back, and thighs as shown in the image. The doctor suggested observation and follow up for a month. On his next visit to the clinic, the rash resolved itself without any intervention. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image A shows "herald patch" of pityriasis rosea (a large, annular pink plaque and overlying scaling).

Image B shows the distribution of pityriasis rosea in a "Christmas tree" pattern over the back.

Pityriasis rosea is a common, acute rash, commonly affecting children and young adults. Proper etiology is still unknown. HHV6 and HHV7 are possible viral causes. It's marked by an initial herald patch, followed by a diffuse papulosquamous rash. The secondary rash appears as a "Christmas tree" pattern over the back, as seen in Image B. There is no confirmatory diagnostic test. While it resolves on its own, topical or systemic steroids and antihistamines are used to relieve pruritis.

A healthy child showing signs of large pink, scaly "herald patch" and many surrounding pink papules over the abdomen and back is significant of pityriasis rosea. The rash is self-limiting and will resolve without intervention within 3-4 weeks.

The differential diagnosis for patients who presenting with large, annular lesion and surrounding papulosquamous exanthem includes guttate psoriasis, nummular eczema, tinea corporis, secondary syphilis, pityriasis lichenoides, viral exanthem, lichen planus, and medication reaction. The rash of pityriasis rosea lasts about 5 weeks and resolves by 8 weeks in more than 80 percent of patients.

A study suggested that Acyclovir may be effective in the treatment of pityriasis rosea, especially in patients treated in the first week from onset, this is when replicative viral activity of HHV is probably very high.

Incorrect Answers:

Choice A : Tinea corporis (ring worm) is a fungal infection presenting with large annular lesions and also needs medical intervention.

Choice B : Tinea versicolor is a yeast infection presenting as hypopigmented macules and patches over the abdomen and back.

Choice D : Urticaria presents with pruritic pink, annular plaques and papules (also called wheals), but doesn't commonly persist for 7 days.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

Pityriasis rosea is a common, acute rash, commonly affecting children and young adults. It's marked by an initial herald patch, followed by a diffuse papulosquamous rash. The secondary rash appears as a "Christmas tree" pattern over the back. The rash is self-limiting and will resolve without intervention within 3-4 weeks.

questions.text: A woman has her pregnancy suddenly terminated due to intrauterine fetal death. At autopsy, the fetus shows severe pallor, generalized edema, and hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following would you suspe.
questions.solution: D. Hydrops fetalis is the most severe form of alpha -thalassemia, and is a direct result of the lack or decreased synthesis of the alpha-globin chain of hemoglobin alpha2beta2.

questions.text: While on Emergency duty, a psychiatry resident is called to assess a 15 month old child in pediatric ward who has developed a muscle spasm in his neck causing him to have a twisted neck, and difficulty in opening mouth since last 1 hour. The child was admitted 4 days back in view of an abdominal infection for which he had been receiving appropriate treatment and care. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause for the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
(C ) DOMPERIDONE : The child in the case vignette has drug-induced movement disorder, named Acute dystonia. It is an extra-pyramidal sign(EPS) and a common complication of Domperidone administration in infants and young children due to their poorly developed blood brain barrier. It is a reversible condition which subsides after discontinuation of the offending agent.

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

(A) Erythromycin

Its is a macrolide antibiotic used to treat infections in pediatric and adult age group. It does not cause EPS.

(B) Pantoprazole

It is a Proton pump inhibitor not known to cause acute dystonic reaction.

(D) Metronidazole

It is the treatment of choice for anaerobic bacterial infections. It’s toxicity can cause features of encephalopathy and seizures, but unlikely EPS.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

Drugs causing EPS are metoclopramide, antipsychotics, Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, Domperidone.
